text: why is this medication prescribed? hydralazine is used to treat high blood pressure. hydralazine is in a class of medications called vasodilators. it works by relaxing the blood vessels so that blood can flow more easily through the body. high blood pressure is a common condition and when not treated, can cause damage to the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys and other parts of the body. damage to these organs may cause heart disease, a heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, loss of vision, and other problems. in addition to taking medication, making lifestyle changes will also help to control your blood pressure. these changes include eating a diet that is low in fat and salt, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and using alcohol in moderation. how should this medicine be used? hydralazine comes as a tablet to take by mouth. it usually is taken two to four a day. take hydralazine at around the same times every day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand. take hydralazine exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. hydralazine controls high blood pressure but does not cure it. continue to take hydralazine even if you feel well. do not stop taking hydralazine without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine hydralazine is also used after heart valve replacement and in the treatment of heart failure. talk to your doctor about the possible risks of using this medication for your condition. this medication is sometimes prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking hydralazine,and pharmacist if you are allergic to hydralazine, aspirin, tartrazine a yellow dye in some processed foods and medications, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in hydralazine tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients.and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while taking hydralazine. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects.if you have ever had a heart attack, or have coronary artery disease, rheumatic heart disease, or heart, kidney or liver disease.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking hydralazine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking hydralazine. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol while you are taking hydralazine. alcohol can make the side effects from hydralazine worse. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take hydralazine with meals or a snack. your doctor may prescribe a low-salt or low-sodium diet. follow these directions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? hydralazine may cause side effects.if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: flushing headache upset stomach vomiting loss of appetite diarrhea constipation eye tearing stuffy nose rash some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately: fainting joint or muscle pain fever rapid heartbeat chest pain swollen ankles or feet numbing or tingling in hands or feet

name: hydrocodone
text: important warning: hydrocodone can be habit forming. take hydrocodone exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it, take it more often, stop taking it suddenly, or take it in a different way than directed by your doctor. if you or anyone in your family drinks or has ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, uses or has ever used street drugs, or has overused prescription medications, or has had an overdose, or if you have or have ever had depression or another mental illness. hydrocodone may cause slowed or stopped breathing, especially during the first 24 to 72 hours of your treatment and any time your dose is increased.if you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: slowed breathing, long pauses between breaths, or shortness of breath. hydrocodone may harm or cause death to other people who take your medication, especially children. keep hydrocodone in a safe place so that no one else can take it accidentally or on purpose. taking certain medications, drinking alcohol, or using street drugs while you are taking hydrocodone may increase the risk that you will experience breathing problems, sedation, coma, or other serious, life-threatening side effects.and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, and nutritional supplements you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully. swallow hydrocodone extended-release capsules or extended-release tablets whole; do not chew, break, divide, crush, or dissolve them. hydrocodone extended-release capsules and extended-release tablets are difficult to crush, break or dissolve. if you swallow broken, chewed, or crushed extended-release capsules or extended-release tablets, you may receive too much hydrocodone at once.if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. if you take hydrocodone regularly during your pregnancy, your baby may experience life-threatening withdrawal symptoms after birth. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the manufacturer's patient information sheet medication guide when you begin treatment with hydrocodone and each time you refill your prescription. read the information carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking hydrocodone. why is this medication prescribed? hydrocodone is used to relieve severe pain. hydrocodone is in a class of medications called opiate narcotic analgesics. it works by changing the way the brain and nervous system respond to pain. this monograph only includes information about the use of hydrocodone alone. if you are taking a hydrocodone combination product, be sure to read information about all the ingredients in the hydrocodone-combination monograph and ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? hydrocodone comes as an extended-release long-acting capsule and an extended-release long-acting tablet to take by mouth. take the extended-release capsule once every 12 hours. take the extended-release tablet once daily. take hydrocodone at around the same times every day. swallow the extended-release capsules or extended-release tablets one at a time with plenty of water. swallow each capsule or tablet as soon as you put it in your mouth. do not presoak, wet, or lick the extended-release tablets before you put them in your mouth. your doctor may adjust your dose of hydrocodone during your treatment, depending on how well your pain is controlled and on the side effects that you experience. talk to your doctor about how you are feeling during your treatment with hydrocodone.if you feel that your pain is not controlled or if your pain increases, becomes worse, or if you have new pain or an increased sensitivity to pain during your treatment with hydrocodone. do not take more of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. talk to your doctor or pharmacist about access to rescue medicines, naloxone or nalmefene, while taking hydrocodone. rescue medications can reverse the life-threatening effects of an opioid overdose and are available over the counter or with a prescription. make sure that you and your family members and people usually around you know how to recognize an overdose, how to use naloxone or nalmefene, and what to do until emergency medical help arrives. your doctor or pharmacist will show you and others how to use it. if symptoms of an overdose occur, they should give the first dose of naloxone, call 911 immediately, and stay with you and watch you closely until emergency medical help arrives. if your symptoms return, the person should give you another dose of the rescue medication. additional doses may be given every 2 to 3 minutes, if symptoms return before medical help arrives. do not stop taking hydrocodone without talking to your doctor. if you suddenly stop taking hydrocodone, you may experience withdrawal symptoms such as restlessness, teary eyes, runny nose, yawning, sweating, chills, hair standing on end, muscle pain, widened pupils black circles in the middle of the eyes, irritability, anxiety, back or joint pain, weakness, stomach cramps, difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep, nausea, loss of appetite, vomiting, diarrhea, fast breathing, or fast heartbeat. your doctor will probably decrease your dose gradually. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking hydrocodone,or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any part of this drug, or any other drugs, foods or substances.or pharmacist about the allergy and what symptoms you had. some medications should not be taken with hydrocodone. make sure you have discussed any medications you are currently taking or plan to take before starting hydrocodone with your doctor and pharmacist. before starting, stopping, or changing any medications while taking hydrocodone, please get the advice of your doctor or pharmacist.or pharmacist if you are taking the following medications or have stopped taking them within the past two weeks: isocarboxazid, linezolid, methylene blue, phenelzine, selegiline, or tranylcypromine. the following nonprescription or herbal products may interact with hydrocodone: st. john's wort and tryptophan. be sure to let your doctor and pharmacist know that you are taking these medications before you start taking hydrocodone. do not start these medications while taking hydrocodone without discussing it with your healthcare provider.if you have slowed breathing, asthma, chronic pulmonary disease copd, or other lung problems; a blockage or narrowing of your stomach or intestines, or paralytic ileus condition in which digested food does not move through the intestines. your doctor may tell you not to take hydrocodone.if you have or have or ever had ever had a brain tumor, or any condition that increases the amount of pressure in your brain; seizures; or thyroid, gall bladder, pancreas, heart, liver, or kidney disease.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking hydrocodone, call your doctor. you should know that this medication may decrease fertility in men and women. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking hydrocodone. you should know to not drink alcoholic beverages while you are taking hydrocodone. alcohol can make the side effects fromhydrocodone worse. you should know that hydrocodone may make you drowsy. do not drive a car or operate machinery until you know how this medication affects you. you should know that hydrocodone may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, and fainting when you get up too quickly from a lying position. this is more common when you first start taking hydrocodone. to avoid this problem, get out of bed slowly, resting your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing up. you should know that hydrocodone may cause constipation. talk to your doctor about changing your diet and using other medications to treat or prevent constipation. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take more than one dose of hydrocodone extended-release capsules in 12 hours or extended-release tablets in 24 hours. what side effects can this medication cause? hydrocodone may cause side effects.if any of these symptoms or those in the special precautions section are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, stomach pain increased sweating decreased sexual desire, inability to get or keep an erection some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the important warning, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: agitation, hallucinations seeing things or hearing voices that do not exist, fever, sweating, confusion, fast heartbeat, shivering, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, loss of coordination, or diarrhea nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, weakness, or dizziness chest pain, changes in heartbeat rash; hives; hoarseness; difficulty breathing or swallowing; or swelling of the face, mouth, tongue or throat seizures extreme drowsiness new pain or pain from touch or doing ordinary tasks such as combing your hair difficulty swallowing, regurgitation bringing up swallowed food into throat and mouth, pain in the chest area unusual snoring or long pauses during breaths during sleep hydrocodone may cause other side effects.

name: hydroxychloroquine
text: why is this medication prescribed? hydroxychloroquine is used to prevent and treat acute attacks of malaria in adults and children weighing more than 31 kg 68 lbs. it is also used to treat discoid lupus erythematosus dle; a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin or systemic lupus erythematosus sle or lupus; an autoimmune disease in which the immune system attacks healthy parts of the body such as joints, skin, blood vessels, and organs and rheumatoid arthritis. hydroxychloroquine is in a class of drugs called antimalarials and is also an antirheumatic drug. it works by killing the organisms that cause malaria. hydroxychloroquine may work to treat rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus by decreasing the activity of the immune system. how should this medicine be used? hydroxychloroquine comes as a tablet to take by mouth. hydroxychloroquine tablets should be taken with food or milk. if you are taking hydroxychloroquine to prevent malaria, one dose is usually taken once a week on exactly the same day of each week. you will begin treatment 1 to 2 weeks before you travel to an area where malaria is common and then continue during your time in the area and for 4 weeks after you return. if you are taking hydroxychloroquine to treat malaria, the first dose is usually taken right away, followed by another dose 6 hours later and then 2 additional doses, 24 and 48 hours after the first dose. if you are taking hydroxychloroquine to treat lupus erythematosus dle or sle or rheumatoid arthritis, it is usually taken once or twice a day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand. take hydroxychloroquine exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. swallow the tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. if you are taking hydroxychloroquine for symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, your symptoms should improve within several weeks to months. if your rheumatoid arthritis symptoms do not improve, or if they worsen, call your doctor. once you and your doctor are sure the drug works for you, do not stop taking hydroxychloroquine without talking to your doctor. symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis will return if you stop taking hydroxychloroquine. other uses for this medicine hydroxychloroquine is also sometimes used to treat porphyria cutanea tarda condition in which certain natural substances build up in the body and may cause painful, blistering skin due to sensitivity to sunlight. talk to your doctor about the possible risks of using this drug for your condition. this medication is sometimes prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking hydroxychloroquine,and pharmacist if you are allergic to hydroxychloroquine, chloroquine, primaquine, quinine, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in hydroxychloroquine tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients.and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. the following nonprescription or herbal product may interact with hydroxychloroquine: cimetidine tagamet hb. be sure to let your doctor and pharmacist know that you are taking this medication before you start taking hydroxychloroquine. do not start this medication while taking hydroxychloroquine without discussing it with your healthcare provider. if you are taking antacids, take them 4 hours before or 4 hours after hydroxychloroquine.if you or anyone in your family has or has ever had a prolonged qt interval a rare heart problem that may cause irregular heartbeat, fainting, or sudden death or if you are of asian descent. also,if you have or have ever had heart failure, a heart attack, an irregular heartbeat, or any other heart problems;a low level of magnesium or potassium in your blood; psoriasis; porphyria an inherited blood disease that may cause skin or nervous system problems, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency g-6-pd; an inherited blood disease, or other blood disorders; dermatitis skin inflammations; seizures; vision problems, including macular degeneration an ongoing disease of the eye that causes loss of the ability to see straight ahead; diabetes; kidney or liver problems; or if you drink large amounts of alcohol.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking hydroxychloroquine, call your doctor. you should know that hydroxychloroquine may cause serious and potentially irreversible eye problems. you will probably need to have regular eye exams during your treatment with hydroxychloroquine.if you have any of the following: blurred vision, floaters in the eye, seeing flashes of light, or other changes in vision. you should know that hydroxychloroquine can cause hypoglycemia low blood sugar. your doctor may tell you to monitor your blood sugar. call your doctor or get emergency medical treatment if you have symptoms of hypoglycemia, including dizziness, weakness, tiredness, sweating, nausea, rapid or irregular heartbeat, confusion, fainting, or loss of consciousness. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? hydroxychloroquine may cause side effects.if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: headache loss of appetite nausea diarrhea stomach pain vomiting difficulty hearing ringing in ears hair loss hair color changes if you experience any of the following symptoms or those mentioned in the special precautions section, call your doctor immediately: hives; rash; swelling of the face, eyes, mouth, throat, tongue, lips, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; or difficulty breathing or swallowing blisters on the skin, eyes, lips or in the mouth; or itching or burning skin muscle weakness burning, numbness, or tingling in the hands or feet excessive tiredness, loss of appetite, nausea, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, pain in the upper right part of the stomach unusual bleeding or bruising cough, fever, sore throat, runny nose, or other signs of infection mood or mental changes fast or irregular heartbeat lightheadedness, dizziness, or fainting unusual tiredness or weakness seizures new or worsening depression mood changes thinking about harming or killing yourself not urinating as much or as frequently, swelling in the legs or feet or ankles, shortness of breath, tiredness, fogginess, confusion, nausea, weakness, pain in the belly, itching, loss of appetite hydroxychloroquine may cause other side effects.

name: hydroxyurea
text: important warning: hydroxyurea can cause a severe decrease in the number of blood cells in your bone marrow.this may increase the risk that you will develop a serious infection or bleeding. if you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately: fever, chills, excessive tiredness or weakness, body aches, sore throat, shortness of breath, ongoing cough and congestion, or other signs of infection; unusual bleeding or bruising; bloody or black, tarry stools; or vomiting blood or brown material that resembles coffee grounds. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory.your doctor will order certain tests on a regular basis to check your body's response to hydroxyurea and to see if your blood count has dropped.your doctor may need to change your dose or tell you to stop taking hydroxyurea for a period of time to allow your blood count to return to normal if it has dropped too low. hydroxyurea may increase the risk that you will develop other cancers, including skin cancer.plan to avoid unnecessary or prolonged exposure to sunlight and to wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen.talk with your doctor about the risks of taking hydroxyurea. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the manufacturer's patient information sheet medication guide when you begin treatment with hydroxyurea and each time you refill your prescription. read the information carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions.why is this medication prescribed? hydroxyurea hydrea is used alone or with other medications or radiation therapy to treat a certain type of chronic myelogenous leukemia cml; a type of cancer of the white blood cells and certain types of head and neck cancer including cancer of the mouth, cheek, tongue, throat, tonsils, and sinuses. hydroxyurea droxia, siklos is used to reduce the frequency of painful crises and reduce the need for blood transfusions in adults and children 2 years of age and older with sickle cell anemia an inherited blood disorder in which the red blood cells are abnormally shaped [shaped like a sickle] and cannot bring enough oxygen to all parts of the body.hydroxyurea is in a class of medications called antimetabolites. hydroxyurea treats cancer by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells in your body. hydroxyurea treats sickle cell anemia by helping to prevent formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells. how should this medicine be used? hydroxyurea comes as a capsule and tablet to take by mouth.it is usually taken once a day with a glass of water. when hydroxyurea is used to treat certain types of cancer, it may be taken once every third day. your doctor will tell you how often you will receive hydroxyurea. the schedule depends on the condition you have and on how your body responds to the medication. take hydroxyurea at around the same time every day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand. take hydroxyurea exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. your doctor may need to delay your treatment or adjust your dose of hydroxyurea depending on your response to treatment and any side effects that you may experience. talk to your doctor about how you are feeling during your treatment. do not stop taking hydroxyurea without talking to your doctor. your doctor will probably tell you to take another medication, folic acid a vitamin, to decrease some of the side effects of this medication.take this medication exactly as directed. swallow the capsules whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. the hydroxyurea 1,000-mg tablets siklos are scored so that they can easily be split into halves or quarters to provide smaller doses. do not break the hydroxyurea 100-mg tablets into smaller parts. your doctor will tell you how to break the tablets and how many tablets or parts of a tablet you should take. if you are unable to swallow hydroxyurea tablets or portions of tablets, you may dissolve your dose in water. place your dose in a teaspoon and add a small amount of water. wait about 1 minute to allow the tablets to dissolve, then swallow the mixture right away. you should wear rubber or latex gloves when you handle the capsules or tablets so that your skin does not come into contact with the medication. wash your hands with soap and water before and after you touch the bottle or medication. if hydroxyurea gets into your eyes, immediately flush your eyes with water for at least 15 minutes. if the powder from a capsule or tablet spills, wipe it up immediately with a damp disposable towel. then place the towel in a closed container, such as a plastic bag, and throw it away in a trash can that is out of the reach of children and pets. clean the spill area using a detergent solution followed by clean water. other uses for this medicine hydroxyurea is also sometimes used to treat polycythemia vera a blood disease in which your body makes too many red blood cells. talk to your doctor about the risks of using this medication for your condition. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking hydroxyurea,and pharmacist if you are allergic to hydroxyurea, any other medications, or any of the inactive ingredients in hydroxyurea capsules or tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients.and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while taking hydroxyurea. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects.if you have human immunodeficiency virus hiv, acquired immunodeficiency syndrome aids, high levels of uric acid in your blood, or leg ulcers; if you are being treated with or have ever been treated with radiation therapy, cancer chemotherapy, or hemodialysis; or if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease. you should know that for some people on continuous glucose monitoring cgm, hydroxyurea may make glucose results seem higher than they actually which may cause higher insulin dosing and put you at risk of hypoglycemia. if you are on cgm, you should talk to your doctor about other ways to monitor glucose during hydroxyurea treatment.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. you should not become pregnant or breastfeed while you are taking hydroxyurea. you will need to have a pregnancy test before you begin treatment with hydroxyurea. if you are a female, you should use effective birth control while taking hydroxyurea and for at least 6 months after stopping your treatment. if you are a male, you and your female partner should use effective birth control while taking hydroxyurea and for at least 6 months siklos or at least 1 year droxia, hydrea after stopping your treatment. talk to your doctor about birth control methods that you can use during and after your treatment and how long you should continue their use. if you become pregnant while taking hydroxyurea, call your doctor immediately. hydroxyurea may harm the fetus. you should know that this medication may decrease fertility in men. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking hydroxyurea. do not have any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? hydroxyurea may cause side effects.if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea vomiting diarrhea loss of appetite weight gain sores in the mouth and throat constipation rash pale skin dizziness headache hair loss changes in skin and nails some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: fast heartbeat ongoing pain that begins in the stomach area but may spread to the back leg wounds or ulcers pain, itching, redness, swelling, or blisters on the skin pain in the upper right part of the stomach blood in the urine yellowing of the skin or eyes numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet fever, cough, shortness of breath, and other breathing problems hydroxyurea may cause other side effects.

name: hyoscyamine
text: why is this medication prescribed? hyoscyamine is used to control symptoms associated with disorders of the gastrointestinal gi tract. it works by decreasing the motion of the stomach and intestines and the secretion of stomach fluids, including acid. hyoscyamine is also used in the treatment of bladder spasms, peptic ulcer disease, diverticulitis, colic, irritable bowel syndrome, cystitis, and pancreatitis. hyoscyamine may also be used to treat certain heart conditions, to control the symptoms of parkinson's disease and rhinitis runny nose, and to reduce excess saliva production. how should this medicine be used? hyoscyamine comes as a tablet, an extended-release long-acting capsule, and a liquid to take by mouth. the tablets and liquid are usually taken three or four times a day. the extended-release capsules are usually taken twice a day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand. take hyoscyamine exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. swallow the extended-release tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. hyoscyamine controls symptoms associated with disorders of the gi tract, but it does not cure the disorders. continue to take hyoscyamine even if you feel well. do not stop taking hyoscyamine without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses. ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking hyoscyamine,and pharmacist if you are allergic to hyoscyamine, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in hyoscyamine tablets, capsules, or liquid. ask your doctor or pharmacist for a list of the ingredients.and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking pr plan to take while taking hyoscyamine. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. be aware that antacids may interfere with hyoscyamine, making it less effective. take hyoscyamine 1 hour before or 2 hours after antacids. the following nonprescription products may interact with hyoscyamine: allergy medications diphenhydramine, loratadine, fexofenadine, chlorpheniramine or cetirizine. be sure to let your doctor and pharmacist know that you are taking these medications before you start taking hyoscyamine. do not start any of these medications while taking hyoscyamine without discussing with your healthcare provider.if you have or have ever had glaucoma; heart, lung, liver, or kidney disease; a urinary tract or intestinal obstruction; an enlarged prostate; ulcerative colitis a condition which causes swelling and sores in the lining of the colon [large intestine] and rectum; or myasthenia gravis.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking hyoscyamine, call your doctor. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of taking hyoscyamine if you are 65 years of age or older. older adults should not usually take hyoscyamine because it is not as safe and may not be as effective as other medications that can be used to treat the same condition. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery,or dentist that you take hyoscyamine. you should know that this medication may make you drowsy. do not drive a car or operate machinery until you know how hyoscyamine affects you. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol during your treatment with hyoscyamine. alcohol can make the side effects of this medication worse. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? hyoscyamine may cause side effects.if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: drowsiness dizziness or lightheadedness headache blurred vision flushing feeling of warmth dry mouth constipation difficulty urinating increased sensitivity to light some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately: diarrhea skin rash eye pain fast or irregular heartbeat hyoscyamine may cause other side effects. .

name: phenylephrine
text: why is this medication prescribed? phenylephrine is used to relieve nasal and sinus congestion caused by colds, allergies, or sinusitis. a prescription injectable form may be used in medical settings to raise low blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? for over the counter oral use, follow the product label or your prescribers directions. typical adult dosing is 10 milligrams by mouth every 4 hours as needed with a maximum of 60 milligrams in 24 hours. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time. do not use for more than 7 days unless directed. for children use only products labeled for their age and follow dosing carefully. how should this medicine be used if it is a nasal spray or drops? use exactly as directed, usually 1 to 2 sprays or drops in each nostril every 4 hours as needed for up to 3 days to avoid rebound congestion. do not share the bottle and avoid contaminating the tip. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are taking or have taken a monoamine oxidase inhibitor within the last 14 days.if you have high blood pressure, heart disease, diabetes, thyroid disease, glaucoma, an enlarged prostate, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. avoid taking other cold or allergy products that also contain decongestants or stimulants. phenylephrine may cause nervousness or trouble sleeping so avoid taking it near bedtime. what special dietary instructions should i follow? limit caffeine and other stimulants which can increase side effects such as jitteriness and rapid heartbeat. drink plenty of fluids if you are congested. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is usually taken as needed. if you are on a schedule, take it when you remember, but skip it if it is almost time for your next dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nervousness, dizziness, headache, increased blood pressure, palpitations, and trouble sleeping. stop use and seek medical help for chest pain, severe or persistent headache, rapid or irregular heartbeat, severe high blood pressure symptoms, or signs of an allergic reaction such as rash, swelling, or trouble breathing.

name: pyrethrin and piperonyl butoxide topical
text: why is this medication prescribed? pyrethrin with piperonyl butoxide is used to treat head lice and their eggs and may also be used for pubic lice when directed. it kills live lice but not all eggs, so retreatment is often needed. how should this medicine be used? for head lice apply to dry hair and scalp enough to thoroughly wet the hair. leave on for 10 minutes, then add a small amount of water, lather, and rinse thoroughly. use a fine tooth nit comb to remove lice and nits while the hair is still damp. repeat in 7 to 10 days to kill newly hatched lice unless your clinician advises otherwise. treat close contacts as recommended and wash or heat dry clothing, hats, bedding, and combs used within the prior 48 hours. avoid contact with eyes, nose, and mouth. do not use on eyelashes or eyebrows. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are allergic to pyrethrins, chrysanthemums, or ragweed. use with caution if you have asthma or very sensitive skin. for external use only. do not use on broken or inflamed skin. keep away from open flame because the product may be flammable. ask a clinician before use in children under 2 years, during pregnancy, or while breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply as soon as you remember if lice are still present, then continue with the planned retreatment schedule. do not apply more often than directed. what side effects can this medication cause? mild itching, redness, tingling, or burning of the scalp are common and usually temporary. stop use and seek medical help if you develop swelling, hives, trouble breathing, or severe irritation.

name: antipyrine-benzocaine otic
text: why is this medication prescribed? antipyrine and benzocaine ear drops are used to relieve ear pain and pressure and to help soften earwax, often alongside other treatments for ear conditions. how should this medicine be used? warm the bottle in your hands. lie with the affected ear upward. instill enough drops to fill the ear canal as directed. insert a clean cotton plug if advised and moisten it with a few drops. for pain you may repeat every 1 to 2 hours as needed or as directed. for earwax softening use drops up to 3 times daily for 2 to 3 days before earwax removal as instructed by your clinician. do not use if you have a perforated eardrum or ear tubes unless directed by a clinician. do not touch the dropper tip to the ear or any surface. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are allergic to benzocaine, other local anesthetics, or antipyrine. seek medical evaluation for severe pain, fever, drainage, trauma, or hearing loss. for ear use only. keep out of reach of children. use with caution in infants and young children because benzocaine can rarely cause methemoglobinemia. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is often used as needed. if on a schedule, use it when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. do not double doses. what side effects can this medication cause? mild local irritation, redness, or itching can occur. stop use and seek immediate medical help if you notice gray or blue colored skin, shortness of breath, extreme fatigue, fast heart rate, or confusion which may indicate methemoglobinemia, or if you have signs of a severe allergic reaction.

name: hydrocortisone injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? hydrocortisone injection is a corticosteroid used to treat adrenal insufficiency, severe allergic reactions, asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbations, certain autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, and some forms of shock. how should this medicine be used? it is usually given by a healthcare professional into a vein or muscle. dose and duration are individualized. if you have adrenal insufficiency, your clinician may provide an emergency injection kit and instructions for use during illness or injury and will advise you to wear medical identification. do not stop long term corticosteroids suddenly without medical guidance because of the risk of adrenal crisis. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about infections, recent exposure to chickenpox or measles, diabetes, high blood pressure, glaucoma or cataracts, osteoporosis, stomach ulcers, mood disorders, seizure disorder, liver disease, or pregnancy or breastfeeding. hydrocortisone can increase infection risk and may mask signs of infection. avoid live vaccines while on significant immunosuppressive doses. many medicines can interact, including certain antifungals, antibiotics, seizure medicines, and hiv medicines. what special dietary instructions should i follow? your clinician may advise limiting sodium, ensuring enough calcium and vitamin d, and managing carbohydrates if you have diabetes or steroid induced hyperglycemia. maintain adequate hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are on a scheduled regimen, take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose, then skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you have adrenal insufficiency and symptoms of adrenal crisis occur, use your emergency injection as instructed and seek emergency care. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fluid retention, swelling, increased appetite, weight gain, mood changes, anxiety or insomnia, elevated blood pressure, elevated blood sugar, stomach upset, acne, and increased sweating. serious effects include signs of infection, vision changes or eye pain, severe mood or behavior changes, stomach bleeding, pancreatitis, severe muscle or bone pain, hip or shoulder pain suggestive of avascular necrosis, and adrenal suppression. injection site pain or infection can occur.

name: methylprednisolone injection
text: important warning: serious neurologic adverse reactions including spinal cord infarction, paraplegia, quadriplegia, cortical blindness, and stroke have occurred with epidural administration of corticosteroids. methylprednisolone injection should not be given by epidural or intrathecal routes. corticosteroids can suppress the immune system, increase the risk of serious infections, and mask signs of infection. do not stop long term therapy suddenly because of the risk of adrenal crisis. why is this medication prescribed? methylprednisolone injection is a corticosteroid used to treat severe allergic reactions, asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbations, autoimmune and inflammatory disorders, multiple sclerosis exacerbations, and other conditions as determined by your clinician. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a healthcare professional into a vein or muscle. dose and duration are individualized based on the condition and response. do not use by epidural or intrathecal routes. if used for more than a few days, your clinician may taper the dose to prevent adrenal suppression. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have current or recent infection, exposure to chickenpox or measles, diabetes, high blood pressure, glaucoma or cataracts, osteoporosis, stomach ulcers, psychiatric history, seizure disorder, liver or kidney disease, myasthenia gravis, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. avoid live vaccines while receiving immunosuppressive doses. some formulations contain benzyl alcohol which should not be used in newborns. many medicines interact including certain antifungals, antibiotics, seizure medicines, blood thinners, and hiv medicines. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may be advised to limit sodium, ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d, and manage carbohydrate intake to control blood sugar. maintain adequate hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are on a scheduled regimen, take the missed dose when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. do not take two doses at once. if you are using a taper, contact your clinician for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fluid retention, swelling, increased appetite, weight gain, mood changes, anxiety or insomnia, elevated blood pressure, elevated blood sugar, stomach upset, acne, and increased sweating. serious effects include severe infection, vision changes or eye pain, stomach bleeding, pancreatitis, severe mood or behavior changes, muscle weakness, bone loss, hip or shoulder pain suggestive of avascular necrosis, and adrenal suppression. injection site reactions can occur.

name: chlordiazepoxide
text: important warning: chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine. taking benzodiazepines with opioids can cause profound sedation, severe respiratory depression, coma, and death. use together only when alternatives are inadequate and with close monitoring. benzodiazepines can cause misuse, abuse, and addiction, and can lead to physical dependence. do not stop suddenly after long term use because withdrawal reactions can be severe or life threatening. why is this medication prescribed? chlordiazepoxide is used to treat anxiety disorders and symptoms of acute alcohol withdrawal. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as prescribed, with or without food. doses for anxiety are usually divided 3 or 4 times daily. doses for alcohol withdrawal may be higher at first and then tapered. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration. do not increase the dose or take more often than prescribed. do not stop suddenly. your clinician will guide a gradual taper to reduce withdrawal risk. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you use opioids, alcohol, or other sedatives. avoid alcohol. tell your clinician if you have liver disease, kidney disease, breathing problems, sleep apnea, depression or other mental health conditions, a history of substance use disorder, glaucoma, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. this medicine may cause drowsiness, dizziness, and impaired coordination; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. many medicines can interact including strong inhibitors or inducers of liver enzymes. older adults are at higher risk of confusion, falls, and fractures. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. if you are sensitive to grapefruit or grapefruit juice, ask your clinician or pharmacist about potential interactions. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, fatigue, confusion, blurred vision, dry mouth, constipation, or coordination problems. serious effects include severe sedation or breathing problems, agitation, worsening depression, suicidal thoughts, yellowing of the skin or eyes, severe rash, or unusual bleeding. seek emergency help for trouble breathing or unresponsiveness, especially if taken with opioids or alcohol.

name: tetrahydrozoline ophthalmic
text: why is this medication prescribed? tetrahydrozoline ophthalmic is used to relieve eye redness due to minor irritation. how should this medicine be used? wash hands before use. remove contact lenses. instill 1 drop in the affected eye every 4 hours as needed. do not use more than 72 hours in a row to avoid rebound redness. do not touch the dropper tip to any surface and recap after use. do not use while wearing contact lenses. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have narrow angle glaucoma unless directed by a clinician. stop use and seek care for eye pain, changes in vision, continued redness, or if redness lasts more than 72 hours. keep out of reach of children because accidental ingestion can cause serious harm such as low heart rate, sleepiness, and low body temperature. ask your clinician before use during pregnancy or breastfeeding or in young children. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? use as needed. if you are on a schedule, use when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. do not use extra drops to make up a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? mild transient stinging or burning, temporary blurred vision, or eye irritation may occur. overuse can cause rebound redness. seek medical help for severe eye pain, persistent vision changes, severe headache with eye pain, or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: abacavir
text: important warning: abacavir can cause a serious and sometimes fatal hypersensitivity reaction that is more likely if you have the hla b*5701 gene variant. you must be tested for hla b*5701 before starting abacavir. stop abacavir and seek emergency care if you develop symptoms of hypersensitivity which may include fever, rash, malaise or fatigue, gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain, or respiratory symptoms such as cough, sore throat, or shortness of breath. never restart abacavir if you have had a suspected hypersensitivity reaction. why is this medication prescribed? abacavir is an antiretroviral medicine used with other medicines to treat human immunodeficiency virus infection. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed, usually 300 milligrams twice daily or 600 milligrams once daily, with or without food. take doses at the same times every day. do not miss doses or stop unless your clinician tells you to. abacavir should always be used in combination with other antiretrovirals. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have liver disease, risk factors for heart disease, or if you drink alcohol. abacavir is not recommended in moderate or severe liver disease. tell your clinician if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. do not breastfeed if you have hiv. many medicines can interact; review all medicines and supplements with your clinician. be aware of possible immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome when starting therapy. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take abacavir with or without food. limit alcohol because it can increase abacavir levels and liver stress. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not take two doses at once. if you have stopped abacavir for any reason and have symptoms suggestive of hypersensitivity or if the cause of prior symptoms is uncertain, do not restart abacavir and contact your clinician immediately. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, headache, fatigue, and rash. serious effects include hypersensitivity reaction, liver problems such as jaundice or dark urine, lactic acidosis with severe weakness or unusual muscle pain, and chest pain or shortness of breath. seek medical help right away for signs of hypersensitivity or severe side effects.

name: abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine
text: important warning: this medicine contains abacavir which can cause a serious and sometimes fatal hypersensitivity reaction that is more likely if you have the hla b*5701 gene variant. you must be tested for hla b*5701 before starting. stop the medicine and seek emergency care if you develop symptoms such as fever, rash, malaise or fatigue, gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain, or respiratory symptoms like cough, sore throat, or shortness of breath. never restart if you had a suspected hypersensitivity reaction. in people with hepatitis b virus infection, stopping lamivudine can cause a serious flare of hepatitis. why is this medication prescribed? the fixed dose combination of abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine treats human immunodeficiency virus infection and is used as a complete regimen in appropriate patients. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet once daily at the same time each day, with or without food. if you take antacids or iron or calcium supplements, take this medicine at least 2 hours before or 6 hours after those products. do not take with dofetilide. do not miss doses or stop unless directed by your clinician. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have liver disease or hepatitis b infection, kidney problems, or if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. your clinician may check hepatitis b status and liver tests and may prescribe additional hepatitis b treatment if needed. dolutegravir can interact with many medicines including metformin, multivitamins or supplements containing polyvalent cations, certain anticonvulsants, rifampin, and st johns wort. this product is not recommended if your creatinine clearance is less than 50 milliliters per minute. watch for depression or insomnia and report new or worsening mood symptoms. do not breastfeed if you have hiv. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take with or without food. separate dosing from antacids or iron or calcium supplements as described. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember if it is within about 12 hours of your usual time. if it is close to the time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. if you vomit within 1 hour after taking a dose, take another dose. do not restart the medicine after a break if you had any signs of abacavir hypersensitivity without first speaking to your clinician. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, nausea, diarrhea, and insomnia. weight gain can occur. serious effects include hypersensitivity reaction, liver problems including hepatitis flares after stopping in people with hepatitis b, lactic acidosis with severe weakness or unusual muscle pain, depression or suicidal thoughts, and severe skin reactions. immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome can occur when starting therapy.

name: abacavir, lamivudine, and zidovudine
text: important warning: this medicine contains abacavir which can cause a serious and sometimes fatal hypersensitivity reaction that is more likely if you have the hla b*5701 gene variant. you must be tested for hla b*5701 before starting. stop the medicine and seek emergency care if you develop symptoms such as fever, rash, malaise or fatigue, gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain, or respiratory symptoms like cough, sore throat, or shortness of breath. never restart if you had a suspected hypersensitivity reaction. this medicine also carries a risk of lactic acidosis and severe liver enlargement with fatty liver. zidovudine can cause bone marrow suppression leading to anemia and neutropenia, and long term use can cause muscle weakness. in people with hepatitis b infection, stopping lamivudine can cause a serious flare of hepatitis. why is this medication prescribed? the fixed dose combination of abacavir, lamivudine, and zidovudine is used with or without other antiretroviral agents to treat human immunodeficiency virus infection. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth twice daily with or without food. take doses at the same times every day. do not miss doses or stop unless directed by your clinician. this product may not be suitable if you have significant kidney impairment because lamivudine requires dose adjustment. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have liver disease, hepatitis b or c infection, kidney disease, low blood counts, anemia, or neutropenia, or if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. your clinician will check blood counts regularly. many medicines can interact including ribavirin, doxorubicin, other medicines that affect bone marrow, and alcohol. do not breastfeed if you have hiv. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take with or without food and should limit alcohol to reduce liver stress. ensure adequate nutrition to support blood counts as advised by your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose, then skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. if you vomit within 1 hour after a dose, take another dose. do not restart the medicine after a break if you had any signs of abacavir hypersensitivity without first speaking to your clinician. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, headache, fatigue, and trouble sleeping. serious effects include hypersensitivity reaction, anemia, neutropenia, lactic acidosis with severe weakness or unusual muscle pain, liver problems with jaundice or dark urine, pancreatitis, and muscle pain or weakness. skin or nail discoloration can occur. seek medical help for shortness of breath, chest pain, severe fatigue, or signs of infection such as fever or persistent sore throat.

name: abaloparatide injection
text: important warning: in animal studies abaloparatide caused an increase in bone cancer called osteosarcoma. because of this potential risk, do not use it if you have conditions that increase your baseline risk for osteosarcoma such as paget disease of bone, unexplained elevations of alkaline phosphatase, bone metastases or a history of skeletal radiation therapy, or in patients with open epiphyses. do not use abaloparatide or other parathyroid hormone analogs for more than a total of 2 years during your lifetime. why is this medication prescribed? abaloparatide is used to treat osteoporosis in postmenopausal women and in men who are at high risk for fracture, to increase bone density and reduce the risk of fractures. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection once daily, usually 80 micrograms, into the abdomen. use at the same time each day, rotate injection sites, and follow pen preparation instructions. your clinician will show you how to inject properly. store and handle the pen exactly as directed on the product label. after completing abaloparatide therapy, your clinician may start an antiresorptive medicine to maintain bone density. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have or had bone cancer, metabolic bone diseases other than osteoporosis, kidney stones, high calcium, severe kidney disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. abaloparatide may cause transient low blood pressure, dizziness, or fast heartbeat after injection, especially at the beginning. sit or lie down after your dose if you feel lightheaded. use caution if you take digoxin because high calcium can increase digoxin toxicity. limit lifetime use of abaloparatide and teriparatide combined to 2 years. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take calcium and vitamin d as directed to ensure adequate intake. avoid excessive calcium supplementation if you have a history of kidney stones and maintain good hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, skip it and take your next dose at the usual time the following day. do not take two doses on the same day. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dizziness, fast heartbeat, nausea, headache, fatigue, upper abdominal pain, and redness or pain at the injection site. it can raise urine calcium and rarely cause kidney stones. serious effects include persistent high calcium symptoms such as confusion or severe constipation, allergic reactions like rash, swelling, or trouble breathing, and very rarely a potential risk of osteosarcoma.

name: abatacept injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? abatacept is used to treat moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis by modulating the immune response to reduce joint inflammation and damage. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion at weeks 0, 2, and 4, then every 4 weeks, or as a subcutaneous injection once weekly after possible intravenous loading. a healthcare professional will administer infusions. if you self inject, your clinician will teach you proper technique, site rotation, and storage. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have current or recurrent infections, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, tuberculosis exposure, or hepatitis b. you will be screened for latent tuberculosis and hepatitis b before treatment. do not receive live vaccines during therapy and for a period after stopping. use caution with other immunosuppressants. inform your clinician about pregnancy or breastfeeding plans. seek medical care promptly for fever, cough, shortness of breath, painful urination, or other infection signs. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. if you also take methotrexate or other hepatotoxic drugs, limit alcohol as advised. what should i do if i forget a dose? for subcutaneous dosing, inject as soon as you remember if it is within a few days, then resume your regular schedule. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue as scheduled. do not double doses. for infusions, contact your clinic to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, nausea, runny or stuffy nose, sore throat, and injection site reactions. serious effects include serious infections such as pneumonia or sepsis, hypersensitivity or infusion reactions, and possible increased risk of certain cancers. call your clinician for signs of infection or allergic reaction.

name: idecabtagene vicleucel injection
text: important warning: this chimeric antigen receptor t cell therapy can cause life threatening cytokine release syndrome and neurologic toxicities. it can also cause hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis or macrophage activation syndrome and prolonged or recurrent low blood counts. it must be given at a certified center with tocilizumab and intensive care support immediately available. seek emergency care for fever, chills, confusion, severe headache, seizure, difficulty speaking, severe weakness, shortness of breath, chest pain, or low blood pressure. why is this medication prescribed? idecabtagene vicleucel is used to treat adults with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who have received prior therapies and meet specific criteria. how should this medicine be used? it is given once as an intravenous infusion after a short course of lymphodepleting chemotherapy. you will be monitored closely in the hospital or clinic and must remain near the treating center for at least 4 weeks. do not drive or operate heavy machinery for at least 8 weeks after infusion due to the risk of neurologic events. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all infections, vaccination history, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. you will be screened for hepatitis and other infections. avoid live vaccines for at least 6 weeks before lymphodepletion and until your clinician says it is safe afterward. idecabtagene vicleucel can cause prolonged low blood counts, serious infections, low immunoglobulins, and secondary cancers, so you will need frequent blood tests and may receive antimicrobials or immunoglobulin replacement. some patients may have a false positive test for hiv due to the lentiviral vector. do not donate blood, organs, tissues, or cells. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions. if your white blood cells are low, follow food safety guidance to reduce infection risk and stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is administered by professionals. if you miss a scheduled visit or premedication, contact your treatment center immediately for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? very common effects include fever, chills, low blood pressure, rapid heart rate, low oxygen levels, fatigue, headache, confusion, tremor, speech difficulty, or sleepiness. laboratory abnormalities include low white cells, red cells, and platelets, elevated liver enzymes, and electrolyte changes. serious risks include cytokine release syndrome, severe neurologic events including seizures and encephalopathy, hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, severe infections, tumor lysis syndrome, and prolonged cytopenias.

name: amphotericin b lipid complex injection
text: important warning: different formulations of amphotericin b are not interchangeable and the dosing is not the same. verify the product name and dose carefully to avoid fatal overdoses. use only for treatment of invasive or potentially life threatening fungal infections. why is this medication prescribed? amphotericin b lipid complex treats severe invasive fungal infections such as aspergillosis, candidiasis, and other susceptible mycoses, especially in patients who cannot tolerate or did not respond to conventional amphotericin b. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion, usually once daily, prepared and diluted exactly as directed, typically in dextrose 5 percent solution, and infused over about 2 hours. it must not be interchanged dose for dose with other amphotericin products. premedication may reduce infusion reactions. kidney function, electrolytes, liver tests, and blood counts will be monitored regularly. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about kidney disease, electrolyte problems, liver disease, anemia, pregnancy, or prior reactions to amphotericin. avoid or minimize other nephrotoxic drugs such as certain nsaids, aminoglycosides, and contrast dye. infusion reactions such as fever, chills, chest or back pain, shortness of breath, and low blood pressure can occur and require monitoring. severe allergic reactions can occur. what special dietary instructions should i follow? maintain good hydration as advised. you may need potassium and magnesium supplementation if your levels fall. limit alcohol and avoid over the counter nephrotoxic medicines unless approved. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by healthcare professionals. if a dose or appointment is missed, contact your clinician to reschedule as soon as possible. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, headache, infusion site reactions, and low potassium or magnesium. kidney function may worsen. anemia and abnormal liver tests can occur. serious reactions include severe infusion reactions, anaphylaxis, severe kidney injury, breathing problems, and low blood pressure.

name: abemaciclib
text: why is this medication prescribed? abemaciclib is a cyclin dependent kinase 4 and 6 inhibitor used for hormone receptor positive, human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 negative breast cancer in metastatic or advanced disease and in some high risk early breast cancer settings, alone or with endocrine therapy. how should this medicine be used? take the tablets by mouth twice daily at about the same times each day with or without food. swallow tablets whole. if you vomit after a dose, do not retake the dose and take the next dose at the scheduled time. your dose may be adjusted based on side effects. start antidiarrheal medicine at the first sign of loose stools and increase fluids. your clinician will monitor blood counts and liver tests regularly. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about liver disease, clotting history, lung disease, infections, and all medicines and supplements. abemaciclib can cause diarrhea, neutropenia, liver injury, blood clots, and interstitial lung disease or pneumonitis. seek care for shortness of breath, chest pain, or severe diarrhea. avoid strong cyp3a inhibitors or inducers including certain antifungals, anticonvulsants, and st johns wort, or follow dose adjustments. use effective contraception during treatment and for a period after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for a period after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and seville oranges as they can increase drug levels. maintain good hydration, especially if you have diarrhea. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, skip it and take your next dose at the usual time. do not take extra tablets to make up a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, abdominal pain, infections, low white blood cells, anemia, low platelets, and elevated liver enzymes. serious effects include dehydration, blood clots, liver injury, and interstitial lung disease or pneumonitis.

name: aripiprazole
text: important warning: elderly patients with dementia related psychosis treated with antipsychotic drugs are at increased risk of death. aripiprazole is not approved for dementia related psychosis. antidepressants, including aripiprazole when used as an adjunct for depression, increase the risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviors in children, adolescents, and young adults. monitor closely for worsening depression or suicidality. why is this medication prescribed? aripiprazole is used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar i disorder, irritability associated with autistic disorder, tourette disorder, and as an adjunctive treatment for major depressive disorder. how should this medicine be used? take aripiprazole by mouth once daily with or without food, at the same time each day. follow your clinicians dosing instructions. do not stop suddenly without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about heart disease, stroke risk, diabetes or risk factors, seizures, low white blood cell counts, liver problems, pregnancy, and breastfeeding. aripiprazole can cause neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, high blood sugar and diabetes, weight gain and lipid changes, orthostatic hypotension, low white cells, seizures, impulse control problems such as compulsive gambling, temperature regulation problems, and difficulty swallowing. avoid alcohol and use caution driving until you know how it affects you. interactions with cyp2d6 and cyp3a4 inhibitors or inducers may require dose changes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions, but limit alcohol. maintain healthy nutrition and exercise to reduce metabolic side effects. discuss grapefruit products with your clinician if you consume them regularly. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include akathisia or restlessness, anxiety, insomnia or sleepiness, headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, constipation, and blurred vision. serious effects include neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, high blood sugar or ketoacidosis, stroke in elderly patients with dementia, seizures, low blood pressure or fainting, and allergic reactions.

name: aripiprazole injection
text: important warning: elderly patients with dementia related psychosis treated with antipsychotic drugs are at increased risk of death. aripiprazole is not approved for dementia related psychosis. antidepressants, including aripiprazole when used as an adjunct for depression, increase the risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviors in children, adolescents, and young adults. monitor closely for worsening mood or suicidality. why is this medication prescribed? intramuscular aripiprazole is used for acute agitation associated with schizophrenia or bipolar i disorder, and long acting formulations are used for maintenance treatment of schizophrenia and for maintenance monotherapy or adjunct in bipolar i disorder. how should this medicine be used? short acting aripiprazole is given as intramuscular injections by a healthcare professional. long acting injections are given into the gluteal or deltoid muscle at intervals such as monthly or every 6 to 8 weeks depending on the product, with a specific initiation plan and in some cases oral overlap. do not inject intravenously and do not self inject unless specifically trained for a particular product. attend all scheduled injection appointments. what special precautions should i follow? the same precautions as oral aripiprazole apply including risk of neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, metabolic changes, orthostatic hypotension, leukopenia, seizures, and impulse control disorders. tell your clinician about all medicines including cyp2d6 and cyp3a4 inhibitors or inducers which may require dose adjustments. use caution with other central nervous system depressants. avoid alcohol. pregnancy in the third trimester can cause symptoms in the newborn. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions. maintain healthy diet and limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your clinician as soon as possible to arrange a catch up injection. the timing of the next dose depends on how long it has been since your last injection and the product used. do not try to self inject to make up a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include injection site pain, akathisia, restlessness, sleepiness, dizziness, headache, nausea, constipation, and anxiety. serious effects include neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, high blood sugar, stroke in elderly patients with dementia, orthostatic hypotension or fainting, seizures, and allergic reactions.

name: abiraterone
text: why is this medication prescribed? abiraterone is used with prednisone and androgen deprivation therapy to treat metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer and metastatic high risk castration sensitive prostate cancer. it lowers androgen production that fuels prostate cancer. how should this medicine be used? take abiraterone tablets by mouth once daily on an empty stomach, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after food, and swallow whole. take prednisone exactly as prescribed to reduce side effects and continue androgen deprivation therapy unless you have had surgical castration. your clinician will monitor liver tests, potassium, blood pressure, and fluid status regularly. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about liver disease, heart disease, hypertension, low potassium, adrenal problems, and all medicines and supplements. abiraterone can cause mineralocorticoid excess leading to high blood pressure, low potassium, and fluid retention, adrenal insufficiency especially if prednisone is interrupted or during stress or infection, and liver injury. seek care for dark urine, yellow skin or eyes, severe fatigue, shortness of breath, or severe swelling. avoid strong cyp3a4 inducers or inhibitors if possible. women who are pregnant or may become pregnant should not handle crushed or broken tablets. do not use during pregnancy and do not breastfeed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? always take abiraterone on an empty stomach. taking it with food can greatly increase drug levels and toxicity. limit alcohol to protect the liver and avoid grapefruit products and st johns wort. ensure adequate potassium intake as advised. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take your next dose at the regular time the following day. do not take extra tablets to make up the missed dose. if you miss prednisone doses, contact your clinician for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fatigue, joint swelling or pain, hot flushes, diarrhea, cough, shortness of breath, edema, high blood pressure, low potassium, and abnormal liver tests. serious effects include liver injury, adrenal insufficiency, heart rhythm problems, and severe fluid retention.

name: methotrexate injection
text: important warning: methotrexate can cause severe and sometimes fatal toxicities including bone marrow suppression leading to serious infections and bleeding, liver damage including fibrosis and cirrhosis, kidney damage especially with high doses, lung injury including pneumonitis, severe skin reactions, gastrointestinal ulceration and bleeding, and embryo fetal toxicity. for noncancer indications such as rheumatoid arthritis or psoriasis it must be taken once weekly, not daily. fatal accidents have occurred when daily dosing was used by mistake. use only under close medical supervision with regular blood tests. avoid use during pregnancy and breastfeeding. why is this medication prescribed? methotrexate is used to treat certain cancers such as leukemia, lymphomas, and osteosarcoma, and severe psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis that have not responded to other treatments. how should this medicine be used? it may be given by subcutaneous, intramuscular, intravenous, intraarterial, or intrathecal routes depending on the regimen. for arthritis and psoriasis it is usually given once weekly. your clinician will determine the route, dose, and schedule. if you self inject subcutaneously, you will be trained on injection technique and site rotation. high dose regimens require leucovorin rescue, aggressive hydration, and urinary alkalinization with close monitoring of drug levels and kidney function. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about liver or kidney disease, lung disease, peptic ulcer disease, fluid collections such as pleural effusions or ascites, low blood counts, infections, and all medicines and supplements. many drugs increase methotrexate toxicity including trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole, penicillins, proton pump inhibitors, and certain nsaids especially with high doses. avoid live vaccines. use effective contraception during treatment and for a period after the last dose. seek urgent care for cough or shortness of breath, mouth ulcers, severe rash, fever, bruising or bleeding, dark urine or yellowing of the skin or eyes, or severe abdominal pain. folic acid supplementation is commonly prescribed to reduce some side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol to reduce the risk of liver toxicity. stay well hydrated. take folic acid as directed. limit excessive caffeine if advised by your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? for weekly regimens, if you remember within 2 days of the scheduled dose, take it as soon as possible and then resume your normal weekly schedule. if more than 2 days have passed, call your clinician for instructions. for cancer regimens or intrathecal dosing, contact your treatment team immediately for guidance. do not double doses. what side effects can this medication cause?
