common effects include nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, stomach pain, mouth sores, diarrhea, headache, dizziness, and fatigue. laboratory changes include elevated liver enzymes and low blood counts. serious effects include severe bone marrow suppression with infections and bleeding, liver fibrosis or cirrhosis with long term use, kidney failure especially with high doses, lung inflammation or scarring, severe skin reactions such as stevens johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis, gastrointestinal perforation or bleeding, and neurologic toxicity with intrathecal use.

name: abobotulinumtoxina injection
text: important warning: the effects of botulinum toxin may spread from the area of injection to produce symptoms consistent with botulism. these may include asthenia, generalized muscle weakness, double or blurred vision, drooping eyelids, trouble speaking or swallowing, and trouble breathing. these symptoms can occur hours to weeks after injection and can be life threatening. children treated for spasticity are at greatest risk. seek emergency care for swallowing or breathing difficulties. why is this medication prescribed? abobotulinumtoxina is used to treat cervical dystonia, upper limb spasticity in adults, lower limb spasticity in pediatric patients 2 years and older, and to temporarily improve the appearance of moderate to severe glabellar lines. how should this medicine be used? it is injected into muscles by a trained clinician. units are specific to this product and are not interchangeable with other botulinum toxin products. dosing and injection sites are individualized. effects usually begin within a few days and peak around 2 weeks, and repeat treatments are typically given every 12 to 16 weeks as needed. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about neuromuscular disorders, breathing or swallowing problems, bleeding disorders, planned surgery, and all medicines including aminoglycoside antibiotics and muscle relaxants that can increase weakness. hypersensitivity reactions can occur. use caution if you have a history of dysphagia or respiratory compromise. do not receive another botulinum toxin within the recommended interval unless directed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. if you develop difficulty swallowing, follow your clinicians guidance, which may include soft foods or thickened liquids to reduce aspiration risk. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by a healthcare professional. if you miss an appointment, contact your clinician to reschedule. do not attempt self injection. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include injection site pain, localized muscle weakness, dry mouth, fatigue, headache, and upper respiratory symptoms. in cervical dystonia, difficulty swallowing is common. serious effects include breathing difficulties, aspiration pneumonia, severe allergic reactions, and generalized muscle weakness from toxin spread.

name: paclitaxel with albumin injection
text: important warning: this medicine can cause severe decreases in blood cell counts that raise the risk of serious or fatal infection and bleeding. it can harm an unborn baby. it must be given only under the supervision of clinicians experienced with cancer chemotherapy, with frequent blood count checks and dose changes as needed. why is this medication prescribed? paclitaxel with albumin is used to treat certain cancers including breast cancer, non small cell lung cancer, and pancreatic cancer. how should this medicine be used? it is given as an intravenous infusion by a trained professional on a repeating cycle schedule. premedication for allergic reactions is usually not required with the albumin bound form, but you will be monitored closely during and after infusions. your care team will adjust dose timing based on your blood counts, side effects, liver tests, and treatment response. what special precautions should i follow?about all health conditions including infections, liver problems, heart problems, numbness or tingling, and pregnancy or plans to become pregnant. use effective birth control during treatment and for at least several months after the last dose as directed by your oncologist. do not breastfeed during treatment.about all medicines and supplements. some drugs that affect liver enzymes such as cyp3a4 or cyp2c8 and herbal products like st johns wort can change paclitaxel levels. report fever, chills, sore throat, unusual bruising or bleeding, shortness of breath, severe diarrhea, or signs of allergic reaction right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice unless your oncology team says otherwise. stay well hydrated unless you have been told to restrict fluids. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to self administer this medicine. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include low white blood cells, anemia, low platelets, hair loss, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, mouth sores, muscle or joint aches, and numbness or tingling in the hands or feet. serious effects can include severe infection, sepsis, severe allergic reactions, liver test changes, severe neuropathy, and rare heart or lung problems. seek urgent care for fever, breathing trouble, chest pain, severe weakness, or severe rash.

name: adalimumab injection
text: important warning: medicines that block tumor necrosis factor including adalimumab increase the risk of serious and sometimes fatal infections such as tuberculosis and invasive fungal infections and may raise the risk of certain cancers including lymphoma. you must be screened for tuberculosis and monitored for infection during and after treatment. why is this medication prescribed? adalimumab is used to reduce inflammation in conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, plaque psoriasis, crohns disease, ulcerative colitis, hidradenitis suppurativa, uveitis, and some forms of juvenile arthritis. how should this medicine be used? it is injected under the skin using a prefilled pen or syringe on a regular schedule, usually every one to two weeks depending on the condition. store in the refrigerator and allow it to reach room temperature before use. do not shake. inject into the thigh or abdomen and rotate sites. your clinician will show you how to prepare, inject, and dispose of supplies safely. what special precautions should i follow?about all infections or symptoms such as fever, cough, weight loss, night sweats, or sores.if you have or had hepatitis b, tuberculosis, cancer, demyelinating disease such as multiple sclerosis, heart failure, or immune system problems. complete recommended vaccines before starting and avoid live vaccines during treatment. some needle covers contain latex, so mention any latex allergy. tell your clinician about all medicines, especially other biologic drugs, immunosuppressants, and blood thinners. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and timing of doses. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. maintain good hydration and nutrition. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember, then return to your regular schedule. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not inject two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include injection site pain or redness, upper respiratory symptoms, headache, rash, and nausea. serious effects include severe infections, tuberculosis reactivation, hepatitis b reactivation, certain cancers, low blood counts, new or worsening heart failure, nerve problems, lupus like symptoms, and severe allergic reactions. seek urgent care for signs of infection, trouble breathing, severe weakness, chest pain, or severe rash.

name: abrocitinib
text: important warning: abrocitinib increases the risk of serious infections, death, cancer, major adverse cardiovascular events such as heart attack and stroke, and blood clots. use only in patients who have not responded to or cannot tolerate other therapies and after discussing risks and benefits. why is this medication prescribed? abrocitinib is an oral janus kinase inhibitor used to treat moderate to severe atopic dermatitis in adults and certain adolescents when topical therapies are not adequate. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily as directed, with or without food, swallowing tablets whole with water. your doctor may adjust the dose based on age, kidney or liver function, platelet counts, and side effects. do not crush or split the tablets. what special precautions should i follow? before starting, your doctor will check for tuberculosis, hepatitis b, and current infections, and will order blood tests including a complete blood count, liver tests, and cholesterol. avoid live vaccines during treatment.about any history of heart disease, stroke, blood clots, cancer, smoking, diabetes, stomach or bowel problems, or kidney or liver disease. use effective birth control while taking abrocitinib and for a time after the last dose as directed by your prescriber. do not breastfeed during treatment and for some time after the last dose.about all medicines and supplements. strong inhibitors or inducers of certain liver enzymes especially those that affect cyp2c19 or cyp2c9 can change abrocitinib levels. report signs of infection, chest pain, trouble breathing, severe stomach pain, leg swelling, severe headache, vision changes, shingles, or unusual bruising or bleeding right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific foods are required. take with food if nausea occurs. avoid herbal products with strong enzyme effects such as st johns wort unless your clinician approves. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose and remember on the same day, take it as soon as you remember. if you do not remember until the next day, skip the missed dose and resume your usual schedule. do not take two doses in one day. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, headache, dizziness, acne, stomach pain, and upper respiratory symptoms. lab changes can include increases in cholesterol and decreases in platelets. serious effects include serious infections such as shingles, blood clots, heart attack, stroke, cancer, gastrointestinal perforation, liver test elevations, and severe allergic reactions.

name: rsv respiratory syncytial virus vaccine
text: why is this medication prescribed? rsv vaccines help prevent lower respiratory tract disease caused by respiratory syncytial virus in adults 60 years and older based on shared clinical decision making, and one vaccine is approved for use during pregnancy to protect infants. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a single intramuscular injection by a healthcare professional. for pregnant people, the vaccine is given during weeks 32 to 36 of pregnancy, typically during rsv season, as advised by the obstetric provider. for older adults, timing is usually before or during rsv season based on risk factors and local guidance. what special precautions should i follow? do not receive the vaccine if you had a severe allergic reaction to a previous dose or any component of the vaccine. tell your provider if you have a history of guillain barre syndrome, are ill with fever, are pregnant or breastfeeding, or have immune system conditions. discuss the timing of this vaccine with other vaccines. remain at the clinic for observation after vaccination. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no dietary changes are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a planned appointment, reschedule with your clinic. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site, tiredness, headache, muscle or joint aches, and fever or chills. serious reactions such as severe allergic reaction are rare and require immediate medical attention. rare cases of guillain barre syndrome have been reported in some older adults.

name: lidocaine transdermal patch
text: why is this medication prescribed? the lidocaine skin patch is used to relieve nerve related pain in the area of a shingles rash after it has healed and may be used for certain localized pain conditions as directed by a clinician. how should this medicine be used? apply the patch to intact, dry skin over the painful area, usually once daily for up to 12 hours in a 24 hour period. do not use more than three patches at one time unless your clinician instructs you to do so. you may cut patches to fit. wash hands after handling and avoid touching eyes or mouth. do not apply external heat such as heating pads over the patch. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have had an allergic reaction to lidocaine or other amide local anesthetics. use caution if you have severe liver disease, heart rhythm problems, or a history of methemoglobinemia. do not apply to broken or inflamed skin. keep out of reach of children and pets and fold and dispose of used patches safely.about all medicines, especially other local anesthetics, heart rhythm medicines, beta blockers, and medicines that can cause methemoglobinemia. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no dietary changes are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply a patch when you remember and remove it at your usual time so that total wear time does not exceed 12 hours in any 24 hour period. do not apply extra patches to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include skin redness, irritation, or a mild burning sensation where applied. rare but serious effects from too much lidocaine in the body include dizziness, drowsiness, confusion, blurred vision, ringing in the ears, seizures, slow or irregular heartbeat, or breathing problems. remove the patch and seek urgent care if serious symptoms occur.

name: isotretinoin
text: important warning: isotretinoin causes severe birth defects. do not use if you are pregnant or may become pregnant. enrollment in the ipledge program is required in the united states with strict pregnancy testing and contraception requirements. do not donate blood during treatment or for a period after the last dose. why is this medication prescribed? isotretinoin is used to treat severe nodular acne that has not responded to other treatments. how should this medicine be used? take capsules by mouth as directed, usually twice daily. take with food to improve absorption unless you are prescribed a formulation that can be taken without regard to meals. swallow capsules whole. your doctor will monitor blood tests including lipids and liver tests and adjust the dose based on response and side effects. what special precautions should i follow? do not become pregnant during treatment or for at least one month after the last dose. use two effective methods of birth control as directed by your prescriber. do not breastfeed during treatment.about any history of depression, mood disorders, high triglycerides, liver disease, diabetes, bone disorders, or bowel disease.about all medicines and supplements. avoid vitamin a supplements, tetracycline antibiotics, and st johns wort, and discuss use of progestin only contraceptives. report mood changes, severe headache, vision changes, chest pain, severe stomach pain, blood in stool, severe muscle or joint pain, or signs of pancreatitis or liver problems right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with meals and avoid alcohol or limit it as advised to reduce liver and triglyceride risks. avoid vitamin a rich supplements. stay well hydrated and use lip and skin moisturizers. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose when you remember unless it is close to the time for the next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? very common effects include dry or chapped lips, dry skin and eyes, nosebleeds, and increased sun sensitivity. other effects may include headache, back or joint pain, changes in vision or hearing, elevated triglycerides and liver enzymes, rash, and fatigue. serious effects include birth defects if used during pregnancy, mood or behavior changes, pancreatitis, severe liver problems, inflammatory bowel symptoms, pseudotumor cerebri, and severe skin reactions. seek urgent care for severe headache with vision changes, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, or signs of allergic reaction.

name: fentanyl
text: important warning: fentanyl is a potent opioid that can cause life threatening addiction, abuse, and misuse, and can cause fatal breathing problems especially when starting or increasing the dose. accidental exposure, especially in children, can be deadly. combining fentanyl with benzodiazepines, alcohol, or other sedatives can cause profound sedation, breathing problems, coma, and death. use exactly as prescribed and store securely. why is this medication prescribed? fentanyl is used to treat severe pain that requires continuous opioid therapy or breakthrough cancer pain in patients who are already taking and tolerant to opioid medicines. how should this medicine be used? the form and directions depend on the product. skin patches deliver medicine over 72 hours and are for patients already taking opioids. apply to clean intact skin, press firmly, and replace every 72 hours rotating sites. do not use heat sources on or near the patch. buccal, sublingual, or nasal products are used for breakthrough cancer pain and are taken as single doses with careful titration. injectable forms are given by trained professionals. do not cut or alter patches or take more than prescribed. your clinician will provide a plan for starting dose, titration, and safe disposal. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about lung disease, sleep apnea, head injury, seizures, liver or kidney disease, low blood pressure, mental health conditions, constipation, or past substance use disorder. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. avoid combining with other sedatives unless directed. strong cyp3a4 inhibitors or inducers and many other drugs can dangerously change fentanyl levels. risk of serotonin syndrome increases with serotonergic drugs. do not use patches if you are not already taking opioid medicines on a regular schedule. keep naloxone available and ensure household members know how to use it. avoid driving or operating machinery until you know how fentanyl affects you. if pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks which include neonatal withdrawal. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not drink alcohol. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice which can raise fentanyl levels. stay hydrated and increase fiber in your diet to help prevent constipation. what should i do if i forget a dose? for a skin patch, apply a new patch as soon as you remember and remove the old one, then continue on the new 72 hour schedule. if a patch falls off, dispose of it safely and apply a new patch to a different site. for buccal, sublingual, or nasal products, if a dose is missed, use it when pain recurs unless it is close to the time you would normally use the next dose. never use extra doses to make up for a missed dose. when unsure, contact your prescriber. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include constipation, nausea, vomiting, sleepiness, dizziness, confusion, sweating, and itching. serious effects include slow or shallow breathing, severe sleepiness, fainting, severe low blood pressure, serotonin syndrome, adrenal insufficiency, allergic reactions, and in long term use low sex hormones. seek emergency help for breathing problems, severe drowsiness, inability to wake, or signs of overdose.

name: acalabrutinib
text: why is this medication prescribed? acalabrutinib is used to treat certain blood cancers including chronic lymphocytic leukemia, small lymphocytic lymphoma, and mantle cell lymphoma in some situations. how should this medicine be used? take acalabrutinib by mouth as directed, typically twice daily. swallow capsules or tablets whole with water. if you take acid reducing medicines, avoid proton pump inhibitors. if you use h2 blockers, take acalabrutinib at least two hours after the h2 blocker. if you use antacids, separate doses by at least two hours. your doctor may adjust dosing with certain interacting medicines. what special precautions should i follow?about any history of bleeding, heart rhythm problems including atrial fibrillation, high blood pressure, infections, liver disease, or kidney disease. this medicine can increase bleeding and infection risk and can cause low blood counts and heart rhythm problems.about all medicines and supplements. strong cyp3a inhibitors or inducers and grapefruit or seville oranges can change acalabrutinib levels. your doctor may recommend infection prevention steps. use sun protection because of a risk of second primary skin cancers. tell your dentist or surgeon that you take acalabrutinib before procedures. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and effective contraception during and after treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit, grapefruit juice, and seville oranges. otherwise, no specific diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose by less than three hours, take it as soon as you remember. if more than three hours have passed, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, diarrhea, muscle or joint pain, fatigue, bruising, and rash. laboratory changes may include low white blood cells, low platelets, and anemia. serious effects include severe infections, significant bleeding, atrial fibrillation, high blood pressure, and second primary cancers. seek prompt care for chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, black stools, severe bleeding, or signs of infection such as fever or chills.

name: acamprosate
text: why is this medication prescribed? acamprosate helps people with alcohol use disorder maintain abstinence as part of a comprehensive treatment program that includes counseling and support. how should this medicine be used? take acamprosate by mouth exactly as prescribed, usually three times daily. swallow delayed release tablets whole with water. it is typically started after you have stopped drinking. dose adjustments are needed in reduced kidney function and it is not recommended in severe kidney disease. what special precautions should i follow?about kidney problems, depression, suicidal thoughts, or other mental health conditions. report any mood or behavior changes or suicidal thoughts right away.about all medicines and supplements. continue counseling and support programs. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take it with or without food. if stomach upset occurs, taking it with meals may help. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, gas, itching, dizziness, insomnia, anxiety, and weakness. serious effects are rare but can include depression, suicidal thoughts, allergic reactions, and severe diarrhea. seek help if you develop severe mood changes or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: benzoyl peroxide topical
text: why is this medication prescribed? benzoyl peroxide is used on the skin to treat acne by reducing acne causing bacteria and helping keep pores clear. how should this medicine be used? use as directed on the label or by your clinician. clean and dry the affected skin, then apply a thin layer once daily and increase to twice daily as tolerated. avoid eyes, lips, inside the nose, and broken skin. wash hands after application. it can bleach hair and fabrics. if you use other acne medicines, apply at different times of day to reduce irritation. what special precautions should i follow? do a small test area at first to check for irritation. stop and seek care if you develop severe redness, swelling, blistering, or difficulty breathing. tell your clinician if you have very sensitive skin or eczema. avoid excessive sun and use sunscreen since irritation can increase sun sensitivity. do not use at the same time as dapsone on the same area because temporary skin discoloration can occur. if pregnant or breastfeeding, it is generally considered acceptable, but discuss with your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no dietary changes are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply when you remember, but if it is close to the next application, skip the missed dose and resume your normal schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dryness, peeling, mild burning or stinging, and redness. less common but serious reactions include severe swelling, blistering, hives, or allergic reactions. if severe irritation occurs, stop use and contact your clinician.

name: clindamycin and benzoyl peroxide topical
text: why is this medication prescribed? this combination is used on the skin to treat acne. clindamycin reduces acne causing bacteria and inflammation, and benzoyl peroxide helps reduce bacteria and unclog pores. how should this medicine be used? use on the skin only. clean and dry the affected area, then apply a thin layer as directed, usually once or twice daily. avoid contact with eyes, inside the nose or mouth, and broken or irritated skin. wash hands after applying. use a gentle cleanser and a noncomedogenic moisturizer. this medicine can bleach hair and fabrics and can increase sun sensitivity, so use sunscreen and protective clothing. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about any history of colitis, inflammatory bowel disease, or antibiotic associated diarrhea. do not use if you are allergic to clindamycin, lincomycin, or benzoyl peroxide. avoid using other topical acne products that can irritate the skin unless your clinician advises it. stop and contact your clinician if you develop severe diarrhea, abdominal cramps, severe skin irritation, or signs of allergy such as hives or swelling. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss the risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is needed. use adequate sun protection. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember, but if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dryness, peeling, redness, burning, stinging, and itching. it may increase sun sensitivity. less common but serious effects include severe skin irritation or allergic reaction and rarely severe or persistent diarrhea due to colitis. seek medical help for severe worsening or signs of allergy.

name: acarbose
text: why is this medication prescribed? acarbose is used with diet and exercise to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes. it slows the digestion of carbohydrates to reduce post meal blood sugar spikes. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth at the first bite of each main meal, usually three times daily. your clinician may start with a low dose and increase gradually to improve tolerance. monitor blood sugar as directed and have periodic blood tests including liver enzymes. do not use it to treat low blood sugar. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have inflammatory bowel disease, colonic ulceration, partial intestinal obstruction, chronic intestinal disorders with marked digestion or absorption issues, or cirrhosis. tell your clinician if you have kidney or liver disease, are pregnant or breastfeeding, or use other diabetes medicines. treat low blood sugar with pure glucose such as dextrose tablets or gel, not table sugar or sucrose containing foods, because acarbose delays the breakdown of sucrose. activated charcoal and digestive enzyme products can reduce the effect of acarbose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your diabetes meal plan and distribute carbohydrate intake evenly. limit alcohol and avoid using table sugar to treat low blood sugar. high fiber foods may increase gas at the start of therapy. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you skip a meal, skip the acarbose dose. if you forget to take it with a meal, do not take it later between meals. take the next dose at the first bite of your next main meal. do not double doses. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects are gas, abdominal discomfort, bloating, and diarrhea, which often lessen over time. it can cause low blood sugar when used with insulin or other diabetes drugs. less common effects include elevated liver enzymes or liver inflammation, rash, or swelling. seek care for yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe abdominal pain, or persistent vomiting.

name: zafirlukast
text: important warning: zafirlukast can cause serious liver injury. stop the medicine and contact your clinician right away if you develop fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea, abdominal pain, itching, dark urine, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. this medicine does not treat sudden asthma attacks. always keep a rescue inhaler available. why is this medication prescribed? zafirlukast is used to prevent and control asthma symptoms by blocking leukotrienes, substances that cause airway inflammation. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth on an empty stomach, either one hour before or two hours after meals, usually twice daily. take it regularly even if you feel well. do not use it to relieve acute wheezing. if you are tapering oral steroids, this must be done under medical supervision. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have liver disease or cirrhosis. tell your clinician about all medicines, especially warfarin, theophylline, and erythromycin, because interactions may occur. report any signs of liver problems. rarely, worsening asthma with eosinophilia and vasculitis can occur, especially when oral steroids are reduced. if pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take on an empty stomach for best absorption. avoid excessive alcohol due to liver risk. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next dose. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and infections. serious effects include liver enzyme elevations, hepatitis, jaundice, allergic reactions, and rare vasculitis with rash, tingling or numbness, and worsening lung symptoms.

name: somatropin injection
text: important warning: do not use somatropin in patients with severe obesity or severe breathing problems who have prader willi syndrome due to risk of sudden death. do not use somatropin in patients with acute critical illness after major surgery, trauma, or with acute respiratory failure. why is this medication prescribed? somatropin is a form of human growth hormone used to treat growth failure in children and growth hormone deficiency in adults, and certain conditions such as turner syndrome, chronic kidney disease before transplant, small for gestational age with failure to catch up growth, and other approved indications. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection once daily or as directed. your dose is individualized and may be adjusted based on weight and insulin like growth factor one levels. you will be taught how to prepare and inject the medicine, rotate injection sites, and store it in the refrigerator. do not shake the product. use only the device and needles provided and do not share injection devices. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have any cancer, a history of a brain tumor, diabetic retinopathy, active proliferative or severe nonproliferative retinopathy, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. do not use if you have active malignancy. use caution if you have diabetes or glucose intolerance, adrenal or thyroid disorders, scoliosis, obstructive sleep apnea, hip problems, pancreatitis, or a history of intracranial hypertension. report severe headache with visual changes, hip or knee pain with limping, abdominal pain, swelling of hands or feet, numbness or tingling in the hands, or signs of cancer recurrence. certain medicines including glucocorticoids, insulin and diabetes medicines, and oral estrogens can interact and may require dose adjustments. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required, but maintain a balanced diet. if you have diabetes, monitor carbohydrate intake and blood glucose as directed. in prader willi syndrome, adhere to nutritional guidance and weight management. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is the next day, skip the missed dose and resume your usual schedule. do not take extra doses. if you miss more than one dose, contact your clinician. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include injection site reactions, swelling, joint and muscle pain, headache, and fluid retention. it can increase blood sugar and may unmask hypothyroidism. carpal tunnel syndrome can occur in adults. serious effects include intracranial hypertension, pancreatitis, slipped capital femoral epiphysis with hip pain and limping, progression of scoliosis, and increased risk of certain cancers or tumor growth. seek urgent care for vision changes, severe abdominal pain, or breathing problems.

name: pseudoephedrine
text: why is this medication prescribed? pseudoephedrine is a decongestant used to relieve nasal and sinus congestion due to colds, allergies, or sinusitis and to relieve ear congestion from air travel or ear infections. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth with or without food and with a full glass of water. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time. swallow extended release tablets whole. measure liquids with a dosing device. avoid taking near bedtime to reduce insomnia. do not use more than directed on the label or by your clinician. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have taken a monoamine oxidase inhibitor within the past 14 days. tell your clinician if you have high blood pressure, heart disease, hyperthyroidism, diabetes, glaucoma, enlarged prostate or urinary retention, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. pseudoephedrine can raise blood pressure and heart rate and can cause nervousness and insomnia. avoid combining with other decongestants or stimulants. limit caffeine. check with your clinician or pharmacist before using with other medicines. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required, but limit caffeinated beverages to reduce jitteriness and insomnia. stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you use it on a schedule, take it when you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take extra doses. if you use it only as needed, take it when symptoms require it. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include insomnia, nervousness, restlessness, dizziness, headache, nausea, and dry mouth. it can increase heart rate and blood pressure and may cause palpitations. serious but rare effects include irregular heartbeat, hallucinations, seizures, severe allergic reactions, and urinary retention. stop and seek care if you develop chest pain, severe headache, or neurologic symptoms.

name: albuterol oral inhalation
text: important warning: overuse or increasing need for albuterol can signal worsening asthma and may be life threatening. do not exceed the prescribed dose. this medicine is for quick relief of bronchospasm and prevention of exercise induced symptoms, not for daily long term control. stop and seek medical care if breathing suddenly worsens after use, which may indicate paradoxical bronchospasm. why is this medication prescribed? albuterol is a short acting bronchodilator used to relieve wheezing and shortness of breath in asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and to prevent exercise induced bronchospasm. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed. for metered dose inhalers, prime before first use or if not used for the period stated in the instructions, shake well, exhale fully, seal lips around the mouthpiece, inhale deeply while pressing down on the canister, then hold your breath as directed. if two puffs are prescribed, wait at least one minute between puffs. use a spacer if recommended. for dry powder inhalers, follow the device specific steps. for nebulizer solution, use the prescribed dose in a nebulizer machine. keep your rescue inhaler with you. have your inhaler technique checked regularly. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, arrhythmias, seizures, hyperthyroidism, diabetes, or low potassium. some medicines including nonselective beta blockers, diuretics that lower potassium, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, and tricyclic antidepressants can interact. report chest pain, rapid or irregular heartbeat, severe tremor, or worsening breathing. if pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? limit excessive caffeine, which can worsen tremor and palpitations. maintain adequate potassium intake if advised, especially if you use medicines that can lower potassium. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is used as needed for symptoms. if you use it to prevent exercise induced bronchospasm, take it as directed before exercise. if you miss that pre exercise dose, do not double later. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include tremor, nervousness, headache, throat irritation, cough, and fast heartbeat. it may cause palpitations, muscle cramps, and transient increases in blood sugar. serious effects include paradoxical bronchospasm, chest pain, irregular heartbeat, low potassium, and allergic reactions.

name: quinapril
text: important warning: do not use quinapril if you are pregnant. drugs that act on the renin angiotensin system can cause injury and death to the developing fetus. stop quinapril as soon as pregnancy is detected and contact your clinician right away. why is this medication prescribed? quinapril is an ace inhibitor used to treat high blood pressure and to manage heart failure in combination with other medicines. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once or twice daily with or without food at the same times each day. your clinician will adjust the dose based on blood pressure and kidney function. continue to take it even if you feel well. what special precautions should i follow? do not take if you have a history of angioedema with ace inhibitors or if you are allergic to quinapril. tell your clinician if you have kidney disease, liver disease, dehydration, heart failure, diabetes, or if you use diuretics, potassium supplements, potassium sparing diuretics, or salt substitutes containing potassium. avoid using with aliskiren if you have diabetes and avoid combining routinely with an angiotensin receptor blocker. this medicine can cause low blood pressure, high potassium, kidney problems, cough, and rare but serious angioedema that requires emergency care. what special dietary instructions should i follow? limit salt substitutes and high potassium foods unless your clinician advises otherwise. limit alcohol which can increase dizziness. follow any sodium restriction plan recommended for your condition. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include cough, dizziness, headache, and fatigue. it can cause low blood pressure, increases in potassium and creatinine, and rash or taste changes. serious effects include angioedema with swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat, severe abdominal pain which can be intestinal angioedema, jaundice, and rare low white blood cell counts.

name: theophylline
text: important warning: theophylline has a narrow therapeutic range and high levels can cause serious and potentially life threatening side effects including seizures and dangerous heart rhythm problems. blood levels may need monitoring and many drugs and illnesses can alter levels. do not change dose or brand without medical guidance. why is this medication prescribed? theophylline is a bronchodilator used for maintenance treatment of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. it is not for sudden breathing attacks. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed at the same times each day. swallow extended release products whole and do not crush or chew. do not switch between different products without checking with your clinician. your dose may be adjusted based on symptoms and blood levels. keep using your reliever inhaler for acute symptoms. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. some antibiotics, antifungals, antidepressants, anti seizure medicines, stomach acid reducers, and others can raise or lower theophylline levels. smoking tobacco or cannabis, changes in smoking status, fever, liver disease, heart failure, thyroid disease, and older age can change how your body handles theophylline. avoid large amounts of caffeine because it can worsen side effects. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? maintain a consistent diet and limit excessive caffeine from coffee, tea, cola, energy drinks, or chocolate. avoid alcohol excess. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember if it is not close to your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take extra doses. if you miss more than one dose or develop symptoms of toxicity such as persistent vomiting, severe restlessness, rapid or irregular heartbeat, or seizures, seek medical care. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, stomach upset, headache, insomnia, tremor, nervousness, and palpitations. serious effects include persistent vomiting, severe agitation, seizures, very fast or irregular heartbeat, low blood pressure, and confusion.

name: hydrochlorothiazide
text: why is this medication prescribed? hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used to treat high blood pressure and to reduce fluid buildup in conditions such as heart failure and certain kidney or liver disorders. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily in the morning with or without food. taking it earlier in the day can reduce nighttime urination. your clinician may adjust the dose based on response and lab results. continue taking even if you feel well. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have kidney or liver disease, gout, diabetes, lupus, or an allergy to sulfonamide medicines. this medicine can cause low blood sodium, potassium, and magnesium, dehydration, low blood pressure, high uric acid, and increased blood sugar. it can rarely cause acute angle closure glaucoma or vision changes. it can increase sun sensitivity and has been associated with a higher risk of some non melanoma skin cancers with long term use, so use sun protection. check with your clinician before using with lithium or digoxin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? stay well hydrated. your clinician may advise limiting sodium and eating potassium rich foods unless you take other medicines that raise potassium. limit alcohol which can increase dizziness. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember unless it is late in the day and may cause nighttime urination. if it is close to your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include increased urination, dizziness, lightheadedness, and muscle cramps. it can cause electrolyte abnormalities such as low potassium or sodium, high uric acid with gout, and higher blood sugar. less common effects include rash, photosensitivity, pancreatitis, and rare eye pain or sudden vision changes that need urgent care.

name: acebutolol
text: important warning: do not stop acebutolol suddenly, especially if you have coronary artery disease. abrupt discontinuation can worsen chest pain or cause heart attack. your clinician will guide you to taper the dose over one to two weeks if it needs to be stopped. why is this medication prescribed? acebutolol is a beta blocker used to treat high blood pressure and certain abnormal heart rhythms and may be used to prevent angina. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once or twice daily at the same times each day. take consistently with respect to meals. your clinician will adjust the dose based on blood pressure, heart rate, and clinical response. do not stop taking it without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diabetes, thyroid disease, slow heart rate, heart block, heart failure, peripheral vascular disease, myasthenia gravis, depression, kidney or liver disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. this medicine can mask symptoms of low blood sugar and hyperthyroidism. use caution with other medicines that slow the heart such as verapamil, diltiazem, and digoxin, and with clonidine. report shortness of breath, wheezing, dizziness, fainting, very slow heart rate, swelling, or sudden weight gain. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required, but limit alcohol and be cautious with over the counter cold medicines that contain stimulants or decongestants. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is near the time of your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include tiredness, dizziness, nausea, and slow heart rate. it may cause low blood pressure, cold hands and feet, depression, sleep disturbances, and sexual dysfunction. serious effects include wheezing or bronchospasm, fainting, heart block, worsening heart failure, and severe allergic reactions.

name: aceclidine ophthalmic
text: why is this medication prescribed? aceclidine eye drops are used to lower pressure inside the eye in people with open angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension and to produce pupil constriction in certain situations. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed by your eye doctor. wash your hands, tilt your head back, pull down the lower eyelid to make a small pocket, and place one drop in the affected eye or eyes. do not touch the dropper tip to your eye or any surface. after instilling a drop, gently press the inner corner of the eye by the nose for one to two minutes and keep the eye closed to reduce systemic absorption. if you use other eye medicines, separate them by at least 5 to 10 minutes. remove soft contact lenses before use and wait at least 15 minutes before reinserting them. use at the same times each day and do not stop without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow?if you have ever had a retinal detachment, severe nearsightedness, uveitis, asthma or other breathing problems, parkinson disease, peptic ulcer disease, bowel or bladder obstruction, heart disease, or if you have had an allergic reaction to miotic eye drops such as pilocarpine. aceclidine may cause blurred or dim vision especially in low light. do not drive at night or perform tasks that require clear vision until you know how it affects you.about all medicines you use including other glaucoma drops. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include eye irritation, redness, tearing, brow ache, headache, and blurred vision. you may notice temporary nearsightedness. less common but serious effects include retinal detachment with symptoms such as sudden flashes or floaters and a curtain over part of your vision, slow heartbeat, sweating, increased salivation, shortness of breath, or wheezing. seek medical help right away if serious symptoms occur.

name: perindopril
text: important warning: do not take perindopril if you are pregnant. medicines that act on the renin angiotensin system can harm or cause death to an unborn baby. stop perindopril as soon as you learn you are pregnant and contact your doctor right away. why is this medication prescribed? perindopril is an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor used to treat high blood pressure, to help manage heart failure, and to reduce the risk of heart events in some people with stable coronary artery disease. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily at the same time each day with or without food. your doctor may adjust the dose based on your blood pressure and kidney function. take it regularly even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow?if you have ever had angioedema swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat, if you have kidney disease, liver disease, diabetes, dehydration, low sodium, renal artery stenosis, are on dialysis, or if you are black because the risk of angioedema may be higher.about all medicines you take including diuretics, potassium supplements, salt substitutes containing potassium, other drugs for blood pressure such as angiotensin receptor blockers or aliskiren, lithium, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, and any injectable gold therapy. perindopril can cause dizziness especially when you first start it or when the dose is increased. rise slowly from sitting or lying positions. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid potassium containing salt substitutes and limit high potassium supplements unless your doctor tells you otherwise. limit alcohol which can increase dizziness. stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is near the time of your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include cough, dizziness, headache, fatigue, and low blood pressure. it can increase potassium which may cause muscle weakness or abnormal heart rhythm. serious side effects include angioedema with swelling of the face or throat and trouble breathing, kidney problems with reduced urine or swelling, and rare liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes. seek urgent care for swelling of the face or throat or severe allergic reactions.

name: acetaminophen rectal
text: important warning: taking more than the recommended amount of acetaminophen can cause severe liver damage and can be life threatening. adults should not take more than 4000 milligrams in 24 hours from all sources. many prescription and nonprescription medicines contain acetaminophen sometimes labeled as apap. always read labels and ask if you are unsure. avoid alcohol while using acetaminophen. why is this medication prescribed? rectal acetaminophen is used to relieve mild to moderate pain and to reduce fever when oral dosing is not preferred. how should this medicine be used? use rectal suppositories exactly as directed. wash your hands, remove the wrapper, if needed moisten the suppository with water, lie on your side, and gently insert the pointed end into the rectum. remain lying for a few minutes to keep it in place. dosing is based on age and weight and is usually every 4 to 6 hours as needed. do not exceed the maximum daily dose. what special precautions should i follow?if you have liver disease, drink three or more alcoholic drinks per day, are malnourished, have severe kidney disease, have rectal bleeding or proctitis, or take warfarin since regular acetaminophen use can increase bleeding risk.about all medicines you use. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding ask your doctor about appropriate use and dosing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. drink fluids as directed if you have fever. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are taking it on a schedule, use it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not use two doses at once. if you use it only as needed, use it when pain or fever occurs and follow the maximum daily limits. what side effects can this medication cause? possible effects include rectal irritation, nausea, or rash. serious reactions include severe skin reactions such as stevens johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, or acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis, and signs of liver injury such as nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, sweating, stomach pain, dark urine, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. seek immediate help if overdose or serious reactions occur. call poison control right away if too much is used.

name: acetaminophen
text: important warning: taking more than the recommended amount of acetaminophen can cause severe liver damage and can be life threatening. adults should not take more than 4000 milligrams in 24 hours from all sources. many prescription and nonprescription medicines contain acetaminophen sometimes labeled as apap. always read labels and ask if you are unsure. avoid alcohol while using acetaminophen. why is this medication prescribed? acetaminophen is used to relieve mild to moderate pain from conditions such as headache, muscle aches, arthritis, backache, toothache, colds, and to reduce fever. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed on the label or by your doctor. use the dosing device that comes with liquid medicines. for children use weight based dosing. space doses at least 4 to 6 hours apart and do not exceed the maximum number of doses per day. what special precautions should i follow?if you have liver disease, drink three or more alcoholic drinks per day, are malnourished, or have severe kidney disease.and pharmacist about all medicines you take including warfarin because regular acetaminophen use can increase bleeding risk. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding discuss appropriate use and dosing with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are taking it on a schedule, take it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not take two doses at once. if you use it only as needed, take it when pain or fever occurs and follow the maximum daily limits. what side effects can this medication cause? acetaminophen is usually well tolerated. possible effects include nausea, stomach upset, or rash. serious reactions include severe skin reactions such as stevens johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, or acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis, and signs of liver injury such as nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, sweating, stomach pain, dark urine, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. seek medical help right away if serious reactions or overdose occur.

name: acetaminophen and codeine
text: important warning: this medicine contains an opioid. opioids can cause addiction, abuse, and misuse which can lead to overdose and death. serious and fatal breathing problems can occur, especially when starting the medicine or when the dose is increased. children are at particular risk and this medicine must not be used in children younger than 12 years and must not be used after tonsil surgery or adenoid surgery in anyone younger than 18 years. some people are ultrarapid metabolizers of codeine which can lead to dangerous levels of morphine. do not take with alcohol, benzodiazepines, or other medicines that cause sleepiness unless directed by your doctor due to the risk of severe sedation, breathing problems, coma, and death. this product also contains acetaminophen. taking more than 4000 milligrams of acetaminophen in 24 hours from all sources can cause severe liver damage. why is this medication prescribed? the combination is used to relieve moderate pain when other pain relievers are not enough. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed, usually every 4 to 6 hours as needed at the lowest effective dose for the shortest possible time. do not exceed the maximum daily dose of acetaminophen from all sources. measure liquid carefully with the provided device. store securely out of reach of others. do not stop suddenly if you have taken it for more than a few days. your doctor may tell you to lower the dose slowly. what special precautions should i follow?if you have breathing problems such as asthma, copd, or sleep apnea, head injury, seizures, liver or kidney disease, adrenal problems, low blood pressure, gallbladder disease, constipation, or pancreatitis.about all medicines you take including sedatives, benzodiazepines, sleep medicines, muscle relaxants, other opioids, antidepressants or migraine medicines that affect serotonin, and cyp2d6 inhibitors or inducers. do not drive or do activities that require alertness until you know how it affects you. do not use during pregnancy unless your doctor decides the benefits outweigh risks. use during pregnancy can cause neonatal withdrawal in the newborn. do not breastfeed because life threatening sedation and breathing problems have occurred in infants exposed to codeine in breast milk. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not drink alcohol. drink fluids, eat fiber, and consider a stool softener to help prevent constipation. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take this on a schedule, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you use it only as needed, take a dose when pain occurs and do not exceed prescribed limits. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, lightheadedness, constipation, nausea, vomiting, and itching. serious effects include slowed or stopped breathing, severe sleepiness, confusion, low blood pressure, fainting, serotonin syndrome with agitation, sweating, fast heartbeat, muscle stiffness, or diarrhea when combined with certain medicines, liver injury from too much acetaminophen, adrenal insufficiency with fatigue and weight loss, severe allergic reactions, and withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly after prolonged use. seek urgent care for severe breathing problems, unusual sleepiness, or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: acetaminophen injection
text: important warning: serious medication errors have occurred with acetaminophen injection including confusion between milligrams and milliliters and between pediatric and adult dosing. acetaminophen can cause severe liver damage if too much is given. your total daily dose from all sources must not exceed 4000 milligrams in adults. tell your healthcare team about all acetaminophen containing medicines you have received. why is this medication prescribed? intravenous acetaminophen is used to relieve mild to moderate pain, to reduce fever, and with opioids to relieve moderate to severe pain when oral or rectal routes are not suitable. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a healthcare professional through a vein over about 15 minutes, with the dose based on your age and weight and your liver and kidney function. doses are spaced at least 4 to 6 hours apart and the total daily dose must stay within recommended limits. what special precautions should i follow?if you have liver disease, drink alcohol regularly, are malnourished, or have severe kidney disease. tell your team about all medicines you receive including other acetaminophen products. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not drink alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is usually given in a hospital or clinic. if a dose is missed, your healthcare team will plan the next dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, headache, and itching. you may have pain or redness at the infusion site. serious reactions include allergic reactions such as rash, swelling, or trouble breathing, severe skin reactions, low blood pressure, and liver injury especially with overdose. tell your healthcare team right away if you develop concerning symptoms.

name: acetaminophen, butalbital, and caffeine
text: important warning: this product contains acetaminophen which can cause severe liver damage if you take more than 4000 milligrams in 24 hours from all sources or if you drink alcohol. it also contains butalbital, a barbiturate that can be habit forming, cause sedation, and lead to dependence and withdrawal if used regularly or in high amounts. using it too often can cause medication overuse headache. do not take with alcohol or other medicines that cause sleepiness unless directed by your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? this combination is used to relieve tension headaches when simple pain relievers are not enough. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed, usually one tablet or capsule at the start of a headache and then as prescribed, often every 4 hours as needed. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time. do not exceed the maximum daily dose and limit how many days per month you use it to avoid rebound headaches. what special precautions should i follow?if you have liver disease, a history of substance use disorder, mood disorders, porphyria, lung disease or sleep apnea, stomach ulcers, or kidney disease.about all medicines you take including other sedatives, opioids, benzodiazepines, sleep aids, antidepressants, seizure medicines, and blood thinners. avoid driving or tasks that require alertness until you know how it affects you. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, ask your doctor about risks and alternatives. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not drink alcohol. limit other sources of caffeine such as coffee, tea, and energy drinks to avoid jitteriness and fast heartbeat. drink water and maintain regular meals. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take it on a regular schedule, take it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not take two doses at once. if you use it only as needed, take it at headache onset and follow your doctors limits. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, lightheadedness, nausea, stomach upset, and feeling restless or unable to sleep. it may cause constipation. serious effects include severe liver injury from too much acetaminophen, severe allergic reactions, confusion, slow or shallow breathing, low blood pressure, dependence and withdrawal symptoms, and rash or severe skin reactions. seek urgent care for breathing problems, severe drowsiness, or signs of liver injury such as dark urine or yellowing of the skin or eyes.

name: acetazolamide
text: why is this medication prescribed? acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to reduce pressure inside the eye in glaucoma, to prevent and lessen symptoms of acute mountain sickness, and as an add on treatment for certain types of seizures and for some cases of fluid retention. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed. dosing depends on your condition. for mountain sickness prevention, start 24 to 48 hours before ascent and continue during ascent and for at least 48 hours at the altitude or until descent. for glaucoma and other conditions, take at evenly spaced times during the day. swallow extended release capsules whole. take with food or milk if stomach upset occurs and take earlier in the day to reduce nighttime urination. what special precautions should i follow? do not take if you have had a severe reaction to sulfonamide medicines.if you have severe liver disease, severe kidney disease, adrenal insufficiency, low sodium, low potassium, kidney stones, chronic lung disease, or metabolic acidosis.about all medicines you take, especially high dose aspirin, lithium, topiramate, anticonvulsants, and other diuretics. it may cause dizziness or fatigue. do not drive until you know how it affects you. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of fluids. your doctor may advise you to limit foods or products that alkalinize the urine such as sodium bicarbonate and to consider potassium rich foods such as bananas and oranges to reduce the risk of low potassium. avoid excessive alcohol at altitude. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include frequent urination, tingling of the fingers or toes, taste changes, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fatigue, and dizziness. it can cause electrolyte imbalances and metabolic acidosis with symptoms such as drowsiness or rapid breathing. less common but serious effects include kidney stones, severe skin rash, blood problems such as low white cells or platelets, liver problems, and severe allergic reactions. seek medical help if severe rash, confusion, bruising, or breathing problems occur.

name: medroxyprogesterone injection
text: important warning: medroxyprogesterone contraceptive injection can cause significant loss of bone mineral density. bone loss is greater with longer use and may not be completely reversible. use beyond 2 years only if other methods of birth control are not adequate. adequate calcium and vitamin d intake and weight bearing exercise are recommended. why is this medication prescribed? the injection is used to prevent pregnancy. it may also be used for certain gynecologic conditions as determined by your doctor. how should this medicine be used? it is given as an intramuscular or subcutaneous injection by a healthcare professional once every 3 months about every 13 weeks. the first injection is usually given within the first 7 days of a menstrual period. if given outside this time you may need to use backup contraception for 7 days. schedule your next injection before you leave the clinic. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are pregnant.if you have unexplained vaginal bleeding, breast cancer, a history of blood clots, stroke, or heart attack, osteoporosis or strong risk factors for bone loss, depression, diabetes, high blood pressure, migraine, liver disease, or if you smoke. this medicine does not protect against hiv or other sexually transmitted infections. it may cause a delay in return to fertility after stopping. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake and avoid smoking and excessive alcohol which worsen bone loss. maintain a balanced diet and exercise regularly. what should i do if i forget a dose? if more than 13 weeks have passed since your last injection, contact your healthcare provider as soon as possible. you may need a pregnancy test and to use backup contraception for at least 7 days after the next injection. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include changes in menstrual bleeding such as irregular bleeding or no periods, weight gain, headache, mood changes, decreased libido, acne, breast tenderness, and abdominal discomfort. it may reduce bone mineral density. serious effects include blood clots with pain or swelling in a leg, chest pain or shortness of breath, stroke symptoms, severe depression, severe allergic reactions, and jaundice. seek medical help right away for signs of blood clots or severe reactions.

name: medroxyprogesterone
text: important warning: in postmenopausal women, taking estrogen with progestin has been associated with an increased risk of heart attack, stroke, blood clots, breast cancer, and probable dementia. if medroxyprogesterone is prescribed with estrogen for hormone therapy, use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration needed. this medicine should not be used to prevent heart disease or dementia. why is this medication prescribed? oral medroxyprogesterone is used to treat secondary amenorrhea and abnormal uterine bleeding due to hormonal imbalance and to protect the lining of the uterus in postmenopausal women receiving estrogen therapy. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed, often once daily for a set number of days each month or in a cyclic schedule with estrogen. take at the same time each day. do not use if you are pregnant. if you have postmenopausal hormone therapy, your doctor will use the lowest dose for the shortest time that helps your symptoms. what special precautions should i follow?if you have a history of blood clots, stroke, heart attack, liver disease, breast cancer or cancer of the reproductive organs, undiagnosed vaginal bleeding, severe headaches or migraine, fluid retention, depression, diabetes, or a history of jaundice during pregnancy.about all medicines you take. report new breast lumps, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe headache, vision changes, leg pain or swelling, or jaundice right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required, but if you are postmenopausal consider adequate calcium and vitamin d intake and avoid smoking to protect bone health. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. do not take two doses at once. if you miss more than one dose in a cyclic regimen, contact your doctor for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include menstrual changes or spotting, breast tenderness, headache, nausea, bloating, mood changes, dizziness, and fatigue. serious effects include blood clots, stroke, heart attack, vision or speech changes, severe headache, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe allergic reactions, and liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes. seek medical help for serious symptoms.

name: aspirin rectal
text: important warning: aspirin can cause serious bleeding, especially in the stomach or brain, and should not be given to children or teenagers with viral illnesses such as flu or chickenpox due to the risk of reyes syndrome. do not use if you have active bleeding, a bleeding disorder, recent stomach or intestinal ulcers, severe uncontrolled high blood pressure, or if you are allergic to aspirin or other nsaids. why is this medication prescribed? rectal aspirin is used to reduce fever, relieve mild to moderate pain, and decrease inflammation when oral dosing is not possible; in some cases a clinician may use it to reduce blood clot risk, but this requires specific dosing and medical supervision. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed on the label or by your clinician. wash your hands, remove the suppository wrapper, moisten the tip with water if needed, lie on your side, gently insert the suppository pointed end first into the rectum adults generally about 2.5 cm or 1 inch, then remain lying for a few minutes to keep it from slipping out. do not use more often or for longer than directed. do not give to children or teens with a fever from viral illness. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about asthma, nasal polyps, stomach or intestinal ulcers or bleeding, gerd, kidney or liver disease, gout, anemia, low platelet count, g6pd deficiency, pregnancy or breastfeeding, and all medicines you use, especially blood thinners warfarin, doacs, other nsaids, ssris/snris, corticosteroids, methotrexate, and alcohol. stop and seek medical help for signs of bleeding vomiting blood, black stools, allergic reaction, severe abdominal pain, or ringing in the ears with dizziness. avoid using with other products that contain aspirin or salicylate. what special dietary instructions should i follow? limit or avoid alcohol because it increases bleeding risk. keep well hydrated; otherwise there are no specific dietary restrictions for the rectal form. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you use it on a schedule, insert it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose; if so, skip the missed dose. do not use two doses at once. if you use it only as needed for pain or fever, take it when needed and do not exceed the maximum daily dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include local rectal irritation or burning, nausea, or upset stomach. serious effects include stomach or intestinal bleeding, easy bruising or bleeding, ringing in the ears or hearing changes, dizziness, severe allergic reaction, and in children or teens with viral illness, reyes syndrome persistent vomiting, confusion, behavior changes.

name: aspirin
text: important warning: aspirin increases the risk of serious bleeding, including in the stomach and brain. do not give aspirin to children or teenagers with viral illnesses such as flu or chickenpox due to the risk of reyes syndrome. do not use if you have active bleeding, a bleeding disorder, a history of severe stomach ulcers or recent gi bleeding, or if you are allergic to aspirin or other nsaids. why is this medication prescribed? aspirin is used to treat pain, fever, and inflammation, and at low doses it is used to reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke in certain people as directed by a clinician. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed. for pain or fever, use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time needed. for heart protection, take the low-dose aspirin at the same time each day. swallow enteric-coated tablets whole; do not crush or chew them. nonenteric-coated tablets for suspected heart attack should be chewed if instructed by emergency personnel. take with a full glass of water and with food if it upsets your stomach. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have asthma or nasal polyps, stomach or intestinal ulcers, gerd, bleeding problems, kidney or liver disease, gout, anemia, low platelet count, g6pd deficiency, are pregnant avoid especially in the last trimester or breastfeeding, and list all medicines and supplements you take. important interactions include blood thinners warfarin, doacs, other nsaids, ssris/snris, corticosteroids, methotrexate, and alcohol. if you need occasional ibuprofen, take ibuprofen at least 8 hours before or at least 30 minutes after immediaterelease aspirin used for heart protection. stop and seek help for signs of bleeding, black stools, vomiting blood, unusual bruising, severe stomach pain, or allergic reactions. what special dietary instructions should i follow? limit or avoid alcohol to reduce bleeding risk; there are no specific food restrictions, but taking with food may lessen stomach upset. avoid other products containing aspirin or salicylates. what should i do if i forget a dose? for daily low-dose aspirin, take it as soon as you remember on the same day; if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. for as-needed use, take only when needed and do not exceed the labeled daily maximum. what side effects can this medication cause? upset stomach, heartburn, nausea, and easy bruising can occur. serious side effects include stomach or intestinal bleeding, severe allergic reactions, ringing in the ears or hearing changes, dizziness, kidney problems, and in children or teens with viral illness, reyes syndrome.

name: tetracycline
text: why is this medication prescribed? tetracycline is an antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections such as acne, respiratory and skin infections, some sexually transmitted infections, cholera, and certain tick-borne diseases; it does not treat viral infections like colds or flu. how should this medicine be used? take on an empty stomach with a full glass of water, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after meals and at least 2 hours before or 4 hours after dairy products, antacids, bismuth subsalicylate, or supplements containing calcium, magnesium, aluminum, iron, or zinc. swallow capsules or tablets with plenty of water and remain upright for 30 minutes to reduce the risk of esophageal irritation. take doses at evenly spaced intervals and complete the full course even if you feel better. protect your skin from sun exposure. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding; tetracycline can harm an unborn baby and cause permanent tooth discoloration and bone effects and is generally avoided during pregnancy and in children under 8 years old. inform your clinician about esophageal problems, liver or kidney disease, increased intracranial pressure, and all medicines you take. do not take with isotretinoin or acitretin due to risk of increased intracranial pressure. tetracycline may reduce the effectiveness of some hormonal contraceptives; use a reliable backup method during therapy. seek medical care if you develop severe headache, vision changes, persistent diarrhea, severe abdominal pain, rash, or signs of allergy. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid milk and dairy products and mineral supplements around dosing times as they reduce absorption. drink adequate fluids. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose; if so, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause?
