nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, photosensitivity with sunburn, and vaginal yeast infections can occur. serious effects include esophagitis or ulcers, severe skin reactions, liver problems, permanent tooth discoloration in children, increased intracranial pressure with severe headache or vision changes, and clostridioides difficileassociated diarrhea.

name: rabeprazole
text: why is this medication prescribed? rabeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease gerd, heal and prevent erosive esophagitis and duodenal ulcers, treat conditions with excessive stomach acid such as zollingerellison syndrome, and in combination with antibiotics to eradicate helicobacter pylori. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed, usually once daily. delayedrelease tablets should be swallowed whole; do not crush or chew. some formulations may be taken with or without food; follow your specific product instructions, and for sprinkle capsules give as directed before a meal. it is not for immediate relief of heartburn symptoms; allow several days for full effect. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have liver disease, osteoporosis, low magnesium, lupus, kidney problems, or if you have persistent diarrhea. longterm use may increase the risk of fractures, vitamin b12 deficiency, low magnesium, kidney problems, and certain infections such as c. difficile diarrhea. inform your clinician about all medicines you take, especially methotrexate, warfarin, digoxin, antifungals, antiretrovirals, and clopidogrel. seek care for severe persistent diarrhea, rash with joint pain, signs of low magnesium such as muscle cramps or irregular heartbeat, or kidney issues. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid foods and beverages that worsen reflux such as large fatty meals, chocolate, caffeine, mint, alcohol, and acidic or spicy foods. ensure adequate calcium and magnesium intake if on longterm therapy. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose; if so, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? headache, diarrhea, constipation, abdominal pain, nausea, gas, and rash may occur. serious effects include severe watery diarrhea, low magnesium, kidney inflammation, new or worsening lupus, and allergic reactions.

name: acitretin
text: important warning: acitretin can cause severe birth defects. do not use if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding. people who can become pregnant must use two effective forms of contraception for at least 1 month before starting, during treatment, and for at least 3 years after the last dose; have regular pregnancy tests; and must not drink alcohol during treatment and for 2 months after stopping because alcohol can convert acitretin to etretinate, which stays in the body much longer and greatly extends the risk of birth defects. do not donate blood during treatment and for 3 years after the last dose. acitretin can cause liver injury and high triglycerides; periodic blood tests are required. why is this medication prescribed? acitretin is an oral retinoid used to treat severe psoriasis in adults when other treatments are not effective. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed, usually once daily with your main meal to improve absorption. swallow capsules whole. do not take vitamin a supplements or other retinoids. follow your clinicians schedule for blood tests to monitor liver function and lipids. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions, especially liver disease, high cholesterol or triglycerides, diabetes, kidney disease, depression, bone disorders, and any eye problems, and list all medicines and supplements you use. avoid tetracyclines and methotrexate due to serious interaction risks. night vision may decrease; use caution when driving at night. limit exposure to sunlight and uv therapy. report severe headache, vision changes, mood changes, abdominal pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, or signs of pancreatitis immediately. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food, avoid all alcohol during treatment and for 2 months after stopping, avoid vitamin acontaining supplements and limit eating very highvitamin a foods in excess. if your triglycerides rise, follow clinicianadvised diet changes such as reducing sugars and saturated fats. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember the same day; if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? very common effects include dry lips and skin, dry eyes, nosebleeds, hair thinning, nail fragility, joint or muscle pain, headache, elevated liver enzymes, and increased cholesterol or triglycerides. serious effects include liver injury, pancreatitis, severe skin reactions, depression or mood changes, vision changes including decreased night vision, and increased intracranial pressure.

name: aclidinium oral inhalation
text: why is this medication prescribed? aclidinium is a longacting anticholinergic bronchodilator used as a maintenance treatment to improve breathing in adults with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease copd, including chronic bronchitis and emphysema; it is not for relief of sudden breathing problems. how should this medicine be used? use the pressair device exactly as prescribed, typically one inhalation twice daily about 12 hours apart. prepare the device, exhale fully away from the device, seal your lips around the mouthpiece, inhale quickly and deeply until you hear a click, hold your breath for as long as comfortable, and then exhale slowly. check the control window to confirm a successful dose. do not use more than directed and do not use to treat acute bronchospasm; keep a rescue inhaler such as albuterol available for sudden symptoms. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have narrowangle glaucoma, urinary retention, enlarged prostate or bladder neck obstruction, heart rhythm problems, or are pregnant or breastfeeding. inform your clinician about all medicines you take, especially other anticholinergics. stop use and seek care if you develop eye pain or vision changes, difficulty urinating, fast heartbeat, severe allergic reaction, or paradoxical bronchospasm. the device may contain lactose; tell your clinician if you have a severe milk protein allergy. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required, but staying hydrated and avoiding smoking can help your lungs. what should i do if i forget a dose? inhale a dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose; if so, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? dry mouth, cough, headache, sinus or throat irritation, and nausea can occur. less common but serious effects include urinary retention, worsening narrowangle glaucoma with eye pain or halos, fast or irregular heartbeat, and paradoxical bronchospasm.

name: acoltremon ophthalmic
text: why is this medication prescribed? i could not verify a medication named acoltremon for ophthalmic use in standard references. it may be a misspelling, a regional brand, or an investigational product; please confirm the exact name or active ingredient with your prescriber or pharmacist. how should this medicine be used? do not use until the medication name is confirmed; if you have the product, follow the specific instructions on its label and those provided by your eye care professional, including hand hygiene, proper drop technique, and dosing frequency. what special precautions should i follow? verify the correct medication and concentration before use. tell your clinician about eye conditions, contact lens use, allergies, and all medicines you use. do not use any eye medication that looks discolored, contains particles, or is past its expiration date. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary instructions apply to most ophthalmic drops. what should i do if i forget a dose? once the medication is confirmed, follow the productspecific missed dose instructions; in general, apply a missed dose when remembered unless it is close to the next scheduled dose, and do not double the dose. what side effects can this medication cause? side effects depend on the active ingredient; common eyedrop effects include temporary burning or stinging, blurred vision, or eye irritation. seek medical care for severe pain, vision changes, significant redness or swelling, or signs of allergic reaction. please contact your clinician or pharmacist to confirm this medications identity before use.

name: acoramidis
text: why is this medication prescribed? acoramidis is a transthyretin ttr stabilizer used to treat transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy attrcm to help slow disease progression and improve outcomes. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed, typically by mouth at a consistent time each day; your clinician will determine the dose. swallow tablets or capsules whole unless your product instructions say otherwise. you may take it with or without food. do not stop or change your dose without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about liver or kidney problems, pregnancy or plans to become pregnant, and all medicines and supplements you use. report new or worsening shortness of breath, swelling, weight gain, dizziness, or palpitations. keep all scheduled followup appointments and laboratory tests. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions for acoramidis. if you have heart failure, follow clinicianadvised sodium and fluid restrictions and limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember on the same day; if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? side effects may include gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea, nausea, or abdominal pain, swelling in the legs, fatigue, and dizziness. serious allergic reactions are uncommon but require immediate medical attention. your clinician may monitor liver tests and other labs during treatment.

name: fluoride
text: why is this medication prescribed? fluoride helps prevent tooth decay by strengthening tooth enamel; it is available in toothpastes, mouth rinses, gels, varnishes applied by dental professionals, and as prescription drops or tablets in areas with low fluoride in the water supply. how should this medicine be used? use fluoride products exactly as directed for your age and dental risk. brush with a peasized amount of fluoride toothpaste twice daily a smear for children under 3 years and spit out excess; do not swallow. for prescription drops or tablets, use the dose based on your childs age and the fluoride level in your drinking water; drops can be placed directly in the mouth or in a small amount of nondairy liquid, preferably at bedtime after brushing. mouth rinses and gels should be swished and spat out; do not swallow. what special precautions should i follow? keep all fluoride products out of reach of children to prevent accidental swallowing. supervise young children during brushing. tell your clinician or dentist if you have kidney disease or are on a lowsalt or special diet. combining multiple fluoride sources may increase the risk of fluorosis in children; your dentist can help assess total exposure. avoid taking fluoride tablets at the same time as calcium, magnesium, or aluminumcontaining products as they reduce absorption. what special dietary instructions should i follow? know your waters fluoride content to avoid excess; your dentist or local water authority can provide this. avoid giving fluoride tablets with milk or calciumcontaining foods; separate by at least 2 hours. what should i do if i forget a dose? for supplements, give the missed dose when remembered unless it is almost time for the next dose; if so, skip the missed dose. do not double doses. resume regular brushing or rinsing at the next scheduled time. what side effects can this medication cause? when used as directed, side effects are uncommon. possible effects include temporary tooth staining with some stannous fluoride products, mild mouth irritation, or stomach upset if swallowed. chronic excessive intake during tooth development can cause dental fluorosis mottling of enamel. large accidental ingestions can cause nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and electrolyte disturbances; seek emergency care if a large amount is swallowed.

name: tocilizumab injection
text: important warning: tocilizumab can increase the risk of serious, sometimes fatal infections including tuberculosis, bacterial, invasive fungal, and opportunistic infections. your clinician will evaluate and treat latent tb if needed before starting and monitor closely during treatment; do not start if you have an active infection. tocilizumab can also cause gastrointestinal perforation, especially in people with diverticulitis, and can cause severe decreases in white blood cells or platelets and elevations in liver enzymes; regular blood tests are required. why is this medication prescribed? tocilizumab is an interleukin6 receptor inhibitor used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, giant cell arteritis, polyarticular and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis, cytokine release syndrome after certain cart therapies, and in some settings hospitalized adults with severe covid19 in combination with steroids. how should this medicine be used? tocilizumab is given by subcutaneous injection at home on a schedule set by your clinician for example every week or every other week or by intravenous infusion in a clinic or hospital for certain indications. for injections, allow the prefilled syringe or autoinjector to reach room temperature, inspect the solution, choose a new site each time abdomen, thigh, or upper arm, and inject as instructed; do not shake. keep all lab and followup appointments. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all infections or exposures, tb or hepatitis history, gi disease such as diverticulitis, liver disease, low blood counts, recent vaccinations, pregnancy or breastfeeding, and all medicines you take. do not receive live vaccines during treatment. tocilizumab can alter the levels of other drugs metabolized by the liver; your clinician may need to adjust doses of drugs such as warfarin, statins, cyclosporine, and some oral contraceptives. seek medical care promptly for fever, chills, cough, shortness of breath, painful urination, severe stomach pain, black stools, easy bruising or bleeding, yellowing of the skin or eyes, severe headache, or allergic reactions. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions, but limit alcohol to reduce liver risk and maintain a balanced diet to support immune health and lipid control. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a subcutaneous dose, take it as soon as you remember if it is within a few days of the scheduled time; otherwise skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. for infusions, contact your clinic to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? injection site reactions, upper respiratory infections, headache, dizziness, increased blood pressure, and elevated cholesterol can occur. serious effects include severe infections, gi perforation, low white blood cells or platelets, liver injury, allergic reactions, and reactivation of tuberculosis.

name: cosyntropin injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? cosyntropin is used to test how well your adrenal glands respond to adrenocorticotropic hormone as part of an acth stimulation test to help diagnose adrenal insufficiency and related conditions. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a healthcare professional as a single intravenous or intramuscular injection. blood samples for cortisol are taken before the dose and at specific times after the dose, most often at 30 and 60 minutes, following your laboratory protocol. follow any pre test instructions such as timing of other medicines. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines and supplements, especially steroids, oral estrogens, mifepristone, ketoconazole, and anti seizure medicines, since they can affect test results.about allergies and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. recent or ongoing steroid use can blunt the response and may require rescheduling. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. follow any fasting or timing instructions given by your testing center. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss your scheduled test or injection appointment, contact your healthcare provider to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? temporary flushing, nausea, headache, dizziness, increased blood pressure, and pain or irritation at the injection site may occur. rarely, allergic reactions with rash, wheezing, or swelling can occur. seek urgent care for severe reactions.

name: corticotropin, repository injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? corticotropin repository is used to treat infantile spasms and to manage short term flares of certain inflammatory or autoimmune conditions such as multiple sclerosis exacerbations and nephrotic syndrome when corticosteroid effects are needed. how should this medicine be used? it is given by subcutaneous or intramuscular injection. dosing depends on the condition being treated and your response. your clinician will teach you or a caregiver how to inject it and how to taper the dose. do not stop suddenly after longer courses unless your doctor tells you to because this can cause adrenal insufficiency. what special precautions should i follow? this medicine can suppress your immune system and your adrenal glands.if you have an active infection, a history of stomach ulcers, osteoporosis, diabetes, high blood pressure, heart failure, kidney problems, glaucoma, cataracts, mood disorders, seizures, or thyroid disease. avoid live vaccines during treatment and for a period after.about all medicines, including diuretics, potassium lowering drugs, anticoagulants, aspirin and other nsaids, diabetes medicines, and vaccines. if you develop fever, severe stomach pain, black stools, severe mood changes, or vision problems, contact your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? your doctor may advise limiting salt, ensuring adequate potassium, calcium, and vitamin d, and moderating carbohydrate intake if you have diabetes. avoid alcohol to reduce the risk of stomach bleeding. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next dose, then skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you miss more than one dose, call your doctor to adjust the taper schedule. what side effects can this medication cause? swelling, weight gain, increased appetite, mood changes, insomnia, elevated blood pressure, high blood sugar, acne, easy bruising, muscle weakness, delayed wound healing, and increased risk of infections. serious effects include stomach bleeding, severe headache or vision changes, severe allergic reactions, and seizures.

name: haemophilus influenzae type b hib vaccine
text: why is this medication prescribed? the hib vaccine helps prevent serious infections caused by haemophilus influenzae type b such as meningitis, pneumonia, epiglottitis, and bloodstream infections, mainly in young children and in certain high risk adults. how should this medicine be used? it is given as an intramuscular injection by a healthcare provider. the routine series is usually at 2 and 4 months with a booster at 12 to 15 months, and some products include a 6 month dose. unvaccinated older children and certain adults with asplenia, sickle cell disease, or after stem cell transplant may receive catch up doses per guidelines. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider about any severe allergy to a previous hib vaccine or to vaccine components and if the child has a bleeding disorder or takes blood thinners. vaccination may be deferred for moderate or severe illness. people with weakened immune systems can receive the vaccine but may have a reduced response. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if a dose is missed, schedule the next visit as soon as possible. the series does not need to be restarted, and the remaining doses will be given on a catch up schedule. what side effects can this medication cause? redness, swelling, or soreness at the injection site, mild fever, irritability, sleepiness, and decreased appetite can occur. severe allergic reactions are rare but require urgent care and present with hives, wheezing, or facial swelling.

name: doxycycline
text: why is this medication prescribed? doxycycline treats many bacterial infections including acne, skin and respiratory infections, some sexually transmitted infections, lyme disease and other tick borne illnesses, and it is used to prevent malaria in travelers. it is also used for rosacea. how should this medicine be used? take it by mouth with a full glass of water and remain upright for at least 30 minutes. take it at the same times each day and for the full course even if you feel better. for malaria prevention start 1 to 2 days before travel, continue daily while in the area, and continue for 4 weeks after leaving. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to tetracyclines, if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding. it is usually avoided in children younger than 8 years except for serious infections. it can increase sun sensitivity so use sun protection. do not take it within 2 hours of antacids, calcium or iron supplements, magnesium, zinc, or bismuth subsalicylate. it may reduce the effectiveness of some oral contraceptives, so use an additional birth control method.if you have liver disease or trouble swallowing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take it with food if your stomach is upset, but avoid taking it with dairy products or calcium fortified foods at the same time. drink plenty of water. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, sun sensitivity with rash or sunburn, headache, yeast infections, and irritation or ulcers in the esophagus. serious effects include severe allergic reactions and increased pressure in the skull with severe headache and vision changes.

name: chlorpheniramine
text: why is this medication prescribed? chlorpheniramine is an antihistamine used to relieve allergy and common cold symptoms including sneezing, runny nose, itchy or watery eyes, and hives. how should this medicine be used? take it by mouth as directed by your doctor or the product label. it comes as immediate release and extended release tablets, capsules, liquids, and chewable forms. measure liquid doses carefully and do not exceed the recommended dose. avoid taking other products that also contain antihistamines. what special precautions should i follow? this medicine may cause drowsiness and impair your ability to drive or operate machinery. avoid alcohol and other sedating medicines.if you have glaucoma, enlarged prostate, difficulty urinating, asthma or chronic bronchitis, stomach ulcers, thyroid disease, heart disease, high blood pressure, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. children and older adults may be more sensitive to side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. avoid alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not double the dose. what side effects can this medication cause? drowsiness, dizziness, dry mouth, dry eyes, blurred vision, constipation, difficulty urinating, fast heartbeat, confusion especially in older adults, and rarely allergic reactions.

name: ursodiol
text: why is this medication prescribed? ursodiol is used to dissolve certain cholesterol gallstones in people who cannot have surgery and to treat primary biliary cholangitis by improving bile flow and reducing liver inflammation. how should this medicine be used? take it by mouth with food in divided doses as prescribed. swallow tablets or capsules whole. if using a liquid, shake well and measure with a dosing device. it may take several months to see the full effect and your doctor will monitor liver tests and imaging. what special precautions should i follow?about allergies, pregnancy, and breastfeeding.if you have gallbladder or bile duct obstruction, pancreatitis, frequent biliary colic, or liver failure.about all medicines, especially bile acid binding resins such as cholestyramine or colestipol, aluminum antacids, oral estrogens, and some birth control pills that can reduce effectiveness. take other medicines that bind bile acids at a different time as advised. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take doses with meals. follow your doctors advice about a balanced diet and maintaining a healthy weight. if you have gallstones, your doctor may advise limiting very high cholesterol foods. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? diarrhea or constipation, stomach pain, nausea, headache, dizziness, back pain, cough, skin rash, and occasionally worsening of liver tests. contact your doctor if you notice jaundice, dark urine, or severe abdominal pain.

name: interferon gamma-1b injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? interferon gamma 1b helps reduce the frequency and severity of infections in chronic granulomatous disease and improves outcomes in severe malignant osteopetrosis by enhancing immune function. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection, usually three times per week in the evening. a healthcare provider will teach you how to prepare and inject it, rotate injection sites, and store the vials. do not shake the vial and do not use if the solution is cloudy or contains particles. what special precautions should i follow?if you have a history of depression, seizures, heart disease, liver or kidney disease, thyroid problems, bone marrow suppression, or autoimmune disease. this medicine can cause flu like symptoms and can affect liver enzymes and blood counts, so regular monitoring is needed.about all medicines and supplements, including other immune therapies and theophylline. if you become pregnant or are breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. seek care for severe mood changes, persistent fever, severe abdominal pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or signs of infection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. stay well hydrated and consider a light snack with the dose if advised to help with flu like symptoms. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember if it is the same day. if it is the next day, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? fever, chills, fatigue, muscle aches, headache, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, redness or pain at the injection site, elevated liver enzymes, low white blood cell count, mood changes, and rarely serious allergic reactions.

name: dactinomycin
text: important warning: dactinomycin can cause severe bone marrow suppression that increases the risk of serious infection and bleeding, serious and sometimes fatal liver injury including blockage of liver blood vessels, and severe tissue damage if the drug leaks outside the vein. it must be given under the supervision of experienced healthcare professionals with the ability to manage severe complications. why is this medication prescribed? dactinomycin is a chemotherapy medicine used to treat certain cancers including wilms tumor, rhabdomyosarcoma, ewing sarcoma, testicular cancer, and gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion in a clinic or hospital, often in cycles and sometimes with other chemotherapy medicines. doses are based on body size or weight. your team will monitor blood counts and organ function before each dose and take precautions to prevent leakage outside the vein. what special precautions should i follow?about any infections, fevers, unusual bruising or bleeding, liver disease, prior radiation to the liver, and all medicines and supplements. avoid live vaccines during treatment and until your doctor says it is safe. use effective contraception during treatment and for the advised period after the last dose and do not breastfeed. report mouth sores, severe nausea or vomiting, yellowing of the skin or eyes, abdominal pain, or swelling at the infusion site. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there is no specific diet required. eat small frequent meals and drink fluids to help with nausea and maintain hydration. avoid alcohol to reduce liver strain. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by your oncology team. if you miss an appointment, contact them to reschedule as soon as possible. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, vomiting, mouth sores, diarrhea, loss of appetite, hair loss, fatigue, rash, elevated liver enzymes, severe bone marrow suppression that can lead to infections, anemia, or bleeding, severe tissue injury if the drug leaks outside the vein, and serious liver injury that can be life threatening.

name: alteplase injection
text: important warning: alteplase can cause severe and life threatening bleeding including bleeding in the brain. it should be used only by trained clinicians who can select appropriate patients and monitor and treat bleeding complications. why is this medication prescribed? alteplase is a thrombolytic medicine used to dissolve blood clots in acute ischemic stroke within a specific time window, in some cases of heart attack when other treatments are not available, in massive pulmonary embolism with instability, and to clear blocked central venous catheters. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion in a hospital with continuous monitoring, with dose and duration based on your weight and the condition being treated. for catheter clearance, it is instilled into the catheter and withdrawn after a set time. blood pressure and neurological status are closely monitored and brain imaging is used to confirm stroke eligibility. what special precautions should i follow? you should not receive alteplase if you have active internal bleeding, certain types of prior brain bleeding, very high uncontrolled blood pressure, recent major surgery or head trauma, or specific bleeding disorders. tell your team about recent procedures, strokes, gastrointestinal bleeding, ulcers, liver disease, use of blood thinners, and if you are pregnant or postpartum. invasive procedures and intramuscular injections are minimized for 24 hours after treatment when possible. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no dietary instructions apply during emergency treatment. after treatment, follow your care teams advice which may include limiting alcohol and following a heart healthy diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? not applicable in emergencies. if you miss an appointment for catheter clearance, contact your clinic to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? bleeding from gums or nose, bruising, low blood pressure, nausea, fever, and serious bleeding including intracranial hemorrhage with sudden severe headache, weakness, confusion, or loss of consciousness, and allergic reactions including swelling of the face or tongue especially when used with certain blood pressure medicines.

name: estrogen and progestin hormone replacement therapy
text: important warning: estrogen with or without progestin increases the risk of blood clots, stroke, heart attack, breast cancer, and dementia in some women. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest possible time and do not use to prevent cardiovascular disease or dementia. why is this medication prescribed? estrogen and progestin therapy treats moderate to severe hot flashes and other menopausal symptoms, treats moderate to severe vaginal dryness and discomfort, and helps prevent osteoporosis in women at high fracture risk when other options are not suitable. progestin is included for women with a uterus to reduce the risk of endometrial overgrowth from estrogen. how should this medicine be used? it is taken as tablets by mouth, applied on the skin as patches or gels, or used as a vaginal ring or cream depending on the product. dosing may be continuous or cyclic and is individualized. follow your doctors directions and do not stop suddenly without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have or have had breast cancer or other estrogen dependent cancers, unexplained vaginal bleeding, active or past blood clots, stroke, heart attack, or severe liver disease.about all medicines and supplements, smoking status, migraines, high blood pressure, high triglycerides, gallbladder disease, diabetes, and family history of cancer. you will need regular breast exams and mammograms and monitoring of blood pressure and lipids. seek urgent care for chest pain, shortness of breath, coughing blood, sudden severe headache, vision changes, or leg swelling. what special dietary instructions should i follow? limit alcohol which can increase breast cancer risk and raise triglycerides. follow a heart healthy diet and ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d as advised. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. if you use a patch and it falls off, reapply it or replace it as directed. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? breast tenderness, nausea, bloating, headache, mood changes, leg cramps, vaginal spotting or bleeding, fluid retention, elevated blood pressure, and rare but serious events such as blood clots, stroke, heart attack, gallbladder disease, and breast cancer.

name: risedronate
text: important warning: risedronate can cause severe irritation and ulcers of the esophagus if not taken exactly as directed. rare but serious problems include osteonecrosis of the jaw and unusual fractures of the thigh bone; dental procedures and certain risk factors can increase these risks. seek urgent care for chest pain, new or worsening heartburn, painful or difficult swallowing, jaw pain, or new thigh or groin pain. why is this medication prescribed? risedronate is used to treat and prevent osteoporosis in postmenopausal women and men, to treat glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis, and to treat pagets disease of bone. how should this medicine be used? take risedronate exactly as directed. for immediate-release tablets, take first thing in the morning on an empty stomach with a full glass of plain water, at least 30 minutes before your first food, beverage, or other medications, and remain sitting or standing upright for at least 30 minutes and until after your first food. swallow tablets whole with plain water only; do not use mineral water, coffee, juice, or milk, and do not chew or suck the tablet. do not take at bedtime or before rising. if you are prescribed delayed-release risedronate, take it immediately after breakfast with at least 4 ounces of plain water and do not take it fasting. follow the dosing schedule your doctor prescribed daily, weekly, or monthly and do not split or crush tablets. what special precautions should i follow?if you have trouble swallowing, esophageal disorders, low calcium levels, severe kidney disease, cannot sit or stand upright for 30 minutes, or plan dental surgery. have a dental exam and complete any major dental work before starting therapy if possible. ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake; correct low calcium before starting. avoid smoking and limit alcohol.about all medicines and supplements, especially calcium, iron, magnesium, aluminum antacids, and other medications taken in the morning; take them at least 30 minutes after risedronate or at a different time as advised. report severe bone, joint, or muscle pain or new thigh or groin pain. what special dietary instructions should i follow? maintain adequate calcium and vitamin d as advised by your clinician. take risedronate only with plain water. avoid food, beverages, calcium or iron supplements, and antacids around the time of your dose as directed. what should i do if i forget a dose? for once-daily dosing, skip the missed dose if it is almost time for your next dose; do not take two doses on the same day. for once-weekly dosing, take one tablet the morning after you remember; then resume your regular scheduled day, and never take two tablets on the same day. for once-monthly dosing, if the next scheduled dose is more than 7 days away, take the missed dose the morning after you remember and resume monthly dosing from that new date; if the next scheduled dose is within 7 days, skip the missed dose and take the next dose on the scheduled day. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include stomach pain, heartburn, nausea, diarrhea or constipation, and bone, joint, or muscle pain. serious effects include severe chest pain or heartburn, difficulty or pain with swallowing, black or bloody stools, severe bone or joint pain, jaw pain or nonhealing sores in the mouth, and new or unusual thigh or groin pain; seek medical attention promptly.

name: metformin
text: important warning: metformin can rarely cause lactic acidosis, a serious buildup of lactic acid in the blood that can be fatal. the risk is higher with significant kidney disease, liver disease, heavy alcohol use, dehydration, heart failure, advanced age, and during or after contrast dye studies or surgery. stop metformin and seek emergency care if you develop fast or difficult breathing, severe fatigue, unusual sleepiness, muscle pain, stomach discomfort, dizziness, or slow or irregular heartbeat. your doctor may stop metformin before iodinated contrast studies or surgery and restart it after your kidney function is checked. why is this medication prescribed? metformin is used with diet and exercise to improve blood sugar control in adults and children with type 2 diabetes; it may be used alone or with other diabetes medicines. how should this medicine be used? take metformin exactly as directed, with meals to reduce stomach upset. immediate-release tablets or liquid are usually taken two or three times daily with meals. extended-release tablets are usually taken once daily with the evening meal and must be swallowed whole; do not crush, split, or chew. your dose may be increased gradually to reduce gastrointestinal side effects. check blood sugar as directed. what special precautions should i follow?if you have kidney or liver disease, heart failure, drink alcohol frequently or binge drink, are older than 65, have b12 deficiency, or will receive iodinated contrast or have surgery; you may need to stop metformin temporarily. do not use metformin if your estimated glomerular filtration rate is too low as directed by your clinician.about all medicines and supplements. learn signs of low blood sugar if you also take insulin or other drugs that can cause hypoglycemia. stay hydrated and follow sick-day rules; stop metformin and contact your clinician if you become seriously ill or dehydrated. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the meal plan recommended for diabetes. take doses with food. limit alcohol to reduce the risk of lactic acidosis and low blood sugar. ensure adequate vitamin b12 intake; your doctor may periodically check b12 levels. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember with food unless it is almost time for your next dose; if so, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, diarrhea, stomach upset, gas, loss of appetite, and a metallic taste. it can lower vitamin b12 levels over time, causing anemia or neuropathy. serious effects include lactic acidosis symptoms as above, allergic reactions, and very low blood sugar when used with other glucose-lowering agents.

name: pioglitazone
text: important warning: pioglitazone can cause or worsen congestive heart failure. do not use if you have severe heart failure, andif you develop shortness of breath, rapid weight gain, swelling of the legs or ankles, or unusual fatigue. why is this medication prescribed? pioglitazone is used with diet and exercise to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes; it may be used alone or with other diabetes medicines. how should this medicine be used? take pioglitazone once daily with or without food at the same time each day. your doctor will adjust the dose based on your blood sugar response; it may take several weeks to see the full effect. continue monitoring blood sugar as directed. what special precautions should i follow?if you have or have had heart failure, swelling, liver disease, bladder cancer, blood in the urine, eye problems like macular edema, or if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. do not use for type 1 diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis. use with insulin or other drugs that cause fluid retention may increase the risk of swelling and heart failure. women may be more likely to fracture bones while taking this medicine; discuss bone health. pioglitazone may increase the chance of ovulation in premenopausal women who do not normally ovulate; use effective contraception if pregnancy is not desired. report urinary symptoms such as blood in urine, painful urination, or urgent need to urinate. your doctor may monitor liver enzymes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the meal plan recommended for diabetes and maintain a healthy weight. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember on the same day; if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include weight gain, swelling of the ankles or legs, headache, sinusitis or upper respiratory symptoms, and bone fractures. serious effects include new or worsening heart failure, shortness of breath, rapid weight gain, fluid retention, vision changes from macular edema, liver problems such as dark urine or jaundice, low blood sugar when used with other diabetes medicines, and possible bladder cancer signals such as blood in the urine or lower abdominal pain.

name: ketorolac ophthalmic
text: why is this medication prescribed? ketorolac ophthalmic solution is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory eye drop used to relieve ocular itching due to seasonal allergic conjunctivitis and to treat pain and inflammation after cataract or other eye surgery as directed. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as prescribed, typically one drop in the affected eyes up to four times daily. wash hands before use, remove contact lenses, tilt your head back, pull down the lower eyelid to form a pocket, instill the drop without touching the bottle tip to the eye, and close the eye gently for 1 to 2 minutes. if using other eye medications, separate them by at least 5 minutes. do not wear contact lenses while your eyes are inflamed; if your drops contain preservatives such as benzalkonium chloride, wait at least 15 minutes after dosing before reinserting lenses. do not touch the dropper tip to any surface. what special precautions should i follow?if you have had asthma, aspirin or nsaid allergy, bleeding problems, corneal diseases, dry eye, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, or recent or planned eye surgery. prolonged use of topical nsaids may delay corneal healing and, rarely, cause corneal thinning or ulceration, particularly in patients with risk factors. stop and seek care for new eye pain, blurred vision, increased redness, sensitivity to light, or signs of infection such as discharge. do not use longer than prescribed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose; if so, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include temporary stinging or burning, eye irritation, headache, and blurred vision. serious effects include corneal problems such as thinning, erosion, or ulceration, delayed healing, eye infection, and allergic reactions or asthma symptoms in sensitive individuals; stop the medication and seek medical attention if these occur.

name: acyclovir topical
text: why is this medication prescribed? topical acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus skin infections such as cold sores on the lips and face, and certain genital herpes lesions as directed; it helps lesions heal faster but does not cure herpes or prevent transmission. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed at the first sign of tingling, redness, or burning. for cold sores, apply a thin layer to the affected area five times daily, about every three hours while awake, for four days or as prescribed. for ointment regimens, your doctor may direct up to six applications daily for up to seven days. wash hands before and after application, and use a finger cot or glove if applying to genital lesions. do not apply in the eyes, inside the mouth or nose, or on severely broken skin unless directed. what special precautions should i follow? for external use only. avoid sexual contact when lesions are present and until healed to reduce the risk of transmission.if you are immunocompromised, pregnant, or breastfeeding, or if lesions are severe or do not improve. do not share this medication. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply as soon as you remember and then continue your usual schedule; do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild burning, stinging, itching, dryness, or flaking at the application site. less common effects include redness, swelling, or a skin rash. severe allergic reactions are rare; stop use and seek medical help if you develop hives, swelling, or trouble breathing.

name: acyclovir
text: why is this medication prescribed? acyclovir is an antiviral used to treat herpes simplex virus infections including genital herpes and cold sores, to treat shingles herpes zoster and chickenpox varicella, and for suppressive therapy to reduce recurrences and viral shedding; it does not cure herpes. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed, with or without food, and start as soon as possible at the first sign of symptoms for best results. swallow tablets or capsules with a full glass of water and stay well hydrated while taking this medication. shake the oral suspension well before each dose and measure carefully. dosing varies by infection type, kidney function, and age; do not change your dose without medical advice. complete the full course even if you feel better. what special precautions should i follow?if you have kidney problems, are elderly, are dehydrated, have neurologic conditions, are immunocompromised, or are pregnant or breastfeeding. some medicines can affect acyclovir levels or kidney effects;about all medicines and supplements. maintain good hydration to reduce the risk of kidney problems. acyclovir may cause dizziness or confusion in some people; use caution with activities requiring alertness until you know how it affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of fluids unless your doctor has told you to restrict fluids. no specific diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose; if so, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, diarrhea, headache, and fatigue. serious effects include kidney problems such as decreased urination or swelling, neurologic symptoms such as tremor, confusion, agitation, hallucinations, or seizures especially in older adults or those with kidney disease, blood disorders in immunocompromised patients, and severe allergic reactions; seek medical attention if these occur.

name: acyclovir buccal
text: why is this medication prescribed? acyclovir buccal tablets are used to treat recurrent cold sores in immunocompetent adults; they deliver acyclovir locally over many hours to shorten healing time when started promptly. how should this medicine be used? apply a single buccal tablet to the upper gum on the same side as the cold sore, preferably within 1 hour of the onset of symptoms such as tingling or burning. place the rounded side against the upper gum just above the incisor canine fossa and hold in place with light pressure for 30 seconds to ensure adhesion. do not chew, crush, or swallow the tablet; allow it to dissolve and stay in place, typically over 12 to 14 hours. avoid touching or repositioning it with your tongue or fingers. if the tablet falls off within the first 6 hours, you may apply a new one; if it falls off after 6 hours, do not replace it. avoid brushing teeth on that side and avoid chewing gum while the tablet is in place. what special precautions should i follow? for buccal use only.if you have severe dry mouth, dentures or dental appliances that interfere with placement, milk protein allergy if your product contains milk-derived excipients, are pregnant or breastfeeding, or are immunocompromised. avoid kissing or sharing utensils during an outbreak to reduce transmission. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may eat and drink normally, but avoid chewing gum or hard, sticky foods on the side of the tablet while it is in place. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you did not apply the tablet at the first sign of a cold sore, apply as soon as possible; if the cold sore is already advanced, contact your clinician for advice for this episode. do not apply more than one tablet for a single episode unless replacing a tablet that fell off within 6 hours. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mouth or gum pain, irritation at the application site, headache, altered taste, and nausea. serious allergic reactions are rare; seek medical help if you develop swelling, hives, or difficulty breathing.

name: acyclovir injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? intravenous acyclovir is used to treat severe herpes simplex infections such as encephalitis, neonatal herpes, disseminated infections in immunocompromised patients, and severe varicella-zoster infections, and may be used when oral therapy is not appropriate. how should this medicine be used? acyclovir injection is administered by a healthcare professional as an intravenous infusion over at least 1 hour to reduce the risk of kidney toxicity. dosing is based on your weight, type of infection, and kidney function; your doctor may adjust the dose and frequency if you have kidney impairment. adequate hydration before and during therapy is important. what special precautions should i follow?about kidney disease, dehydration, neurologic conditions, pregnancy or breastfeeding, and all medicines you take including those that affect the kidneys. you will be monitored with labs for kidney function and blood counts. report pain, burning, or swelling at the infusion site. use caution with activities that require alertness if you feel dizzy or confused. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of fluids if your clinician allows, especially around infusion times. no special diet is otherwise needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, contact your healthcare provider as soon as possible to reschedule; do not attempt to self-administer unless you have specific training and instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, headache, and inflammation of the vein at the injection site. serious effects include kidney problems such as increased creatinine or decreased urine output due to crystal precipitation, neurologic effects such as confusion, agitation, hallucinations, tremors, or seizures, blood abnormalities, liver enzyme elevations, and severe allergic reactions; seek medical attention if these occur.

name: acyclovir ophthalmic
text: why is this medication prescribed? acyclovir ophthalmic ointment is used to treat herpes simplex keratitis, an infection of the cornea caused by herpes simplex virus. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed by your eye specialist, commonly applying a 1 cm ribbon of ointment into the lower eyelid sac of the affected eye five times daily until the corneal ulcer heals, then three times daily for an additional seven days. wash hands before and after use. avoid touching the tip of the tube to your eye or any surface to keep it sterile. do not wear contact lenses during treatment unless your doctor tells you it is safe. blurred vision may occur briefly after application; avoid driving until your vision clears. what special precautions should i follow?if you have allergies to acyclovir or valacyclovir, other eye diseases, are pregnant or breastfeeding, or use other eye medications; separate other eye medicines by at least 5 to 10 minutes. stop and seek care if you develop worsening eye pain, swelling, discharge, sensitivity to light, or vision changes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose; if so, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild eye burning or stinging, temporary blurred vision, eyelid irritation, and superficial punctate keratopathy. serious effects include allergic reactions, worsening inflammation, or corneal problems; contact your doctor if these occur.

name: dapsone topical
text: why is this medication prescribed? topical dapsone gel is used to treat acne vulgaris. it helps reduce inflammatory lesions and may be used on the face and other affected areas as directed. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed. for 7.5 percent gel, apply a thin layer once daily to clean, dry skin over the entire affected area. for 5 percent gel, apply a thin layer twice daily as prescribed. use a pea-sized amount for the entire face and avoid the eyes, inside the nose, mouth, and broken skin. wash hands after application. if you also use benzoyl peroxide, apply at different times of day to minimize the risk of temporary yellow-orange discoloration at application sites. what special precautions should i follow?if you have glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, anemia, methemoglobinemia, peripheral neuropathy, or a sulfone allergy. even though systemic absorption is low, topical dapsone can, rarely, cause hemolysis or methemoglobinemia, especially in people with g6pd deficiency; seek medical care for symptoms such as unusual fatigue, shortness of breath, dark urine, dizziness, headache, or gray or blue-colored skin or lips.if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. do not apply to large areas or use more often than prescribed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next application; if so, skip the missed application and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include redness, dryness, oiliness, peeling, and mild burning or stinging at the application site. less common effects include rash and headache. rare but serious effects include hemolytic anemia and methemoglobinemia, especially in patients with g6pd deficiency, and severe allergic reactions; stop the medication and seek medical attention if these occur.

name: covid-19 vaccine, viral vector janssen [johnson & johnson]
text: important warning: rare cases of blood clots with low platelets called thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome and cases of guillain barre syndrome have occurred after this vaccine. seek urgent care for severe headache, vision changes, fainting, chest pain, shortness of breath, leg swelling, severe or persistent abdominal pain, easy bruising or tiny blood spots under the skin, weakness or tingling especially in the legs, trouble walking, or facial droop. do not receive this vaccine again if you developed thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome after a prior dose. why is this medication prescribed? it is given to help prevent covid nineteen. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a healthcare professional as a single injection into a muscle and some people may be advised to receive an additional dose according to public health guidance. if you previously received this vaccine ask about using an mrna or protein based vaccine for any additional doses. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider about any severe allergies including to polysorbate, a history of thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome, heparin induced thrombocytopenia, guillain barre syndrome, bleeding disorders, current fever or moderate to severe illness, pregnancy, breastfeeding, or if you are immunocompromised. do not get this vaccine if you had a severe allergic reaction after a previous dose of this vaccine or to a component. you will be monitored briefly after the injection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a scheduled appointment, reschedule as soon as possible and follow current guidance for additional doses. what side effects can this medication cause? pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site, tiredness, headache, muscle aches, chills, fever, nausea, and swollen lymph nodes are common and usually resolve within a few days. severe allergic reactions can occur. rarely, blood clots with low platelets or guillain barre syndrome can occur. seek care for chest pain, shortness of breath, severe or persistent headache, vision changes, confusion, weakness, difficulty speaking, or severe abdominal pain.

name: tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis tdap vaccine
text: why is this medication prescribed? it protects against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis. it is recommended once in adulthood, during each pregnancy, and as boosters to maintain protection. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a healthcare professional as an injection into a muscle. most adults receive one dose of tdap followed by a tetanus and diphtheria booster every ten years. pregnant people should receive one dose during each pregnancy preferably between twenty seven and thirty six weeks. after certain dirty wounds a booster may be needed if it has been five years or longer since the last tetanus shot. what special precautions should i follow? do not receive tdap if you had a severe allergic reaction to a previous tetanus, diphtheria, or pertussis vaccine or to any component. tell your provider if you ever had encephalopathy within seven days after a pertussis containing vaccine, a history of guillain barre syndrome within six weeks of a tetanus containing vaccine, a severe local reaction after a tetanus containing vaccine, progressive neurologic disease, or if you are moderately or severely ill. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss your scheduled vaccination, reschedule as soon as possible. if you are behind on boosters you usually do not need to restart the series. what side effects can this medication cause? soreness, redness, or swelling at the shot site, mild fever, tiredness, headache, and body aches are common. fainting can occur after injections. severe allergic reactions are rare. very rarely, nerve inflammation such as brachial neuritis can occur.

name: adagrasib
text: why is this medication prescribed? it treats cancers that have a kras g twelve c mutation including non small cell lung cancer after prior therapy and it may be used with cetuximab for previously treated colorectal cancer with this mutation. how should this medicine be used? the usual dose is six hundred milligrams by mouth twice daily with or without food. swallow tablets whole and do not crush or chew. if you vomit after a dose do not take an extra dose and take the next dose at the regular time. treatment continues until disease progression or unacceptable side effects. your doctor may change your dose for side effects. what special precautions should i follow?if you have heart rhythm problems or a history of long qt, liver problems, lung disease or breathing symptoms, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. use effective birth control during treatment and for at least one week after the last dose. adagrasib can interact with many medicines. avoid strong cyp3a inhibitors and inducers and avoid other drugs that prolong the qt interval. avoid proton pump inhibitors and h two blockers. if an antacid is needed take adagrasib at least two hours before or two hours after the antacid. your provider may check heart tracings and blood tests for electrolytes and liver function. report new or worsening cough, fever, or shortness of breath which can be due to pneumonitis. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and seville orange products. stay well hydrated if you have diarrhea or vomiting. what should i do if i forget a dose? if it is less than four hours since the missed dose take it as soon as you remember. if more than four hours have passed skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, stomach pain, decreased appetite, fatigue, swelling, cough or shortness of breath, changes in liver tests, dizziness, and rash are common. serious effects can include abnormal heart rhythm from qt prolongation, severe diarrhea with dehydration, interstitial lung disease or pneumonitis, severe liver injury, and pancreatitis.

name: crizanlizumab-tmca injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? it was approved to reduce the frequency of vaso occlusive crises in people with sickle cell disease. the indication has been withdrawn in the united states because a confirmatory trial did not verify benefit. if you are receiving this medicine, discuss with your specialist whether to continue or switch to alternatives. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion by a healthcare professional at week zero and week two and then every four weeks. you will be monitored during and after each infusion. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider about any prior severe infusion reactions or allergies. report new or worsening pain, hives, itching, swelling, dizziness, wheezing, or shortness of breath during or after infusions. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your clinic to receive the missed infusion as soon as possible. subsequent doses are usually scheduled every four weeks from the date of the most recent dose. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, joint or back pain, fever, diarrhea, itching, and infusion reactions are common. serious reactions can include severe pain crises during infusion, hypersensitivity, or anaphylaxis.

name: nifedipine
text: why is this medication prescribed? it treats high blood pressure and chest pain from angina and may be used for raynaud phenomenon. how should this medicine be used? take it exactly as prescribed. extended release tablets are usually taken once daily. swallow tablets whole and do not bite, split, or crush them. immediate release capsules should not be used for sudden severe blood pressure elevations unless directed by a specialist. what special precautions should i follow?if you have heart failure, very low blood pressure, severe aortic stenosis, liver disease, or if you recently had a heart attack. nifedipine can cause dizziness or lightheadedness so rise slowly from sitting or lying down. do not stop it suddenly without medical advice. many drugs affect nifedipine levels including certain antibiotics, antifungals, hiv medicines, seizure medicines, and rifampin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember unless it is close to your next scheduled dose. if it is almost time for the next dose skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? ankle or foot swelling, headache, flushing, dizziness, fatigue, nausea, constipation, heartburn, and palpitations are common. gum overgrowth can occur with long term use. rarely, severe low blood pressure, worsening chest pain, or heart attack can occur in susceptible people.

name: amantadine
text: why is this medication prescribed? it helps treat symptoms of parkinson disease and drug induced movement problems and certain extended release forms help treat levodopa induced dyskinesia. it is no longer recommended for routine prevention or treatment of influenza a because most strains are resistant. how should this medicine be used? take it exactly as prescribed. immediate release is usually taken once or twice daily. extended release products are taken once daily often at bedtime and should be swallowed whole. doses are adjusted for kidney function. do not stop suddenly; your doctor will taper your dose. what special precautions should i follow?if you have kidney disease, heart disease, low blood pressure, glaucoma, mental health conditions, seizures, or eczema. amantadine can cause drowsiness, sudden sleep, dizziness, confusion, hallucinations, impulse control problems, and suicidal thoughts. avoid alcohol and do not drive until you know how it affects you. older adults may be more sensitive. discuss use if pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required; maintain hydration and avoid alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember unless it is close to the next scheduled dose. if you miss an extended release bedtime dose skip it and take the next dose at the usual time. do not take extra doses. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, dizziness, insomnia, dry mouth, constipation, mottled skin discoloration called livedo reticularis, ankle swelling, low blood pressure on standing, agitation, and hallucinations are common. serious effects include suicidal thoughts, urinary retention, kidney problems, and a serious reaction if stopped abruptly that resembles neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

name: adapalene
text: why is this medication prescribed? it is a topical retinoid that treats acne by keeping pores clear and reducing inflammation. how should this medicine be used? for skin use only. after gently washing and drying the area, apply a thin layer once daily preferably in the evening to the entire area where you get acne, not just to individual pimples. use a pea sized amount for the whole face and avoid the eyes, lips, inner nose, and broken or sunburned skin. wash hands after applying. you may use a gentle non comedogenic moisturizer and sunscreen. improvement is usually seen after eight to twelve weeks and acne can temporarily appear worse during early treatment. what special precautions should i follow?about any skin conditions, eczema, sun sensitivity, or if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. adapalene can increase sensitivity to sunlight and wind or cold. use sunscreen and protective clothing and avoid tanning beds. avoid products that dry or irritate the skin such as astringents, abrasive cleansers, and alcohol based products. if severe irritation occurs reduce frequency or stop and contact your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it when you remember unless it is close to the next application. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? dryness, redness, burning, itching, peeling, and mild sun sensitivity are common. rarely, severe irritation, swelling, or allergic contact dermatitis can occur.

name: tralokinumab-ldrm injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? it treats moderate to severe atopic dermatitis in adults who are not adequately controlled with topical therapies or when those therapies are not advisable. how should this medicine be used? it is injected under the skin. the usual starting dose is six hundred milligrams given as four separate injections, then three hundred milligrams every two weeks. some patients who are well controlled may extend to every four weeks if directed by their prescriber. you or a caregiver can be trained to inject into the thigh, abdomen away from the navel, or upper arm if given by a caregiver. rotate injection sites and do not inject into tender, bruised, or scarred skin. continue prescribed topical therapies as directed. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you had a serious allergy to tralokinumab.if you have eye symptoms, as conjunctivitis and keratitis can occur. treat any parasitic worm infection before starting. avoid live vaccines during treatment. discuss use if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember and then resume your regular schedule. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue as scheduled. do not use extra doses. what side effects can this medication cause? injection site reactions, upper respiratory infections, headache, stomach pain, and eye inflammation such as conjunctivitis are common. allergic reactions are uncommon but can be serious.

name: brentuximab vedotin injection
text: important warning: this medicine can cause progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, a serious brain infection that can be fatal. call your doctor right away for confusion, memory problems, vision changes, trouble speaking, weakness, or seizures. do not use with bleomycin because of a risk of severe lung injury. why is this medication prescribed? it treats certain cancers that express cd thirty including classical hodgkin lymphoma, systemic anaplastic large cell lymphoma, and other cd thirty positive lymphomas, and it is used alone or with other chemotherapy as directed by your oncologist. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion by healthcare professionals, often once every three weeks or on other schedules depending on the regimen. the dose is based on body weight and your doctor may adjust or delay doses for side effects. you will be observed during and after infusions. what special precautions should i follow?about nerve problems, infections, liver or kidney disease, lung disease, diabetes, or recent chemotherapy or radiation. this drug can cause peripheral neuropathy, low blood counts, serious infections, infusion reactions, liver injury, pancreatitis, tumor lysis syndrome, lung toxicity, and severe skin reactions. avoid becoming pregnant or fathering a child during treatment and for six months after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for at least one week after the final dose. avoid live vaccines during treatment. some drugs that affect cyp3a may interact. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required but maintain good hydration unless your care team advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your clinic to reschedule as soon as possible. the schedule will be adjusted to maintain appropriate intervals. what side effects can this medication cause? fatigue, nausea, diarrhea, constipation, stomach pain, fever, cough, rash, itching, hair loss, decreased appetite, and peripheral neuropathy with numbness, tingling, or pain are common. low white blood cells, anemia, and low platelets can occur. serious effects include infections and sepsis, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, severe liver problems, pancreatitis, lung injury, and severe skin reactions such as stevens johnson syndrome.

name: tadalafil
text: why is this medication prescribed? it treats erectile dysfunction, symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia, and under a different brand treats pulmonary arterial hypertension. how should this medicine be used? for erectile dysfunction it may be taken as needed or once daily. for as needed use, the common starting dose is ten milligrams taken at least thirty minutes before sexual activity and not more than once daily. for daily use, two and a half to five milligrams is taken at about the same time each day. for benign prostatic hyperplasia, five milligrams is taken once daily. swallow tablets with water and take with or without food. your doctor may adjust the dose based on response and other medicines. what special precautions should i follow? do not take tadalafil with any nitrates or with riociguat as this combination can cause a dangerous drop in blood pressure.about heart disease, recent heart attack or stroke, low blood pressure or uncontrolled high blood pressure, liver or kidney disease, eye problems such as retinitis pigmentosa or prior vision loss due to nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, hearing problems, stomach ulcers or bleeding risk, blood cell disorders, penile deformity, or conditions that predispose to prolonged erections. it can cause sudden vision or hearing loss and prolonged erection. limit alcohol because it can increase dizziness and blood pressure lowering. many medicines interact including strong cyp3a inhibitors such as ketoconazole or ritonavir and inducers such as rifampin. use with alpha blocker medicines requires careful dose timing and monitoring. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take it with or without food but avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take tadalafil daily, take the missed dose when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not take extra to make up for a missed dose. if you use it as needed there is no scheduled dose. what side effects can this medication cause? headache, flushing, nasal congestion, indigestion or heartburn, back pain, muscle aches, and dizziness are common. rare but serious effects include a severe drop in blood pressure, chest pain, allergic reaction, sudden hearing loss or vision loss, and an erection lasting more than four hours which requires emergency care.

name: ibuprofen
text: important warning: this medicine can increase the risk of serious heart and blood vessel problems including heart attack and stroke, and the risk may increase with longer use or at higher doses. it can also cause serious and sometimes fatal stomach or intestinal bleeding or ulcers without warning. do not use right before or after coronary artery bypass graft surgery. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time needed. why is this medication prescribed? ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti inflammatory medicine used to relieve pain, reduce fever, and decrease inflammation from conditions such as arthritis, muscle aches, dental pain, and menstrual cramps. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed on the label or by your doctor. swallow with a full glass of water, and taking it with food or milk may reduce stomach upset. do not take more often or for longer than directed. do not use multiple products that contain ibuprofen or other nonsteroidal anti inflammatory medicines at the same time. what special precautions should i follow?about all allergies to aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti inflammatory medicines, any history of stomach or intestinal ulcers or bleeding, heart disease, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, kidney or liver disease, asthma, fluid retention, or if you smoke. many medicines interact with ibuprofen including blood thinners, antiplatelets, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, steroids, other pain relievers, ace inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, diuretics, lithium, and methotrexate. avoid use after twenty weeks of pregnancy unless your doctor tells you to, and do not use in the last trimester. ask about use while breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food or milk if your stomach is sensitive. limit or avoid alcohol because it raises the risk of stomach bleeding. stay well hydrated, especially if you have kidney disease risks. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take it on a schedule, take the missed dose when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include upset stomach, heartburn, nausea, dizziness, or drowsiness. serious effects that need urgent care include chest pain, shortness of breath, weakness on one side of the body, slurred speech, black or bloody stools, vomit that looks like coffee grounds, severe stomach pain, swelling of the legs, sudden weight gain, little or no urine, severe rash, swelling of the face or throat, or wheezing.

name: dextroamphetamine and amphetamine
text: important warning: this medicine has a high risk for abuse and dependence. misuse can cause sudden death and serious heart or blood vessel problems. keep it in a safe place and never share it. your doctor will monitor for misuse, blood pressure, heart rate, and mental health changes. why is this medication prescribed?
