text: why is this medication prescribed? butoconazole vaginal cream treats vaginal yeast infections caused by candida. how should this medicine be used? use intravaginally exactly as directed, often as a single dose or a short course depending on the product. apply at bedtime with the provided applicator. avoid sexual intercourse during treatment. do not use tampons, douches, or other vaginal products during therapy. complete the full course even if symptoms improve. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are allergic to azole antifungals. talk to a clinician before use if this is your first vaginal yeast infection, if you have fever, pelvic or abdominal pain, foul smelling discharge, sores, or if you have recurrent infections. avoid contact with eyes. the product base may weaken latex condoms and diaphragms for up to three days after use, so use alternative protection. if pregnant, consult your clinician before use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for the next dose. if you are using a single dose regimen and you missed it, apply it as soon as possible. do not use extra cream to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild vaginal burning, itching, or irritation, pelvic cramps, and headache. serious allergic reactions are rare but may include rash, hives, swelling, or trouble breathing. if symptoms worsen or do not improve within a few days, contact your clinician.

name: butorphanol injection
text: important warning: butorphanol is an opioid. opioids can cause addiction, abuse, and misuse which can lead to overdose and death. serious and life threatening breathing problems may occur, especially when starting or after a dose increase, or when combined with benzodiazepines, alcohol, or other central nervous system depressants. use during pregnancy can cause neonatal opioid withdrawal. butorphanol can also precipitate withdrawal in people who are dependent on other opioids. why is this medication prescribed? butorphanol injection is used to relieve moderate to severe pain and for pain during labor as determined by a clinician. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a clinician by intravenous or intramuscular injection. the dose is individualized and the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration should be used. you will be monitored for breathing, blood pressure, and sedation. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements, especially benzodiazepines, sedatives, alcohol, other opioids, muscle relaxants, sleep medicines, antipsychotics, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors. tell your clinician if you have breathing problems, sleep apnea, head injury, increased pressure in the skull, liver or kidney disease, gallbladder disease, heart disease, seizures, or a history of substance use disorder. do not drive or operate machinery until the effects have worn off. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are receiving this as an outpatient and miss a scheduled dose, contact your clinician to reschedule. do not take extra doses. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, sweating, constipation, dry mouth, and changes in blood pressure or heart rate. serious effects include slow or difficult breathing, severe sedation, fainting, allergic reactions, adrenal insufficiency, serotonin syndrome, seizures, and dependence or withdrawal. seek urgent medical help for serious effects.

name: butorphanol nasal spray
text: important warning: butorphanol is an opioid. opioids can cause addiction, abuse, and misuse which can lead to overdose and death. serious and life threatening breathing problems may occur, especially when starting or after a dose increase, or when combined with benzodiazepines, alcohol, or other central nervous system depressants. use during pregnancy can cause neonatal opioid withdrawal. butorphanol can also precipitate withdrawal in people who are dependent on other opioids. why is this medication prescribed? butorphanol nasal spray is used for the management of pain severe enough to require an opioid and for which alternative treatments are inadequate. how should this medicine be used? read the patient instructions. prime the spray before first use by pumping until a fine mist appears. gently blow your nose, insert the tip into one nostril, and spray as directed. do not sniff hard after spraying. doses may be repeated as directed with minimum intervals. do not exceed the maximum daily dose your clinician prescribes. keep the bottle capped, do not share it with others, and discard as directed after the labeled period from first use. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements, especially benzodiazepines, sedatives, alcohol, other opioids, sleep medicines, antipsychotics, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors. tell your clinician if you have breathing problems, sleep apnea, head injury, liver or kidney disease, gallbladder disease, heart disease, nasal conditions, seizures, or a history of substance use disorder. this medicine may cause drowsiness or dizziness. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you use it as needed, take it when you need pain relief as directed, observing the minimum interval between doses. if you are on a schedule and miss a dose, use it when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, altered taste, nasal irritation or congestion, and sweating. serious effects include slow or difficult breathing, severe sedation, fainting, allergic reactions, adrenal insufficiency, serotonin syndrome, seizures, and dependence or withdrawal. seek urgent medical help for serious effects.

name: econazole topical
text: why is this medication prescribed? econazole topical is used to treat fungal skin infections such as athletes foot, jock itch, ringworm, and tinea versicolor. how should this medicine be used? for skin use only. clean and dry the affected area. apply a thin layer once or twice daily as directed, covering the affected skin and a small amount of surrounding skin. wash hands before and after use. do not use occlusive dressings unless directed. continue for the full time prescribed even if symptoms improve. what special precautions should i follow? do not use on the eyes, mouth, or inside the vagina. tell your clinician about any allergies. tell your clinician if you are using warfarin or other blood thinners and you need to apply econazole to large areas or for long periods. if there is no improvement after two to four weeks depending on the condition being treated, contact your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild burning, stinging, redness, irritation, or dryness at the application site. serious allergic reactions are rare but may include rash, hives, swelling, or blisters.

name: eculizumab injection
text: important warning: eculizumab increases the risk of serious and life threatening meningococcal infections. vaccination against meningococcal disease is required at least two weeks before starting treatment, or antibiotic prophylaxis is needed until two weeks after vaccination if treatment must start sooner. patients and caregivers must be educated on the signs of meningococcal infection and the need for urgent care. why is this medication prescribed? eculizumab is a complement inhibitor used to treat paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome, generalized myasthenia gravis in certain patients, and neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion by a clinician on a loading schedule followed by maintenance doses at regular intervals. do not stop treatment without medical guidance, as disease symptoms can return and may worsen. what special precautions should i follow? receive required meningococcal vaccines, including serogroups acwy and b, and keep boosters current. your clinician may prescribe antibiotics when starting. watch for fever, headache, stiff neck, confusion, muscle aches, rash, nausea, or sensitivity to light and seek urgent care if these occur. tell your clinician about all infections and vaccines. avoid live vaccines during treatment. tell your clinician if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. infusion reactions can occur, so report shortness of breath, chest tightness, rash, or dizziness during or after infusion. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your clinician as soon as possible to reschedule the infusion. do not double up doses. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, upper respiratory infections, nausea, diarrhea, back pain, and infusion reactions. serious effects include meningococcal sepsis, other serious infections, allergic or infusion reactions, liver enzyme elevations, and a return or worsening of disease if treatment is interrupted.

name: edaravone injection
text: important warning: edaravone contains sodium bisulfite which may cause severe allergic type reactions including anaphylaxis and asthma symptoms in susceptible individuals. hypersensitivity reactions including rash, hives, swelling, and breathing problems have been reported. why is this medication prescribed? edaravone is used to slow the decline in the ability to perform daily activities in people with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion by a clinician. the usual schedule is once daily for fourteen days followed by a fourteen day drug free period for the first cycle, then once daily for ten days out of each fourteen day period within a twenty eight day cycle thereafter. your clinician will adjust the schedule as appropriate and will monitor you during and after infusions. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have asthma, a history of sulfite sensitivity, or have had allergic reactions to edaravone. report any rash, hives, swelling, wheezing, shortness of breath, or dizziness during or after infusion. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements and if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your treatment team to reschedule the missed infusion within the planned cycle. do not receive extra doses without medical direction. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include bruising, headache, gait disturbance, falls, fatigue, cough, shortness of breath, and skin reactions such as rash or eczema. serious effects include hypersensitivity reactions and anaphylaxis, swelling of the face lips tongue or throat, and severe breathing problems. seek urgent medical help for serious effects.

name: edaravone oral
text: why is this medication prescribed? edaravone oral suspension is used to slow the loss of physical function in people with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis als. it is a freeradical scavenger that may help reduce oxidative stress in the nervous system. how should this medicine be used? take the oral suspension exactly as directed, usually in treatment cycles. the initial cycle is one dose by mouth or feeding tube once daily for 14 days, followed by 14 days off. subsequent cycles are one dose once daily for 10 days within a 14day period for example, 10 days on and 4 days off, followed by 14 days off. shake the bottle gently before each use and measure the dose with the provided oral syringe. administer on an empty stomach, preferably in the morning after an overnight fast. do not eat for at least 8 hours before your dose and for at least 1 hour after your dose; water is allowed. if you use a feeding tube, flush the tube before and after dosing as directed. store and discard the product as instructed by the manufacturer once opened. do not change your dosing schedule without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow?and pharmacist if you are allergic to edaravone or any of its ingredients, including sulfites, or if you have asthma or a history of sulfite sensitivity.about all medicines and supplements you take.if you have kidney problems, are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. edaravone can cause allergic reactions, including potentially serious hypersensitivity; stop the medicine and seek urgent care for rash, hives, swelling of the face, lips, or throat, wheezing, or trouble breathing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take on an empty stomach as directed. do not eat for at least 8 hours before the dose and for at least 1 hour after the dose. water is allowed during the fasting period. otherwise, follow your doctors dietary advice. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day, then take your next dose at the usual time. if you do not remember until the next day, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not take two doses on the same day. keep the overall treatment cycle schedule as directed by your doctor. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include headache, dizziness, fatigue, bruising, gait disturbance, and skin rash. serious side effects can include allergic reactions or anaphylaxis, wheezing or shortness of breath especially in people with sulfite sensitivity, swelling, and hives. call your doctor if any side effect is severe or does not go away, and seek emergency help for signs of a severe reaction.

name: edoxaban
text: important warning: edoxaban can cause serious bleeding which may be lifethreatening; call your doctor or seek emergency help for unexpected bleeding or bruising, pink or brown urine, red or black stools, coughing or vomiting blood, severe headache, weakness, or dizziness. do not stop taking edoxaban without talking to your doctor; stopping suddenly increases the risk of stroke or blood clots. in people with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation and normal to high kidney function creatinine clearance greater than 95 ml/min, edoxaban may be less effective at preventing stroke; your doctor will determine if another medicine is better for you. people who receive spinal or epidural anesthesia or puncture while taking edoxaban are at increased risk of developing a spinal or epidural hematoma which may cause longterm or permanent paralysis; tell your healthcare providers you take edoxaban before any spinal procedures and seek urgent care if you develop back pain, numbness or weakness in the legs, or loss of bladder or bowel control. why is this medication prescribed? edoxaban is used to prevent stroke and systemic embolism in people with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation and to treat deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism after 5 to 10 days of initial treatment with a parenteral anticoagulant. it is a factor xa inhibitor that helps prevent harmful blood clots. how should this medicine be used? take edoxaban by mouth once daily with or without food at the same time each day. the dose is based on your condition, kidney function, body weight, and other medicines; do not change your dose unless your doctor tells you to. for atrial fibrillation, your doctor will confirm your kidney function is appropriate before prescribing. for dvt or pe, it is started after 5 to 10 days of anticoagulation with an injection or infusion. if you are scheduled for surgery or dental work, ask your doctor when to stop and restart edoxaban. what special precautions should i follow?and pharmacist about all your medicines, including other anticoagulants, antiplatelet drugs, nsaids, certain antidepressants, and herbal supplements such as st. johns wort, because these can increase bleeding risk or affect edoxaban levels.if you have kidney or liver disease, artificial heart valves, moderatetosevere mitral stenosis, a history of bleeding or stroke, stomach or intestinal ulcers, low body weight, or if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. use extra caution to avoid injury and bleeding. carry a medication card or wear a medical alert bracelet. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take edoxaban with or without food. unlike warfarin, there are no specific vitamin k restrictions. limit alcohol and avoid activities that increase bleeding risk. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day, then take your next dose at the usual time the next day. do not take two doses at the same time to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include easy bruising, nosebleeds, bleeding gums, and anemia. serious side effects include severe or uncontrollable bleeding, blood in urine or stools, vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds, coughing up blood, severe headache, dizziness or fainting, weakness on one side of the body, slurred speech, vision changes, back pain or neurologic symptoms after spinal procedures, and allergic reactions. seek medical attention immediately for serious symptoms.

name: efavirenz
text: why is this medication prescribed? efavirenz is used with other antiretroviral medicines to treat human immunodeficiency virus hiv infection. it helps lower the amount of hiv in the blood and improve immune function but does not cure hiv. how should this medicine be used? take efavirenz by mouth once daily exactly as directed, usually at bedtime to lessen nervous system side effects. take on an empty stomach; taking it with food, especially a highfat meal, can increase side effects. swallow tablets or capsules whole. take efavirenz with other antiretroviral drugs as part of your prescribed regimen and do not change or stop any medicine without your doctors advice. what special precautions should i follow?and pharmacist about all medicines and supplements you take. many drugs interact with efavirenz, including certain antifungals, antibiotics, anticonvulsants, antidepressants, antipsychotics, methadone, hormonal contraceptives, directacting antivirals for hepatitis c, and herbal products like st. johns wort. efavirenz can cause nervous system and psychiatric symptoms such as dizziness, trouble concentrating, abnormal dreams, insomnia, depression, anxiety, and rarely severe mental health problems including suicidal thoughts; contact your doctor right away if you develop severe mood changes, confusion, hallucinations, or thoughts of selfharm. use caution when driving or doing tasks that require alertness until you know how it affects you.if you have liver disease, a history of seizures, heart rhythm problems or a prolonged qt interval, or if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. efavirenz may reduce the effectiveness of hormonal birth control; use a reliable barrier method and discuss contraception and pregnancy planning with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take efavirenz on an empty stomach, preferably at bedtime. avoid highfat meals around dosing because they can increase side effects. limit alcohol and cannabis, which can worsen nervous system effects. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. if it is close to your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include dizziness, drowsiness, trouble concentrating, abnormal or vivid dreams, insomnia, headache, nausea, diarrhea, rash, and fatigue. serious side effects can include severe depression or other psychiatric symptoms, suicidal thoughts, severe rash or blistering skin reactions such as stevensjohnson syndrome, liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, rightsided abdominal pain, or heart rhythm problems. call your doctor right away for serious symptoms.

name: efavirenz, emtricitabine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate
text: important warning: severe, potentially lifethreatening lactic acidosis and enlarged fatty liver can occur with nucleostide analogs. get emergency help if you develop unusual weakness or tiredness, abdominal pain with nausea and vomiting, shortness of breath, cold or blue hands and feet, or irregular heartbeat. if you have hepatitis b virus hbv infection, your hbv may suddenly worsen after you stop this medicine; do not stop without talking to your doctor. your doctor will test you for hbv before starting treatment and will monitor liver function for several months after stopping. this medicine can cause serious liver problems and severe rash; contact your doctor right away for yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe fatigue, or skin blistering. why is this medication prescribed? this singletablet regimen combines efavirenz, emtricitabine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate tdf to treat hiv1 infection in adults and certain adolescents. it lowers the amount of hiv in the body and improves immune function but does not cure hiv. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth once daily as directed, preferably at bedtime on an empty stomach to lessen nervous system side effects from efavirenz. swallow the tablet whole. do not take with other medicines that contain emtricitabine, lamivudine, or tenofovir disoproxil fumarate. this product is not recommended if your kidneys are not working well; your doctor will check your kidney function before and during treatment. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines and supplements you take, because many drugs interact with this regimen, including certain antifungals, antibiotics, anticonvulsants, antidepressants, antipsychotics, hepatitis c antivirals, some heart rhythm drugs, methadone, other hiv medicines, and herbal products such as st. johns wort.if you have or had liver disease, including hepatitis b or c, kidney disease or bone problems, seizures, mental health conditions, or heart rhythm problems. efavirenz can cause nervous system and psychiatric symptoms such as dizziness, abnormal dreams, insomnia, depression, anxiety, and rarely severe mental health problems; contact your doctor right away for severe mood changes or thoughts of selfharm. tdf may cause kidney problems and decrease bone mineral density; your doctor may monitor kidney function and may recommend calcium and vitamin d. efavirenz can reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives; use reliable barrier contraception and discuss pregnancy planning with your doctor. do not stop this medicine without medical advice, especially if you have hbv. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take on an empty stomach, preferably at bedtime. avoid highfat meals near dosing to reduce efavirenz side effects. limit alcohol, which can worsen liver problems and nervous system effects. ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake if recommended by your doctor. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include dizziness, drowsiness, abnormal dreams, insomnia, headache, nausea, diarrhea, rash, and fatigue. other effects can include depression, anxiety, increased cholesterol, skin discoloration on palms or soles, and bone or back pain. serious side effects include severe psychiatric symptoms, severe rash or blistering, liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes and dark urine, kidney problems including decreased urination or bone pain from fanconi syndrome, lactic acidosis, and severe exacerbation of hepatitis b after stopping. seek medical care for serious symptoms.

name: efavirenz, lamivudine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate
text: important warning: severe, potentially lifethreatening lactic acidosis and enlarged fatty liver can occur with nucleostide analogs. seek emergency help for unusual weakness, abdominal pain with nausea and vomiting, trouble breathing, or an irregular heartbeat. if you have hepatitis b virus hbv infection, your hbv may suddenly worsen after you stop this medicine; do not stop without medical advice. your doctor will test you for hbv before starting and will monitor liver function for several months after stopping. this medicine can cause serious liver problems and severe rash; contact your doctor for yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe fatigue, or skin blistering. why is this medication prescribed? this singletablet regimen combines efavirenz, lamivudine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate tdf to treat hiv1 infection in adults and certain adolescents. it lowers the amount of hiv in the body and improves immune function but does not cure hiv. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth once daily as directed, preferably at bedtime on an empty stomach to lessen nervous system side effects from efavirenz. swallow the tablet whole. do not take with other medicines that contain lamivudine or tenofovir disoproxil fumarate. this product is not recommended if your kidneys are not working well; your doctor will check kidney function before and during treatment. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines and supplements you take, as many drugs interact with this regimen, including certain antifungals, antibiotics, anticonvulsants, antidepressants, antipsychotics, hepatitis c antivirals, heart rhythm drugs, methadone, other hiv medicines, and herbal products such as st. johns wort.if you have or had liver disease, including hepatitis b or c, kidney disease or bone problems, seizures, mental health conditions, or heart rhythm issues. efavirenz can cause nervous system and psychiatric symptoms such as dizziness, abnormal dreams, insomnia, depression, anxiety, and rarely severe mental health problems; contact your doctor right away for severe mood changes or thoughts of selfharm. tdf may cause kidney problems and decrease bone mineral density; your doctor may monitor kidney function and may recommend calcium and vitamin d. efavirenz can reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives; use a reliable barrier method and discuss pregnancy planning with your doctor. do not stop this medicine without medical advice, especially if you have hbv. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take on an empty stomach, preferably at bedtime. avoid highfat meals near dosing to reduce efavirenz side effects. limit alcohol to reduce the risk of liver problems and nervous system effects. ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake if recommended. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include dizziness, drowsiness, abnormal dreams, insomnia, headache, nausea, diarrhea, rash, and fatigue. other effects can include depression, anxiety, increased cholesterol, and bone or back pain. serious side effects include severe psychiatric symptoms, severe rash or blistering, liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes and dark urine, kidney problems including decreased urination or bone pain from fanconi syndrome, lactic acidosis, and severe exacerbation of hepatitis b after stopping. seek medical care for serious symptoms.

name: efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? efbemalenograstim alfavuxw is a longacting granulocyte colonystimulating factor used to reduce the risk of infection in people receiving certain chemotherapy that can cause low white blood cell counts neutropenia. it helps the body make more neutrophils. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection by a healthcare professional, typically once per chemotherapy cycle, at least 24 hours after finishing chemotherapy and not within 24 hours before the next chemotherapy. follow your treatment schedule exactly as directed. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to this medicine or to other colonystimulating factors, or if you have had serious reactions to pegfilgrastim or filgrastim.about all medicines and supplements you take, including lithium, which can increase white blood cell production.if you have sickle cell disease, a history of lung problems, kidney disease, or previous spleen issues. this medicine may rarely cause serious problems including splenic rupture, adult respiratory distress syndrome, serious allergic reactions, capillary leak syndrome, inflammation of the kidneys, and aortitis. seek urgent care for left upper abdominal or shoulder pain, trouble breathing, swelling with low blood pressure and dizziness, decreased urination, severe allergic symptoms, or persistent fever. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required unless your doctor gives you other instructions. stay well hydrated during chemotherapy. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your doctors office for instructions if you miss an appointment for your injection. do not try to selfinject unless you have been trained and told to do so. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include bone pain, muscle pain, headache, fatigue, and redness or soreness at the injection site. serious side effects can include allergic reactions with rash, hives, swelling, or trouble breathing, splenic rupture with severe leftsided abdominal or shoulder pain, fever or signs of infection, shortness of breath, rapid weight gain and swelling from capillary leak syndrome, kidney problems, and inflammation of the aorta. contact your doctor for persistent or severe symptoms.

name: efgartigimod alfa and hyaluronidase-qvfc injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? efgartigimod alfa and hyaluronidaseqvfc is used to treat generalized myasthenia gravis in certain adults who test positive for antiacetylcholine receptor antibodies. it reduces pathogenic igg antibodies by blocking the neonatal fc receptor. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection by a healthcare professional, typically once weekly for 4 weeks per treatment cycle. additional cycles may be given based on your symptoms and your doctors assessment. follow the schedule provided by your doctor. what special precautions should i follow?if you have an active infection or a history of recurrent infections, and about all medicines and vaccines you receive. this medicine may increase the risk of infections because it lowers igg levels;right away if you develop fever, cough, burning with urination, or other signs of infection. complete needed vaccines before starting treatment when possible, and avoid live vaccines during treatment; your doctor will advise you when vaccines are appropriate.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. hypersensitivity reactions can occur; seek urgent care for rash, hives, swelling, dizziness, or trouble breathing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary changes are required. maintain good hydration and nutrition as advised by your care team. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your healthcare provider as soon as possible to reschedule a missed injection. do not attempt to administer a dose on your own unless you have been trained and instructed to do so. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include injection site pain, redness, or bruising, headache, respiratory infections, urinary tract infections, fatigue, and nausea. serious side effects can include severe infections and hypersensitivity reactions with swelling or difficulty breathing. call your doctor for severe or persistent symptoms.

name: efgartigimod alfa-fcab injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? efgartigimod alfafcab is used to treat generalized myasthenia gravis in certain adults who are antiacetylcholine receptor antibody positive. it reduces circulating igg antibodies by blocking the neonatal fc receptor. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion by a healthcare professional, typically once weekly for 4 weeks per treatment cycle. additional cycles may be given based on your clinical response and your doctors assessment. each infusion is administered over the period directed by your infusion center. what special precautions should i follow?if you have an active infection or a history of recurrent infections and about all medicines and vaccines you receive. because it can lower igg levels, this medicine may increase infection risk; report fever, cough, burning with urination, or other signs of infection. complete needed immunizations prior to treatment when possible, and avoid live vaccines during treatment; your doctor will advise you on timing of vaccines. hypersensitivity reactions, including during or after infusion, can occur; tell your nurse right away if you develop rash, itching, hives, flushing, dizziness, or trouble breathing.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary changes are needed unless your doctor gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your healthcare provider to reschedule a missed infusion. do not attempt to selfadminister. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include headache, respiratory infections, infusionrelated reactions such as chills or flushing, nausea, and fatigue. serious side effects can include severe infections and hypersensitivity reactions with swelling or breathing difficulty. contact your doctor for severe or persistent symptoms.

name: efinaconazole topical
text: why is this medication prescribed? efinaconazole topical solution is used to treat fungal infection of the toenails onychomycosis caused by certain fungi. how should this medicine be used? apply the solution once daily to affected toenails as directed, usually for 48 weeks. clean and dry the nails and surrounding skin before application. use the provided brush to cover the entire toenail, the toenail folds, the undersurface of the nail tip if possible, and the surrounding skin. allow it to dry completely before putting on socks or shoes. do not use in the eyes, mouth, vagina, or inside the nose, and do not apply to broken or irritated skin. nail polish may be used, but apply the medication first and allow it to dry. use exactly as prescribed and do not stop early even if the nail looks better; full clearing often requires months. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to efinaconazole or any ingredients in the solution.about all your medicines and skin products. inform your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. avoid use on open wounds or severely inflamed skin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no dietary changes are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if you do not remember until the next day, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include application site pain, redness, irritation, peeling, ingrown toenail, and blisters. serious allergic reactions are rare; stop using and seek medical attention for widespread rash, hives, swelling, or trouble breathing.

name: eflornithine
text: why is this medication prescribed? eflornithine topical cream is used to slow the growth of unwanted facial hair in women. it does not remove hair but reduces the rate of new hair growth. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin layer of the cream to the affected areas of the face and under the chin twice daily, at least 8 hours apart, or as directed. clean and dry the skin before application, rub in thoroughly, and wash your hands after applying. allow the cream to dry completely before applying cosmetics or sunscreen. you may continue other hair removal methods; the cream helps slow regrowth over time. it may take 4 to 8 weeks to notice improvement, and continued use is needed to maintain benefit. if no benefit is seen after 6 months, talk to your doctor. do not use in the eyes, inside the nose or mouth, or on broken or irritated skin. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to eflornithine or any ingredients in the cream, and about all medicines and skin products you use.if you have skin conditions in the treatment area, and if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. stop using and contact your doctor if severe irritation occurs. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no dietary changes are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember if it is not close to the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. keep doses at least 8 hours apart and do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include mild burning, stinging, tingling, redness, acne, rash, or hair bumps in the treated areas. serious allergic reactions with hives, swelling, or trouble breathing are rare; stop using and seek medical help if they occur.

name: elacestrant
text: why is this medication prescribed? elacestrant is an oral selective estrogen receptor degrader used to treat adults with estrogen receptor positive and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 negative advanced or metastatic breast cancer that has an esr1 mutation and has progressed after endocrine therapy. how should this medicine be used? take elacestrant exactly as directed by your oncology team, usually once daily at the same time with food. swallow tablets whole with water and do not crush or chew. if you vomit after taking a dose do not take an extra dose and take the next dose at the regular time. your doctor may perform genetic testing to confirm esr1 mutation status before starting. what special precautions should i follow?and pharmacist about all medicines and supplements you take because elacestrant is affected by medicines that change liver enzymes such as certain antibiotics, antifungals, anti seizure drugs, and herbal products like st johns wort. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. use effective contraception during treatment and for a period after the last dose because this medicine can harm an unborn baby. do not breastfeed during treatment and for a period after the last dose as advised by your doctor.if you have liver problems. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food and avoid grapefruit products. there are no other specific diet restrictions unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose and you remember within about 6 hours of your usual time take it as soon as you remember with food. if more than 6 hours have passed skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, fatigue, hot flush, joint or muscle pain, increased cholesterol, and increases in liver enzymes are common. less common side effects include abdominal pain, diarrhea, headache, back pain, and electrolyte changes. seek urgent care for signs of an allergic reaction, severe or persistent vomiting, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, or severe abdominal pain.

name: eladocagene exuparvovec-tneq injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? eladocagene exuparvovec is a gene therapy used to treat patients with aromatic l amino acid decarboxylase deficiency to improve motor function and reduce symptoms such as oculogyric crises. how should this medicine be used? it is a one time treatment administered by a neurosurgeon as a bilateral infusion into specific areas of the brain under general anesthesia. you will receive careful pre procedure assessment and post procedure monitoring in a specialized center. your care team will give medicines to prevent nausea and manage discomfort and will monitor neurologic status and breathing after the procedure. what special precautions should i follow? because this is a neurosurgical procedure there is a risk of bleeding in the brain, infection, seizures, breathing problems, and other surgery related complications. s about all medicines you take including blood thinners and supplements. you may need to avoid certain vaccines around the time of treatment and you may be advised to take or avoid corticosteroids or other medicines to manage inflammation and immune responses.if you have any bleeding disorders, active infection, or breathing problems. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific diet requirements for this treatment. follow the instructions from your surgical team including any fasting instructions before anesthesia and hydration guidance after the procedure. what should i do if i forget a dose? this treatment is given once under medical supervision. if your procedure is postponed or you miss an appointment contact your treatment center to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dyskinesia or increased movements, irritability, insomnia, vomiting, fever, and upper respiratory infections. procedure related risks include headache, brain bleeding, seizures, cerebrospinal fluid leak, and infection. seek urgent care for severe headache, repeated vomiting, confusion, weakness, seizures, fever, or breathing problems.

name: elafibranor
text: why is this medication prescribed? elafibranor is used to treat adults with primary biliary cholangitis who have an inadequate response to or cannot tolerate ursodeoxycholic acid. it can be used with ursodeoxycholic acid or alone. how should this medicine be used? take elafibranor by mouth exactly as prescribed, usually once daily at the same time. swallow tablets whole. your doctor will check your liver tests and kidney function before and during treatment and will adjust therapy as needed. what special precautions should i follow?if you have liver disease, especially cirrhosis or a history of liver decompensation, kidney disease, gallbladder disease, or if you drink alcohol. this medicine can raise liver enzymes, change kidney test results, and may increase the risk of gallbladder events.and pharmacist about all medicines you take including statins, bile acid binding resins, anticoagulants, and fibrates because interactions may require dose adjustments or separation of dosing. if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding discuss risks and contraception. report new or worsening fatigue, abdominal pain, jaundice, dark urine, or severe itching. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific foods you must avoid, but limit alcohol, maintain a liver friendly diet, and follow your doctors advice about vitamin supplementation if you have fat soluble vitamin deficiencies. if you also take a bile acid binding resin take elafibranor at a different time as directed by your doctor. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? itching, abdominal pain or discomfort, diarrhea, nausea, fatigue, headache, and increases in liver or kidney blood tests can occur. gallbladder related problems may happen. call your doctor right away for severe abdominal pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, very dark urine, light colored stools, or swelling in the legs or abdomen.

name: elagolix
text: why is this medication prescribed? elagolix is a gonadotropin releasing hormone antagonist used to manage moderate to severe pain associated with endometriosis. how should this medicine be used? take elagolix by mouth exactly as prescribed, either once daily or twice daily depending on the dose your doctor chooses. treatment duration is limited to reduce bone mineral density loss. swallow tablets whole and take at the same times each day. what special precautions should i follow? do not use elagolix if you are pregnant. use effective nonhormonal contraception during treatment and for at least one week after the last dose.if you have osteoporosis, low bone mineral density, depression or mood disorders, liver disease, or if you take medicines that affect liver enzymes or transporters such as cyclosporine, rifampin, certain antivirals, or strong oatp1b1 inhibitors. elagolix can decrease bone density and may cause mood changes and liver enzyme increases. your doctor may check your bone density and liver tests. seek help right away for thoughts of self harm, severe mood changes, or signs of liver injury such as yellowing of the skin or eyes or dark urine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific diet restrictions. ask your doctor about adequate calcium and vitamin d intake to support bone health. avoid grapefruit products if your doctor advises due to possible interactions. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if you do not remember until the next day skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? hot flush, night sweats, headache, nausea, trouble sleeping, decreased menstrual bleeding or missed periods, mood changes, and joint pain are common. elagolix can decrease bone mineral density. less common effects include liver enzyme elevations. seek urgent care for severe depression, suicidal thoughts, severe abdominal pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or severe allergic reactions such as swelling or trouble breathing.

name: elagolix, estradiol, and norethindrone
text: important warning: this medicine contains estrogen and a progestin and can increase the risk of blood clots, stroke, and heart attack especially in women who smoke, are over 35 years old, have uncontrolled high blood pressure, have certain migraine headaches, or have a history of clotting disorders. it also causes loss of bone mineral density which may not be fully reversible. do not use if you have current or past blood clots, stroke, heart attack, certain cancers, liver disease, or if you are pregnant. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of elagolix with estradiol and norethindrone is used to manage heavy menstrual bleeding due to uterine fibroids in premenopausal women. how should this medicine be used? take this medicine exactly as prescribed, with one capsule in the morning that contains all three medicines and one capsule in the evening that contains elagolix only. take doses at the same times each day with or without food. treatment duration is limited to reduce bone loss, typically not longer than 24 months. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are pregnant. use effective nonhormonal contraception during treatment because estrogen containing contraceptives should not be used with this medicine.if you smoke, have high blood pressure, diabetes, high cholesterol, migraine with aura, liver disease, depression, osteoporosis, or a history of blood clots or stroke.and pharmacist about all medicines and supplements you take including those that affect liver enzymes such as rifampin, certain antifungals, antivirals, and seizure medicines. your doctor may check your blood pressure, bone density, and liver tests before and during treatment. stop the medicine and seek urgent care for chest pain, shortness of breath, one sided weakness, trouble speaking, severe headache, leg swelling or pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or severe mood changes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific diet restrictions. ask your doctor about adequate calcium and vitamin d intake to support bone health. avoid grapefruit products if your doctor advises due to possible interactions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a morning or evening dose and less than about 4 hours have passed, take the missed capsule as soon as you remember. if more than about 4 hours have passed skip the missed capsule and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two capsules at once. what side effects can this medication cause? hot flush, headache, nausea, abdominal pain, irregular bleeding or spotting, decreased menstrual bleeding or missed periods, mood changes, fatigue, and elevated blood pressure can occur. bone mineral density may decrease. less common effects include increases in liver enzymes and gallbladder problems. seek urgent care for symptoms of a blood clot such as chest pain, trouble breathing, sudden severe headache, vision changes, or swelling and pain in a leg.

name: elbasvir and grazoprevir
text: important warning: hepatitis b virus can reactivate in patients who have current or past hepatitis b infection and are treated with medicines for hepatitis c. reactivation can lead to severe liver problems including liver failure and death. your doctor will test you for hepatitis b before starting and will monitor during and after treatment. why is this medication prescribed? elbasvir and grazoprevir are used together in a single tablet to treat chronic hepatitis c virus infection in certain genotypes, usually genotype 1 or 4, in adults and in some adolescents, sometimes with ribavirin depending on resistance testing. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth once daily with or without food for the full course prescribed, usually 12 to 16 weeks. do not miss doses. your doctor may perform resistance testing before treatment and will monitor liver tests during therapy. what special precautions should i follow? do not take this medicine if you have moderate or severe liver impairment, or with certain medicines such as strong inducers of liver enzymes.about all medicines and supplements you take including statins, cyclosporine, certain antivirals, seizure medicines, and herbal products. your doctor will test for hepatitis b infection before starting and will monitor for liver enzyme elevations and signs of hepatitis.if you have any liver disease, kidney disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific foods you must avoid. avoid alcohol to protect your liver. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? headache, fatigue, and nausea are common. increases in liver enzymes can occur and your doctor will monitor for this. when used with ribavirin additional side effects such as anemia and cough may occur. seek urgent care for signs of severe liver problems such as yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe fatigue, or right upper abdominal pain.

name: eletriptan
text: why is this medication prescribed? eletriptan is used for the acute treatment of migraine with or without aura. it does not prevent migraine and should not be used for hemiplegic or basilar migraine. how should this medicine be used? take a dose at the first sign of a migraine as directed, usually 20 or 40 milligrams by mouth. if the headache returns or does not fully resolve you may take a second dose at least 2 hours after the first. do not exceed the maximum daily dose prescribed by your doctor. swallow tablets with water. do not use more than the recommended frequency. what special precautions should i follow? do not use eletriptan if you have coronary artery disease, a history of heart attack or stroke, uncontrolled high blood pressure, peripheral vascular disease, severe liver impairment, or certain heart rhythm problems. do not take within 72 hours of strong inhibitors of cyp3a4 such as certain antifungals, macrolide antibiotics, or protease inhibitors. do not take within 24 hours of another triptan or an ergot type migraine drug.if you smoke, have diabetes, high cholesterol, or a family history of early heart disease. serotonin syndrome can occur especially when used with ssris, snris, or other serotonergic drugs. stop the medicine and seek urgent care for chest pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, one sided weakness, trouble speaking, severe rash, or symptoms of serotonin syndrome such as agitation, fever, or muscle stiffness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions for eletriptan. avoid alcohol if it worsens your migraines. what should i do if i forget a dose? eletriptan is taken as needed for migraine. if your headache returns you may take a second dose at least 2 hours after the first according to your doctors instructions. do not take extra doses if the medicine is not working; call your doctor for advice. what side effects can this medication cause? tingling, dizziness, sleepiness, flushing, dry mouth, nausea, and a feeling of pressure or heaviness in the chest, neck, or jaw can occur. rare but serious heart attack, stroke, or dangerous heart rhythm problems can happen in susceptible patients. seek urgent care for severe chest pain, shortness of breath, sudden severe headache, or neurologic symptoms.

name: elexacaftor, tezacaftor, and ivacaftor
text: why is this medication prescribed? the combination of elexacaftor, tezacaftor, and ivacaftor is used to treat cystic fibrosis in patients who have at least one f508del mutation or other responsive mutations to improve lung function and reduce exacerbations. how should this medicine be used? take the morning dose that contains all three medicines and the evening dose that contains ivacaftor only as prescribed based on age and weight. take each dose with a fat containing meal such as food with butter, cheese, nuts, eggs, or avocado to increase absorption. swallow tablets whole. your doctor may adjust doses if you also take medicines that affect liver enzymes. what special precautions should i follow?if you have liver disease or a history of elevated liver enzymes. your doctor will check liver tests before starting, every 3 months during the first year, and then periodically. eye examinations are recommended in pediatric patients because cataracts have been reported with ivacaftor containing regimens.and pharmacist about all medicines and supplements you take because many drugs interact including strong inducers or inhibitors of cyp3a. avoid grapefruit and seville oranges. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? always take each dose with a fat containing meal or snack. avoid grapefruit juice and seville oranges because they can increase drug levels. maintain good hydration and nutrition as advised for cystic fibrosis. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a morning or evening dose and less than about 6 hours have passed take the missed dose with a fat containing food and then take the next dose at the usual time. if more than about 6 hours have passed skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses close together. what side effects can this medication cause? headache, diarrhea, upper respiratory tract infection, stomach pain, rash, dizziness, and increases in liver enzymes can occur. cataracts have occurred in children. seek medical care for yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe abdominal pain, or signs of an allergic reaction such as rash or trouble breathing.

name: eliglustat
text: why is this medication prescribed? eliglustat is a substrate reduction therapy used to treat adults with gaucher disease type 1 who are appropriate based on cyp2d6 genotype. how should this medicine be used? take eliglustat by mouth exactly as prescribed, usually once or twice daily depending on your cyp2d6 metabolizer status. swallow capsules whole with water and take at the same times each day. your doctor will perform genetic testing before starting and may monitor electrocardiograms and blood levels in certain situations. what special precautions should i follow?about all medical conditions, especially heart disease, arrhythmias, liver or kidney disease, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. do not use eliglustat with certain medicines that strongly inhibit or induce cyp2d6 or cyp3a because dangerous heart rhythm changes can occur at high levels.and pharmacist about all medicines and supplements you take including antidepressants, antifungals, certain antibiotics, antivirals, seizure medicines, and st johns wort. report palpitations, dizziness, fainting, or chest discomfort right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take eliglustat with or without food. avoid grapefruit products which can raise drug levels. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? headache, nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain, heartburn, fatigue, back pain, and palpitations can occur. at high blood levels changes in heart rhythm can occur. seek urgent care for fainting, fast or irregular heartbeat, severe dizziness, or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: elivaldogene autotemcel injection
text: important warning: elivaldogene autotemcel can increase the risk of blood cancers including myelodysplastic syndrome and leukemia. these events have occurred after treatment and can be life threatening or fatal. you will need lifelong monitoring with blood counts and other tests to detect abnormal blood cells or clonal expansion. conditioning chemotherapy used before infusion carries additional serious risks including severe low blood counts, infection, liver veno occlusive disease, seizures, and fertility impairment. why is this medication prescribed? elivaldogene autotemcel is a gene therapy made from your own blood forming stem cells that have been modified to add a working copy of the abcd1 gene. it is used to slow the progression of early active cerebral adrenoleukodystrophy in boys who do not have a matched sibling donor for transplant. how should this medicine be used? you will first receive medicines to move stem cells from your bone marrow into your blood and then undergo apheresis to collect cells. the cells are modified in a manufacturing facility. before infusion you will receive myeloablative conditioning chemotherapy, then the product is infused into a vein in a hospital. you will be monitored in the hospital until blood counts recover and for complications, and will have regular follow up visits for many years. do not donate blood, organs, tissues, or cells in the future. what special precautions should i follow? tell your care team about all medicines and supplements you take. avoid live vaccines before treatment and until your immune system has recovered after therapy as advised by your doctor. you will need seizure prevention during busulfan conditioning and careful dosing with blood level monitoring.if you have liver disease, infections, bleeding problems, or if you are sexually active. discuss sperm banking or fertility preservation before conditioning. use effective contraception as advised because the conditioning drugs can harm an unborn baby. seek immediate care for fever, signs of infection, unusual bruising or bleeding, severe abdominal pain or swelling, yellowing of the skin or eyes, severe headache, seizures, or any new neurologic symptoms. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow instructions from your care team during conditioning and recovery, which may include a neutropenic diet to reduce infection risk and guidance on safe food handling and adequate hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? this therapy is given in a hospital setting as a one time infusion. keep all appointments for preparation, infusion, and follow up. if you miss an appointment contact your care team to reschedule as soon as possible. what side effects can this medication cause? very common effects include low white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets, fever, infection, mouth sores, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, hair loss, and fatigue due to conditioning. liver problems including veno occlusive disease can occur. long term risks include blood cancers. seek urgent care for fever, bleeding, severe mouth or throat pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, seizures, or confusion.

name: elotuzumab injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? elotuzumab is a monoclonal antibody used in combination with other medicines such as lenalidomide and dexamethasone or pomalidomide and dexamethasone to treat adults with multiple myeloma who have received prior therapies. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion on a schedule determined by your oncologist, typically more frequently during the first cycles and then less often. you will be premedicated with medicines such as dexamethasone, an antihistamine, an h2 blocker, and acetaminophen to reduce the risk of infusion reactions. attend all infusion appointments and the laboratory monitoring your care team orders. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines and supplements you take. inform your care team if you have a history of infections or are currently ill. you may be at increased risk of infections; report fevers, cough, shortness of breath, or any signs of infection promptly. do not receive live vaccines during treatment and until your care team says it is safe. if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and contraception; the companion drugs may be harmful to a fetus and require effective contraception. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary requirements for elotuzumab itself; follow nutrition guidance from your oncology team and stay well hydrated unless told otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is administered in a clinic. if you miss an appointment, contact your clinic as soon as possible to reschedule; do not attempt to self-administer. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include infusion reactions with fever, chills, flushing, shortness of breath, or low blood pressure, fatigue, cough, diarrhea or constipation, decreased appetite, and upper respiratory infections. it can lower certain blood counts and increase infection risk. serious reactions include severe infusion reactions, pneumonia, liver test abnormalities, and rare severe hypersensitivity; seek urgent care for trouble breathing, severe dizziness, or signs of severe allergic reaction.

name: elranatamab-bcmm
text: important warning: elranatamab can cause cytokine release syndrome and serious neurologic toxicity including immune effector cell-associated neurotoxicity syndrome, which can be severe or life-threatening. you will receive step-up dosing and premedications to lower this risk, and you will be monitored closely after early doses. seek emergency help for fever, chills, rapid heartbeat, dizziness, lightheadedness, low blood pressure, difficulty breathing, confusion, severe headache, tremor, seizures, slurred speech, or difficulty staying awake. do not drive or operate heavy machinery for at least 48 hours after each dose in the step-up phase or if you have neurologic symptoms. why is this medication prescribed? elranatamab-bcmm is a bispecific antibody used to treat adults with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who have received multiple prior lines of therapy. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection by a healthcare professional with a step-up dosing schedule followed by regular maintenance dosing, which may be adjusted based on your response and tolerability. you will receive premedications such as corticosteroids, antihistamines, and antipyretics before initial doses. keep all appointments and lab checks. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines you take and any history of neurologic conditions, seizures, or infections. you are at increased risk of infections; report fever, cough, sore throat, painful urination, or other signs of infection promptly and you may receive antimicrobial prophylaxis per your teams guidance. vaccinations with live vaccines should be avoided during treatment. use effective contraception during treatment and for the time recommended after the last dose; discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding with your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required; maintain good hydration unless otherwise instructed. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is administered by your care team. if you miss an appointment, contact your clinic immediately to arrange the next dose; dosing may need to be adjusted depending on the length of the delay. what side effects can this medication cause? in addition to cytokine release syndrome and neurologic events, common side effects include fatigue, fever, injection site reactions, diarrhea, nausea, decreased appetite, cough, muscle or joint pain, and swelling. laboratory abnormalities and low blood counts can occur, increasing the risk of infection and bleeding. serious infections, liver enzyme elevations, and hypersensitivity can occur.

name: eltrombopag
text: important warning: eltrombopag can cause liver problems and, in people with chronic hepatitis c receiving interferon-based therapy, can increase the risk of hepatic decompensation. it has also been associated with thromboembolic events when platelet counts rise excessively. liver function must be monitored regularly and dosing adjusted carefully to the lowest dose that maintains a safe platelet count. contact your clinician immediately for yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, right upper abdominal pain, unusual swelling, sudden shortness of breath, chest pain, severe headache, weakness on one side, or vision changes. why is this medication prescribed? eltrombopag increases platelet production and is used to treat chronic immune thrombocytopenia when other treatments have not worked well, severe aplastic anemia, and thrombocytopenia in certain patients with hepatitis c to allow antiviral therapy. how should this medicine be used? take it by mouth exactly as directed, usually once daily. take it on an empty stomach, either 1 hour before or 2 hours after a meal. do not take it within 4 hours of products containing polyvalent cations such as antacids or supplements with iron, calcium, magnesium, aluminum, selenium, or zinc, or dairy products and calcium-fortified juices, because they reduce absorption. your dose will be adjusted based on platelet counts and liver tests. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines and supplements you use. inform your clinician if you have liver disease, a history of blood clots, cataracts, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. use effective contraception during treatment. eye exams may be recommended for cataracts. this medicine is not used to normalize platelet counts; it is used to reduce bleeding risk. keep all lab appointments for platelet and liver monitoring. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take on an empty stomach and separate by at least 4 hours from dairy and mineral-containing antacids or supplements. otherwise follow your clinicians dietary advice for your condition. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. if you miss more than one dose, contact your clinician for guidance. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, diarrhea, fatigue, headache, muscle aches, and liver enzyme elevations. it can cause cataracts, increased bone marrow reticulin, and blood clots including deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. serious liver problems can occur; report jaundice, dark urine, severe abdominal pain, or unusual bleeding or bruising.

name: eluxadoline
text: why is this medication prescribed? eluxadoline is used to treat irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea in adults. how should this medicine be used? take it by mouth twice daily with food, exactly as prescribed. your dose may be reduced in certain situations such as mild to moderate liver impairment or when taken with certain interacting medicines. what special precautions should i follow? do not use eluxadoline if you do not have a gallbladder, if you have a history of pancreatitis, biliary duct obstruction, sphincter of oddi disease or dysfunction, severe liver impairment, known or suspected intestinal obstruction, or if you consume more than three alcoholic drinks per day.about all medicines you take, especially other drugs that can cause constipation or slow the gut, opioids, or strong oatp1b1 inhibitors. stop the medicine and seek medical help right away if you develop new or worsening upper abdominal pain that may radiate to the back or shoulder, with or without nausea and vomiting, as this may indicate pancreatitis or sphincter of oddi spasm. if you develop severe constipation lasting more than 4 days, stop the drug and contact your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take doses with food. follow your clinicians advice for an ibs-friendly diet such as a trial of low fodmap eating, limiting alcohol, caffeine, and high-fat foods, and maintaining adequate hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the next dose at the regularly scheduled time; do not double up to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, constipation, abdominal pain, vomiting, and gas. serious risks include pancreatitis, spasm of the sphincter of oddi, increased liver enzymes, and severe constipation; seek immediate care for severe or persistent abdominal pain, especially if associated with nausea or vomiting.

name: elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir alafenamide
text: important warning: severe acute exacerbations of hepatitis b have been reported in patients who are coinfected with hbv and hiv-1 and who have discontinued this medicine. test for hbv infection before starting, and if you have hbv, close monitoring of liver function and hbv management is needed if the medicine is stopped. do not stop taking this medicine without talking to your clinician. why is this medication prescribed? this fixed-dose combination, often known by the brand genvoya, is used to treat hiv-1 infection in adults and certain pediatric patients. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth once daily with food. take it at the same time each day and do not skip doses. do not use with other antiretrovirals unless directed by your hiv specialist. your clinician will check kidney and liver function and viral load regularly. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider about all medicines and supplements. because cobicistat strongly affects cyp3a, many drugs are contraindicated or require dose adjustments, including certain anticonvulsants, rifamycins, st johns wort, certain statins, ergot derivatives, some sedatives, and others. do not use for pre-exposure prophylaxis. inform your clinician if you have kidney or liver disease, osteoporosis or risk for fractures, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. do not stop this medicine without medical guidance because viral rebound and hbv flares can occur. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food to ensure proper absorption. maintain adequate calcium and vitamin d intake for bone health as advised by your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember that day with food. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. if you vomit within 1 hour of taking a dose, take another tablet; if more than 1 hour has passed, do not take an extra dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, diarrhea, headache, and fatigue. it can cause increases in cholesterol, weight gain, and rare kidney or liver problems. serious side effects include lactic acidosis and severe hepatomegaly with steatosis, although uncommon with this regimen, and severe drug interactions; seek medical help for persistent nausea or vomiting, abdominal pain, unusual muscle pain, rapid breathing, jaundice, dark urine, or severe rash.

name: elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate
text: important warning: severe acute exacerbations of hepatitis b have been reported in patients who are coinfected with hbv and hiv-1 and who have discontinued this medicine. nucleoside analogs have also been associated with lactic acidosis and severe hepatomegaly with steatosis, including fatal cases. test for hbv infection before starting, monitor hepatic function if the medicine is stopped, and seek urgent care for symptoms such as persistent nausea or vomiting, abdominal pain, unusual fatigue, shortness of breath, or jaundice. why is this medication prescribed? this fixed-dose combination, often known by the brand stribild, is used to treat hiv-1 infection in adults and certain adolescents with adequate renal function. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth once daily with food. take it at the same time each day. do not use with other antiretrovirals unless directed by your hiv specialist. your clinician will monitor kidney function, liver tests, bone health, and viral load regularly; this regimen should not be started or continued in patients with reduced kidney function as directed by current guidelines. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider about all medicines and supplements. cobicistat has many drug interactions via cyp3a; certain anticonvulsants, rifamycins, st johns wort, certain statins, ergot derivatives, and some sedatives are contraindicated. avoid nephrotoxic drugs if possible and tell your clinician if you develop bone pain, fractures, or symptoms of kidney problems such as increased urination or thirst. do not stop this medicine without medical guidance due to risk of viral rebound and hbv flares. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and alternatives. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food to ensure proper absorption. ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake for bone health as recommended by your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember that day with food. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. if you vomit within 1 hour of taking a dose, take another tablet; if more than 1 hour has passed, do not take an extra dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, diarrhea, headache, and fatigue. it can cause kidney problems including proximal tubulopathy, decreases in bone mineral density, and increases in liver enzymes. serious side effects include lactic acidosis and severe hepatomegaly with steatosis and severe drug interactions; seek medical help for shortness of breath, rapid breathing, persistent abdominal pain, severe weakness, jaundice, dark urine, or severe rash.

name: emapalumab-lzsg injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? emapalumab-lzsg is a monoclonal antibody that blocks interferon gamma and is used to treat primary hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis in patients with refractory, recurrent, or progressive disease or intolerance to conventional therapy. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion in a clinic or hospital, typically twice weekly, with dose adjustments based on clinical response and drug levels. you will have frequent blood tests to monitor for effectiveness and safety. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. you are at increased risk for serious infections and reactivation of latent infections including tuberculosis; you will be screened for latent tb and may receive antimicrobial prophylaxis. report fever, cough, shortness of breath, painful urination, severe diarrhea, or other signs of infection right away. do not receive live vaccines during treatment and until your care team says it is safe. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and the need for effective contraception during treatment and for a period after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions; maintain adequate hydration and follow any nutrition advice from your care team. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is administered in a healthcare setting. if you miss an appointment, contact your clinic promptly to reschedule; do not attempt to self-administer. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include infusion-related reactions such as fever, chills, flushing, or low blood pressure, infections including viral reactivation, diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, elevated liver enzymes, high blood pressure, low blood counts, and rash. serious infections, hypersensitivity reactions, and liver problems can occur; seek immediate care for severe reactions or signs of infection.

name: emicizumab-kxwh injection
