text: why is this medication prescribed? cefotaxime is a third generation cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat serious infections such as lower respiratory tract infections, septicemia, skin and soft tissue infections, bone and joint infections, urinary tract infections, gynecologic and intra abdominal infections, and meningitis. it may also be used for surgical prophylaxis. how should this medicine be used? cefotaxime is given by intravenous or intramuscular injection by a healthcare professional, often every 6 to 8 hours. the dose depends on the infection and kidney function. complete the full prescribed course. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cefotaxime, other cephalosporins, or penicillins.if you have kidney disease, a history of seizures, or have had severe diarrhea with antibiotics. cefotaxime can cause severe allergic reactions and clostridioides difficile associated diarrhea.about all medicines you take.if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a scheduled dose administered in a clinic or by home infusion, contact your healthcare provider promptly to reschedule. do not give two doses at the same time unless directed. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include pain or inflammation at the injection site, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, rash, and changes in blood counts such as eosinophilia. serious side effects include severe allergic reaction, severe or persistent diarrhea, seizures especially in people with kidney problems or underlying seizure disorders, liver problems, and low white blood cell or platelet counts.

name: cefotetan injection
text: important warning: cefotetan can affect blood clotting and increase the risk of bleeding, particularly in people with poor nutrition, kidney or liver disease, or those taking blood thinners. your doctor may monitor your prothrombin time and give vitamin k if needed. cefotetan can also cause a reaction with alcohol that leads to flushing, headache, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, breathing difficulty, and low blood pressure. avoid alcoholic drinks and alcohol containing products during treatment and for at least 72 hours after the last dose. why is this medication prescribed? cefotetan is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat susceptible infections such as intra abdominal and gynecologic infections, skin and soft tissue infections, bone and joint infections, lower respiratory tract infections, urinary tract infections, and for surgical prophylaxis especially in colorectal and gynecologic surgery. how should this medicine be used? cefotetan is given by intravenous or intramuscular injection by a healthcare professional, usually every 12 hours. the dose depends on the infection and kidney function. complete the full prescribed course. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cefotetan, other cephalosporins, or penicillins.if you have a bleeding disorder, are taking anticoagulants, have kidney or liver disease, are malnourished, or have had severe diarrhea with antibiotics. cefotetan can cause severe allergic reactions and clostridioides difficile associated diarrhea. avoid alcohol during treatment and for 72 hours after the last dose.if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not consume alcohol or alcohol containing products during therapy and for 72 hours after the last dose. otherwise there are no specific dietary restrictions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a scheduled dose administered in a clinic or by home infusion, contact your healthcare provider to reschedule. do not administer two doses at the same time unless directed. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include pain or inflammation at the injection site, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and rash. serious side effects include bleeding or easy bruising, severe allergic reaction, severe or persistent diarrhea, liver problems, and blood disorders including hemolytic anemia.

name: cefoxitin injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? cefoxitin is a cephamycin antibiotic related to cephalosporins used to treat susceptible infections such as intra abdominal and gynecologic infections, septicemia, lower respiratory tract infections, skin and soft tissue infections, bone and joint infections, urinary tract infections, and for surgical prophylaxis especially in colorectal surgery. how should this medicine be used? cefoxitin is given by intravenous or intramuscular injection by a healthcare professional, typically every 6 to 8 hours. the dose depends on the infection and kidney function. complete the full prescribed course. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cefoxitin, other cephalosporins, or penicillins.if you have kidney disease, a history of colitis, or if you are taking blood thinners. cefoxitin can cause severe allergic reactions and clostridioides difficile associated diarrhea.about all medicines you take.if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a scheduled dose administered in a clinic or by home infusion, contact your healthcare provider promptly to reschedule. do not give two doses at the same time unless directed. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include pain or inflammation at the injection site, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, rash, and changes in blood counts. serious side effects include severe allergic reaction, severe or persistent diarrhea, liver problems, kidney problems especially when combined with other nephrotoxic medicines, and hemolytic anemia.

name: cefpodoxime
text: why is this medication prescribed? cefpodoxime is a third generation oral cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat susceptible infections such as community acquired pneumonia, sinus infections, flare ups of chronic bronchitis, strep throat and tonsillitis, skin and soft tissue infections, ear infections in children, uncomplicated urinary tract infections, and certain sexually transmitted infections. how should this medicine be used? take cefpodoxime tablets or oral suspension by mouth exactly as directed, usually every 12 hours. take each dose with food to improve absorption. shake the suspension well and measure with a proper device. avoid taking antacids or acid reducing medicines close to the time you take cefpodoxime because they can reduce absorption. if you have reduced kidney function your dose may need adjustment. complete the full prescribed course. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cefpodoxime, other cephalosporins, or penicillins.if you have kidney disease, a history of colitis, or if you take blood thinners. cefpodoxime can cause severe allergic reactions and clostridioides difficile associated diarrhea.if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take cefpodoxime with food. avoid taking antacids or h2 receptor blockers within a couple of hours of your dose to prevent reduced absorption. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your usual schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, headache, and rash. serious side effects include severe allergic reaction, severe or persistent diarrhea that may be watery or bloody, liver problems, and blood disorders including low white blood cell counts.

name: cefprozil
text: why is this medication prescribed? cefprozil is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections such as ear infections, sinusitis, throat infections, bronchitis, skin infections, and some urinary tract infections. it will not treat viral infections like colds or flu. how should this medicine be used? take cefprozil exactly as prescribed, usually by mouth once or twice daily. it may be taken with or without food; taking it with food can reduce stomach upset. shake the oral suspension well before each dose and measure with a dosing device. take doses at evenly spaced times and complete the full course even if you feel better. what special precautions should i follow?if you have ever had an allergic reaction to cefprozil, other cephalosporins, penicillins, or other beta lactam antibiotics.if you have kidney disease, a history of colitis or severe diarrhea with antibiotics, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. cefprozil may interact with probenecid and may affect blood thinning in people taking warfarin; your doctor may monitor your blood tests. it can cause a positive coombs test and may affect certain urine glucose tests. stop the medicine and seek care right away if you develop signs of a severe allergic reaction such as rash, swelling, or trouble breathing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. if the medicine upsets your stomach, take it with food. stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, headache, and rash. yeast infections can occur. serious effects that need medical attention include severe watery or bloody diarrhea even weeks after finishing, yellowing of the skin or eyes, unusual bleeding or bruising, severe skin reaction, seizures in people with significant kidney problems, and signs of an allergic reaction.

name: ceftaroline injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? ceftaroline is a cephalosporin antibiotic given by vein to treat community acquired bacterial pneumonia and acute bacterial skin and skin structure infections, including those caused by methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion by a healthcare professional, typically every twelve hours. if you are receiving it at home, use it exactly as trained, infuse over the instructed time, use aseptic technique, and do not reuse leftover solution or equipment. complete the full course. dose adjustments may be needed if you have decreased kidney function. what special precautions should i follow?about any allergy to cephalosporins, penicillins, or other beta lactam antibiotics.if you have kidney disease, a history of seizures, anemia, or prior antibiotic associated colitis. prolonged use can lead to overgrowth of nonsusceptible organisms. ceftaroline can cause a positive coombs test and rarely hemolytic anemia; report unusual tiredness, pale skin, or dark urine. seek urgent care for signs of severe allergic reaction such as hives, swelling, or trouble breathing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary changes are required. maintain adequate fluid intake. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion, contact your healthcare provider as soon as possible to reschedule. do not administer extra doses without medical advice. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, rash, itching, headache, and infusion site reactions. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, severe skin reactions, severe or persistent diarrhea which may indicate c difficile infection, hemolytic anemia, low white blood cell count with prolonged therapy, liver test abnormalities, and seizures especially in people with kidney impairment.

name: ceftazidime and avibactam injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? ceftazidime and avibactam is an intravenous antibiotic combination used to treat complicated urinary tract infections including kidney infection, complicated intra abdominal infections usually given with metronidazole, and hospital acquired and ventilator associated bacterial pneumonia caused by susceptible bacteria, including some resistant gram negative organisms. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion over a set period of time by a healthcare professional, usually every eight hours. if you are instructed to infuse at home, follow the training exactly, keep supplies sterile, and complete the full course. dose adjustments are required in reduced kidney function. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cephalosporins, penicillins, or other beta lactam antibiotics.if you have kidney disease, a history of seizures, or previous severe diarrhea with antibiotics. this medicine can cause a positive coombs test, may rarely cause hemolytic anemia, and can increase liver enzymes. probenecid and other medicines may affect antibiotic levels; blood thinners such as warfarin may require closer monitoring. seek immediate care for signs of severe allergic reaction or severe diarrhea. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. drink adequate fluids unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion, contact your healthcare provider right away to arrange the next dose. do not double up doses. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, headache, and infusion site reactions. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, severe or persistent diarrhea which may indicate c difficile infection, liver problems, changes in blood counts, and seizures or confusion especially in people with kidney impairment.

name: ceftazidime injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? ceftazidime is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat serious bacterial infections such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, skin and soft tissue infections, abdominal infections, bone and joint infections, bloodstream infections, and meningitis, including those caused by pseudomonas aeruginosa. how should this medicine be used? it is administered by intravenous infusion or intramuscular injection by a healthcare professional at regular intervals. if you receive it at home, infuse exactly as taught, keep everything sterile, and finish the prescribed course. your dose may need adjustment if you have kidney problems. what special precautions should i follow? inform your doctor if you are allergic to cephalosporins, penicillins, or other beta lactam antibiotics.if you have kidney disease, a history of seizures, or prior severe diarrhea with antibiotics. ceftazidime can cause neurotoxicity such as confusion, myoclonus, or seizures especially in kidney impairment or with high doses. it may cause a positive coombs test and rarely hemolytic anemia. warfarin and similar medicines may need closer monitoring. seek urgent care for signs of severe allergic reaction. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. maintain adequate hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your healthcare provider promptly to reschedule a missed dose. do not administer extra doses without advice. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, rash, and pain or redness at the injection site. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, severe or persistent diarrhea which may indicate c difficile infection, liver test abnormalities, changes in blood counts, kidney problems, and neurologic symptoms such as confusion or seizures.

name: ceftibuten
text: why is this medication prescribed? ceftibuten is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections such as bronchitis, ear infections, throat infections, and uncomplicated urinary tract infections. it does not treat viral infections. how should this medicine be used? take ceftibuten by mouth exactly as directed, usually once daily. take it on an empty stomach at least two hours after a meal or one hour before a meal because food decreases absorption. shake the oral suspension well and measure with a dosing device. store the mixed suspension in the refrigerator and discard after fourteen days. complete the full course. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cephalosporins, penicillins, or other beta lactam antibiotics.if you have kidney disease, a history of antibiotic associated colitis, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. separate from antacids by at least two hours. probenecid can increase antibiotic levels, and warfarin may require closer monitoring. ceftibuten may affect certain urine glucose tests. seek immediate care for signs of severe allergic reaction. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take on an empty stomach. if stomach upset occurs, discuss with your doctor, but avoid taking it with food unless your clinician advises otherwise. stay hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, headache, and rash. serious effects include severe watery or bloody diarrhea which may indicate c difficile infection, severe allergic reactions, yellowing of the skin or eyes, unusual bleeding or bruising, and seizures in people with significant kidney impairment.

name: ceftolozane and tazobactam injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? ceftolozane and tazobactam is an intravenous antibiotic combination used to treat complicated urinary tract infections including kidney infection, complicated intra abdominal infections usually with metronidazole, and hospital acquired and ventilator associated bacterial pneumonia caused by susceptible bacteria, including resistant gram negative organisms. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion over about one hour by a healthcare professional at scheduled intervals. higher doses are used for hospital and ventilator acquired pneumonia. if you infuse at home, follow your training exactly, keep supplies sterile, and complete the full course. dose adjustments are required in reduced kidney function. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cephalosporins, penicillins, or other beta lactam antibiotics.if you have kidney disease or a history of seizures or severe antibiotic associated colitis. this product contains sodium, which may be important if you are on a sodium restricted diet or have heart failure. probenecid and other medicines can affect levels of the beta lactamase inhibitor. blood thinners like warfarin may require closer monitoring. seek urgent care for signs of severe allergic reaction or severe diarrhea. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. maintain adequate fluid intake. if you are on a sodium restricted diet, discuss your total sodium intake with your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion, contact your healthcare provider as soon as possible to arrange dosing. do not take extra doses without advice. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, headache, fever, and infusion site reactions. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, severe or persistent diarrhea which may indicate c difficile infection, liver enzyme elevations, low or high potassium, kidney problems, and seizures especially in people with kidney impairment.

name: ceftriaxone injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? ceftriaxone is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat many bacterial infections such as pneumonia, ear infections, skin and soft tissue infections, urinary tract infections, abdominal infections, bone and joint infections, bloodstream infections, meningitis, and gonorrhea, and it may be given before surgery to prevent infection. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion or intramuscular injection by a healthcare professional, often once daily. if you receive it outside a clinic, use exactly as trained and complete the full course. do not mix or infuse with calcium containing solutions in the same line at the same time. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cephalosporins, penicillins, or other beta lactam antibiotics.if you have kidney or liver disease, gallbladder disease, a history of severe diarrhea with antibiotics, or anemia. ceftriaxone can cause biliary sludge and gallbladder complications and rarely pancreatitis; report right upper abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. it can cause a positive coombs test and rarely hemolytic anemia; report unusual fatigue, pale skin, or dark urine. in newborns, particularly those with high bilirubin, ceftriaxone may be unsafe; special precautions apply in that age group. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. maintain good hydration unless otherwise instructed. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your healthcare provider promptly to reschedule a missed injection. do not take extra doses without advice. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include pain or soreness at the injection site, diarrhea, nausea, rash, and changes in blood counts. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, severe or persistent diarrhea which may indicate c difficile infection, gallbladder sludge or stones with abdominal pain, pancreatitis, hemolytic anemia, kidney problems, and severe skin reactions.

name: cefuroxime
text: why is this medication prescribed? cefuroxime is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections such as bronchitis, sinusitis, ear infections, throat infections, skin infections, uncomplicated urinary tract infections, and early lyme disease. how should this medicine be used? take cefuroxime by mouth exactly as directed, usually twice daily. take tablets with food to improve absorption. the oral suspension should also be taken with food, shaken well, and measured with a dosing device. do not substitute tablets and suspension milligram for milligram because they have different absorption; follow the specific form prescribed. complete the full course. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cephalosporins, penicillins, or other beta lactam antibiotics.if you have kidney disease, a history of severe diarrhea with antibiotics, or stomach or intestinal disease. separate doses from antacids or acid reducing medicines if possible since they may reduce absorption. probenecid can increase cefuroxime levels and warfarin may require closer monitoring. cefuroxime can affect certain urine glucose tests and can cause a positive coombs test. seek immediate care for signs of severe allergic reaction. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food. if stomach upset occurs, continue taking with meals and water. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, headache, and a bad or metallic taste. serious effects include severe watery or bloody diarrhea which may indicate c difficile infection, severe allergic reactions, yellowing of the skin or eyes, unusual bleeding or bruising, seizures in people with significant kidney problems, and severe skin reactions.

name: cefuroxime injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? cefuroxime injection is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat serious infections including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, skin and soft tissue infections, abdominal infections, bone and joint infections, bloodstream infections, and meningitis. how should this medicine be used? it is administered by intravenous infusion or intramuscular injection by a healthcare professional at scheduled intervals. if receiving therapy at home, use exactly as trained, keep supplies sterile, and complete the full course. dose adjustments may be needed in kidney impairment. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cephalosporins, penicillins, or other beta lactam antibiotics.if you have kidney disease, a history of seizures, or prior severe diarrhea with antibiotics. prolonged use may result in overgrowth of nonsusceptible organisms. cefuroxime can cause a positive coombs test and rarely hemolytic anemia. blood thinners such as warfarin may need closer monitoring. seek urgent care for signs of severe allergic reaction. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. maintain adequate hydration unless otherwise instructed. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your healthcare provider promptly to reschedule a missed dose. do not take extra doses without advice. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, rash, and pain or redness at the injection site. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, severe or persistent diarrhea which may indicate c difficile infection, liver test abnormalities, changes in blood counts, seizures especially in people with kidney impairment, and severe skin reactions.

name: celecoxib
text: important warning: nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs including celecoxib increase the risk of serious cardiovascular events such as heart attack and stroke which can be fatal. this risk may occur early and may increase with duration of use. celecoxib also increases the risk of serious gastrointestinal bleeding, ulceration, and perforation of the stomach or intestines which can be fatal and may occur without warning symptoms. do not use celecoxib right before or after heart bypass surgery. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration needed. why is this medication prescribed? celecoxib is a nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drug that reduces pain and inflammation. it is used for osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis including juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, acute pain, and menstrual pain. how should this medicine be used? take celecoxib exactly as prescribed, usually once or twice daily. it may be taken with or without food. swallow capsules whole; if you have trouble swallowing, some capsule strengths can be opened and sprinkled on applesauce and taken right away. do not take more than prescribed. what special precautions should i follow?if you have ever had heart disease, stroke, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, smoking history, stomach or intestinal bleeding or ulcers, liver or kidney disease, asthma especially with aspirin sensitivity, fluid retention or heart failure, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. avoid use after twenty weeks of pregnancy and especially in the third trimester due to risks to the fetus. do not take if you have had an allergic reaction to celecoxib, sulfonamides, aspirin, or other nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs.about all medicines you take because interactions are common, including with blood thinners such as warfarin, antiplatelet medicines, other nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs including over the counter products, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, blood pressure medicines such as ace inhibitors, arbs, and diuretics, lithium, methotrexate, and medicines that affect cyp2c9 such as fluconazole or rifampin. your doctor may adjust your dose if you are a poor metabolizer of cyp2c9. stop the medicine and seek care right away if you have chest pain, shortness of breath, weakness on one side of the body, slurred speech, black or bloody stools, vomit that looks like coffee grounds, severe stomach pain, swelling of the face or throat, severe skin rash, or little or no urine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take celecoxib with or without food. if stomach upset occurs, take it with food. limit alcohol as it can increase stomach irritation and bleeding risk. maintain adequate hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include stomach pain, indigestion, diarrhea, gas, headache, dizziness, and swelling of the hands or feet. serious effects include heart attack, stroke, new or worsening high blood pressure, heart failure with shortness of breath or sudden weight gain, gastrointestinal bleeding or ulcers, liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes or dark urine, kidney problems with decreased urination, severe skin reactions such as stevens johnson syndrome, and severe allergic reactions.

name: cemiplimab-rwlc injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? cemiplimab is used to treat certain cancers including cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma that has spread or cannot be treated with surgery or radiation, some cases of basal cell carcinoma after treatment with a hedgehog pathway inhibitor, and some cases of non small cell lung cancer that express pd 1 ligand. it works by helping your immune system recognize and attack cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? cemiplimab is given as an intravenous infusion by a health care professional, usually over about 30 minutes every 3 weeks. your dosing schedule and length of treatment depend on your condition, how you respond, and side effects. keep all appointments for infusions and lab tests. what special precautions should i follow?if you have or have ever had an autoimmune disease, a lung transplant or other organ transplant, lung problems, liver problems including hepatitis b or c, kidney problems, diabetes, a nervous system disorder, or if you have ever had an infusion reaction to another immune therapy. cemiplimab can cause your immune system to attack normal organs and tissues, which can be serious or life threatening and can occur during treatment or after it ends. call your doctor right away if you develop new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, diarrhea, severe abdominal pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe nausea or vomiting, unusual fatigue, severe headache, vision changes, confusion, dizziness, fainting, significant weight changes, increased thirst or urination, rash, itching, muscle or joint pain, or decreased urine.about all medicines and supplements you use. do not receive live vaccines during treatment. cemiplimab can harm an unborn baby. use effective birth control during treatment and for at least 4 months after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for at least 4 months after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your doctor or infusion center as soon as you remember to reschedule. do not try to make up a missed infusion on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fatigue, rash or itching, diarrhea, nausea, decreased appetite, cough, and muscle or joint pain. serious effects can include inflammation of the lungs, colon, liver, kidneys, hormone producing glands such as thyroid, pituitary, and adrenal glands, and the pancreas which may cause diabetes, severe skin reactions, infusion reactions, and rejection of transplanted organs. seek urgent care for symptoms of severe or rapidly worsening side effects.

name: cenegermin-bkbj ophthalmic
text: why is this medication prescribed? cenegermin eye drops are used to treat neurotrophic keratitis, a rare disease in which the cornea does not heal properly due to nerve damage. how should this medicine be used? use one drop in the affected eye or eyes six times each day at two hour intervals for 8 weeks, or as directed. this medicine comes in single use vials prepared in a daily treatment pack. store vials in the refrigerator in the original carton. when a vial is opened for the day, keep it at room temperature protected from light and discard any remaining solution 12 hours after first opening. wash hands before use. do not let the dropper tip touch your eye or any surface. if you wear contact lenses, remove them before using the drops and wait at least 15 minutes before reinserting. what special precautions should i follow?if you have any eye infections, if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. use exactly as prescribed and do not use if the solution is cloudy, discolored, or contains particles. avoid driving or operating machinery until your vision is clear after each dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? instill the missed dose as soon as you remember, then take the next doses at the usual times. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include eye pain or discomfort, redness, increased tearing, feeling like something is in the eye, eyelid pain, and blurred vision. contact your doctor for signs of infection such as worsening redness, swelling, discharge, fever, severe eye pain, or sudden changes in vision.

name: cenobamate
text: important warning: cenobamate can cause a serious and potentially life threatening drug reaction called dress which can involve fever, rash, swollen lymph nodes, and injury to organs such as the liver, kidneys, lungs, heart, or blood cells. this reaction usually occurs within 2 to 8 weeks after starting treatment. seek immediate medical care if you develop rash, fever, swollen glands, flu like symptoms, unusual bruising or bleeding, persistent cough, shortness of breath, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe fatigue, chest pain, or a fast or irregular heartbeat. cenobamate can also shorten the qt interval on the electrocardiogram and may not be appropriate for people with short qt syndrome. why is this medication prescribed? cenobamate is used to treat partial onset seizures in adults. how should this medicine be used? take cenobamate by mouth once daily exactly as directed. it must be started at a low dose and increased slowly over several weeks to reduce the risk of serious reactions. do not start, stop, or change your dose without your doctors guidance. swallow tablets whole with or without food. do not stop this medicine suddenly because this may increase the risk of seizures. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines you take because cenobamate can interact with many medicines, including increasing levels of phenytoin and phenobarbital and reducing the effectiveness of some medicines such as hormonal birth control. use a non hormonal form of birth control while taking cenobamate and for some time after your last dose.if you have heart rhythm problems, liver disease, or kidney disease. avoid alcohol and other medicines that cause drowsiness unless your doctor approves. cenobamate may cause dizziness and sleepiness. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. report mood changes, new or worsening depression, or thoughts about self harm to your doctor right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take cenobamate with or without food. avoid alcohol. maintain a consistent routine and stay hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. do not take two doses at the same time. if you miss more than one day of doses, contact your doctor because you may need to restart at a lower dose and retitrate. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dizziness, sleepiness, fatigue, headache, nausea, vomiting, problems with coordination or balance, double vision, and sleep disturbance. serious effects include dress, severe allergic reactions, changes in heart rhythm due to qt shortening, suicidal thoughts or behavior, and severe skin reactions. seek urgent care for signs of severe reaction or heart rhythm problems such as fainting or a fast or irregular pulse.

name: cephalexin
text: why is this medication prescribed? cephalexin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections such as infections of the skin, ears, respiratory tract, bone, and urinary tract. it will not work for colds, flu, or other viral infections. how should this medicine be used? take cephalexin by mouth exactly as directed, with or without food. if it upsets your stomach, take it with food. take it at evenly spaced times and complete the full course even if you feel better. measure liquid carefully with a dosing device. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cephalosporins, penicillins, or any medicine, and if you have kidney disease, a history of intestinal disease such as colitis, or are pregnant or breastfeeding.about all medicines you take. cephalexin can interact with medicines such as warfarin, metformin, and probenecid. call your doctor if you develop severe or persistent diarrhea, watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or signs of an allergic reaction such as hives, swelling, or trouble breathing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet and drink plenty of fluids. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, stomach upset, and rash. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, severe diarrhea due to clostridioides difficile, seizures especially in people with kidney problems or very high doses, and unusual bleeding or bruising. seek medical help for severe or concerning symptoms.

name: ceritinib
text: why is this medication prescribed? ceritinib is used to treat metastatic non small cell lung cancer that tests positive for an abnormal alk gene. it helps stop cancer cell growth. how should this medicine be used? take ceritinib by mouth once daily with food, usually 450 mg once daily, or exactly as your doctor prescribes. swallow tablets whole and take at the same time each day. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose. take the next dose at the usual time. what special precautions should i follow?if you have liver disease, pancreas problems, diabetes, slow heartbeat, heart rhythm problems, low potassium or magnesium, lung disease, or gastrointestinal problems. ceritinib can cause serious liver injury, pancreatitis, high blood sugar, slow heartbeat, heart rhythm changes, and lung inflammation. your doctor will monitor blood tests and your heart rhythm.about all medicines and supplements you take. avoid strong inhibitors or inducers of cyp3a if possible. use effective birth control during treatment and for a period after the last dose because this medicine can harm an unborn baby. do not breastfeed during treatment and for some time after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take ceritinib with food to improve tolerability and absorption. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice while on this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember unless your next dose is due within 12 hours. if the next dose is due within 12 hours, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, decreased appetite, fatigue, weight loss, and abnormal liver tests. serious effects include severe liver injury with yellowing of the skin or eyes or dark urine, pancreatitis with severe stomach pain, very high blood sugar with increased thirst or urination or confusion, lung inflammation with new or worsening cough or shortness of breath, slow or irregular heartbeat, fainting, and severe dehydration from diarrhea or vomiting. call your doctor for severe or persistent symptoms.

name: cerliponase alfa injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? cerliponase alfa is an enzyme replacement given to children with cln2 disease also called late infantile batten disease to slow the loss of ability to walk. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a trained health care team directly into the fluid around the brain through a special reservoir and catheter surgically placed under the scalp. it is usually given every other week. each infusion includes the medicine and a flushing solution and takes several hours. children are usually given an antihistamine with or without a fever reducer before each dose to reduce infusion reactions. the infusion must be done using strict sterile technique and with monitoring during and after the infusion. what special precautions should i follow? this medicine can cause hypersensitivity reactions including fever, vomiting, irritability, and in rare cases anaphylaxis. your child will be monitored for reactions during and after each infusion. there is a risk of infections including meningitis related to the implanted device. do not receive an infusion if there is a device related infection, leakage, swelling, redness, fever, severe headache, stiff neck, or if the device is not working properly. tell your care team about any heart rhythm problems, seizures, breathing problems, or if your child is ill on the day of infusion. periodic testing of cerebrospinal fluid for infection and device checks are recommended. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. maintain normal hydration and nutrition as advised by your care team. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your treatment center to reschedule as soon as possible and then return to the every other week schedule as directed. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fever, vomiting, irritability, upper respiratory infections, seizures, headache, and increased white blood cells in the cerebrospinal fluid. serious effects include severe hypersensitivity reactions, meningitis or other infections, device related complications such as leakage or dislodgement, and changes in heart rate or blood pressure during the infusion. seek urgent care for high fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, persistent vomiting, confusion, or any signs of device infection.

name: certolizumab injection
text: important warning: certolizumab lowers the ability of your immune system to fight infections. serious infections have happened in patients treated with certolizumab, including tuberculosis, sepsis, and infections caused by fungi and other opportunistic organisms, which can lead to hospitalization or death. your doctor will test for tuberculosis before starting and may treat it before you begin.right away if you have fever, cough, weight loss, night sweats, flu like symptoms, diarrhea, painful urination, skin wounds, or any signs of infection. lymphoma and other cancers, some fatal, have been reported in adults and children treated with medicines that block tumor necrosis factor. discuss your risks with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? certolizumab is used to reduce signs and symptoms and help prevent joint damage in rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, and non radiographic axial spondyloarthritis, to treat moderate to severe crohn disease, and to treat moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. it blocks a protein called tumor necrosis factor that drives inflammation. how should this medicine be used? certolizumab is given as a subcutaneous injection under the skin. many patients can self inject after training. dosing depends on the condition being treated. a common schedule is 400 mg at the start, then again at weeks 2 and 4, followed by 200 mg every 2 weeks or 400 mg every 4 weeks. rotate injection sites in the abdomen or thigh. do not inject into skin that is tender, bruised, red, or hardened. what special precautions should i follow?if you have any infections, frequent infections, diabetes, hiv, immune system problems, hepatitis b or c, heart failure, multiple sclerosis or other demyelinating disease, blood problems, cancer, or if you are scheduled for surgery or dental work. you will be screened for tuberculosis and hepatitis b before treatment. do not receive live vaccines while using certolizumab.about all medicines and supplements you use. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. maintain a healthy diet and avoid alcohol excess, especially if taking other medicines that affect the liver. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember and then resume your regular schedule. if you are not sure when to take the next dose, call your doctor or pharmacist. do not inject two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include injection site pain or redness, upper respiratory infections, headache, nausea, rash, and fatigue. serious effects include severe infections, reactivation of hepatitis b, nervous system problems such as seizures or new or worsening multiple sclerosis, heart failure worsening, low blood counts, lupus like syndrome, and certain cancers including lymphoma and skin cancers. seek urgent care for fever, shortness of breath, persistent cough, severe weakness, bruising or bleeding, or signs of allergic reaction such as hives, swelling, or trouble breathing.

name: cetirizine
text: why is this medication prescribed? cetirizine is an antihistamine used to relieve symptoms of allergies such as sneezing, runny nose, itchy or watery eyes, and itching due to hives. how should this medicine be used? take cetirizine by mouth once daily as directed. adults and children 12 years and older usually take 10 mg once daily. some adults may do well with 5 mg once daily. dosing for younger children depends on age and weight, so follow your doctors directions and the product label. if you use the liquid, measure with a dosing device. what special precautions should i follow? cetirizine may cause drowsiness in some people. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. avoid alcohol and other medicines that cause drowsiness unless your doctor approves.if you have liver or kidney problems, if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, or if you have difficulty urinating due to an enlarged prostate.about all medicines and supplements you use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. avoid alcohol because it can increase drowsiness. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dry mouth, fatigue, and headache. less common effects include stomach upset and agitation. serious reactions such as severe allergic reaction or swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat are rare but require immediate medical attention.

name: cetirizine injection
text: why is this medication prescribed? intravenous cetirizine is used for the treatment of acute hives in adults and children when rapid relief is needed and when the intravenous route is preferred or oral medicine is not appropriate. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a health care professional as a slow intravenous injection. adults and adolescents usually receive 10 mg given over one to two minutes. children receive weight or age based doses as directed by the prescriber. what special precautions should i follow?about any allergies, kidney or liver disease, pregnancy or breastfeeding, and all medicines you take. cetirizine can cause drowsiness. avoid alcohol and other sedating medicines unless your doctor approves. dose adjustments may be needed in kidney impairment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. avoid alcohol because it can increase drowsiness. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is usually given in a clinical setting. if you miss a scheduled dose, contact your health care provider as soon as possible. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, fatigue, headache, dry mouth, nausea, and discomfort at the injection site. serious allergic reactions are rare but require immediate medical attention if they occur, including hives, swelling, wheezing, or trouble breathing.

name: cetirizine ophthalmic
text: why is this medication prescribed? cetirizine eye drops are used to relieve itchy eyes due to allergic conjunctivitis. how should this medicine be used? instill one drop in the affected eye or eyes twice daily about 8 hours apart, or as directed. wash your hands before use. do not touch the dropper tip to any surface, including the eye. if you wear contact lenses, remove them before using the drops, wait at least 10 minutes after using the medicine before reinserting, and do not wear contacts if your eyes are red. what special precautions should i follow?if you have eye infections or injuries, glaucoma, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. use exactly as directed. stop use and contact your doctor if you develop eye pain, changes in vision, persistent redness, or irritation that worsens or lasts more than 72 hours. avoid driving or operating machinery until your vision clears after each dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include temporary eye irritation or burning when applied, redness, blurred vision, and headache. serious reactions are uncommon but can include severe eye pain, swelling, discharge, or sudden changes in vision. seek medical care if these occur.

name: cetuximab injection
text: important warning: cetuximab can cause severe and sometimes life threatening infusion reactions that most often occur with the first infusion. symptoms include trouble breathing, wheezing, chest tightness, dizziness, fainting, and low blood pressure. treatment should be stopped and emergency care provided if a severe reaction occurs. there is a risk of cardiopulmonary arrest and sudden death, especially when used with radiation for head and neck cancer. cetuximab can cause serious electrolyte disturbances including low magnesium, calcium, and potassium which may lead to abnormal heart rhythms. frequent monitoring and replacement are required during treatment and for at least eight weeks after the last dose. why is this medication prescribed? cetuximab is used to treat certain cancers that express the epidermal growth factor receptor, including metastatic colorectal cancer with ras wild type tumors and certain head and neck cancers. it may be used alone or with other treatments such as chemotherapy or radiation depending on the cancer type and stage. how should this medicine be used? cetuximab is given by intravenous infusion in a clinic or hospital. you will usually receive a premedication such as an antihistamine before the first dose and before later doses to lower the risk of infusion reactions. the dose and schedule depend on your cancer plan and may be given weekly or every two weeks. your care team will monitor your skin, electrolytes, and heart during therapy. report any new or worsening symptoms right away. use sun protection because skin reactions are common and sun exposure can make them worse. what special precautions should i follow?if you have ever had a severe reaction to cetuximab or to mouse proteins, and if you have heart disease, lung disease, electrolyte problems, or eye problems.about all medicines you take. some medicines can raise the risk of heart rhythm problems when combined with electrolyte abnormalities. use effective birth control during treatment and for at least two months after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for two months after the last dose. seek immediate care if you develop signs of an infusion reaction, severe skin rash, signs of infection, chest pain, or severe diarrhea. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. stay well hydrated. protect your skin from the sun by using sunscreen and protective clothing. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, contact your oncology clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to self administer this medicine. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include acne like skin rash, dry or itchy skin, nail changes, diarrhea, mouth sores, headache, and fatigue. serious effects include severe infusion reactions, severe skin reactions, eye irritation or pain, infection, low magnesium and other electrolytes which can cause muscle cramps or abnormal heart rhythms, interstitial lung disease with cough or shortness of breath, and cardiopulmonary arrest. call your doctor right away for severe or unusual symptoms.

name: cevimeline
text: why is this medication prescribed? cevimeline is used to treat dry mouth symptoms in people with sjogren syndrome. it works by stimulating saliva production. how should this medicine be used? take cevimeline by mouth as directed, usually three times daily. swallow the capsules with water and try to take each dose at the same times every day. it may take several weeks to feel the full benefit. if stomach upset occurs, taking it with food may help. what special precautions should i follow?if you have asthma, chronic bronchitis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, heart rhythm problems, low blood pressure, peptic ulcer disease, gallbladder disease, bile duct obstruction, urinary obstruction, kidney or liver problems, or narrow angle glaucoma. this medicine may cause sweating and increased urination and can raise the risk of dehydration. use caution in hot weather and drink adequate fluids. it may cause blurred vision, especially at night or in low light, so use caution when driving after dark.about all medicines you take including beta blockers, anticholinergic drugs, and other cholinergic agents.if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of water to stay hydrated. you may take doses with food if your stomach is upset. limit alcohol because it can worsen side effects such as dizziness. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include sweating, flushing, increased urination, nausea, diarrhea, stomach cramps, runny nose, cough, headache, and blurred vision. serious effects can include wheezing or shortness of breath, slow heart rate, chest pain, fainting, severe abdominal pain, gallbladder pain, urinary obstruction, and allergic reactions with rash, swelling, or trouble breathing. seek medical care for serious symptoms.

name: chenodiol
text: important warning: chenodiol can cause serious liver injury including elevated liver enzymes and, rarely, liver failure. liver function tests must be checked frequently during treatment, often monthly at the beginning, and the dose reduced or stopped if abnormalities occur. use this medicine only under the supervision of a doctor experienced with its risks. chenodiol can harm an unborn baby. do not use during pregnancy and use effective birth control during treatment. why is this medication prescribed? chenodiol is a bile acid used to treat certain conditions including dissolution of radiolucent cholesterol gallstones in carefully selected patients who cannot undergo surgery and treatment of cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis to reduce toxic bile alcohols. it is not effective for calcified or pigment gallstones and is generally used when other options are not suitable. how should this medicine be used? chenodiol is taken by mouth with food. dosing is individualized and may be started at a low dose and increased based on response and tolerance while monitoring liver tests. treatment for gallstones can take many months. regular blood tests to monitor liver function and cholesterol are required. do not change your dose without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow?if you have liver disease, a history of abnormal liver tests, bile duct obstruction, gallbladder inflammation, pancreatitis, high cholesterol or triglycerides, kidney disease, or if you are pregnant or planning to become pregnant. estrogen containing drugs may reduce the effectiveness of chenodiol for gallstones.about all medicines you take. use reliable non hormonal contraception when possible during therapy. keep all laboratory and imaging appointments. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow a diet low in cholesterol and saturated fat as recommended by your doctor. maintain a healthy body weight. limit or avoid alcohol to reduce liver stress. take doses with meals to improve tolerance. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea, headache, itching, and rash. it can raise ldl cholesterol. serious effects include liver injury with yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, right upper abdominal pain, severe or persistent diarrhea, and complications of gallstones such as gallbladder inflammation or pancreatitis. contact your doctor immediately if serious symptoms occur.

name: chloral hydrate
text: why is this medication prescribed? chloral hydrate is a sedative used short term for insomnia and to produce sedation before procedures. because of safety concerns and the availability of safer alternatives, its use has become uncommon. how should this medicine be used? take chloral hydrate by mouth exactly as directed. it is available as a liquid and as capsules. measure liquid doses with a proper measuring device. taking it with food or a full glass of water can help reduce stomach upset. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest possible time. do not stop regular use suddenly without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow?if you have heart disease, liver or kidney disease, stomach ulcers, sleep apnea, breathing problems, depression, a history of substance use disorder, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. do not drink alcohol or take other medicines that cause sleepiness unless your doctor tells you to. chloral hydrate can interact with many medicines including warfarin and can increase bleeding risk. it can cause dependence and withdrawal if used regularly for a long time. use caution when driving or operating machinery until you know how it affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. you may take doses with food or milk to reduce stomach upset. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you use it for sleep, take it only at bedtime. if you forget a bedtime dose and you are close to your planned wake time, skip the dose. if it is prescribed on a schedule for a procedure, contact your provider for instructions. do not take extra medicine to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and stomach discomfort. serious effects include slow or irregular heartbeat, low blood pressure, confusion, agitation, paradoxical excitement, breathing problems, signs of bleeding such as unusual bruising, severe allergic reactions, and liver problems. seek emergency help for severe symptoms such as trouble breathing or fainting.

name: chlorambucil
text: important warning: chlorambucil can cause severe bone marrow suppression leading to infections, anemia, and bleeding. blood counts will be checked regularly and the dose may be adjusted or stopped for low counts. chlorambucil is mutagenic and carcinogenic and has been associated with secondary cancers including leukemia. it can harm an unborn baby and may cause infertility in both males and females. use effective birth control during treatment and discuss fertility preservation with your doctor before starting therapy. why is this medication prescribed? chlorambucil is a chemotherapy medicine used to treat certain cancers including chronic lymphocytic leukemia and some types of lymphoma. it may be used alone or with other medicines as part of a treatment plan. how should this medicine be used? take chlorambucil by mouth exactly as directed. take it at the same time each day. swallow the tablets whole and do not crush or chew them. your doctor will decide the dose and schedule and will monitor your blood counts frequently. handle the tablets carefully and wash your hands after handling. what special precautions should i follow?about any infections, low blood counts, seizures, liver or kidney disease, and if you have recently had radiation or chemotherapy. avoid contact with people who have contagious infections.about all medicines and supplements you take. do not receive live vaccines during treatment. use effective birth control during treatment and for a period after the last dose as directed by your doctor. do not breastfeed during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. to reduce the risk of infection, follow food safety practices, avoid undercooked foods, and wash fruits and vegetables well. limit alcohol and stay well hydrated unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. if you vomit after a dose or miss more than one dose, contact your oncology team for instructions. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include low white blood cells, anemia, low platelets, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, mouth sores, rash, fatigue, and menstrual changes. serious effects include severe infections, bleeding, seizures, liver problems, severe allergic reactions, and secondary cancers. report fever, chills, unusual bruising or bleeding, severe sore throat, persistent vomiting or diarrhea, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or seizures right away.

name: chloramphenicol injection
text: important warning: chloramphenicol can cause serious and sometimes fatal blood disorders including aplastic anemia and bone marrow suppression. blood problems can occur during treatment or weeks to months after stopping. this medicine should be used only for serious infections when less risky medicines are not effective or cannot be used. regular blood count monitoring is required. use in newborns can cause gray baby syndrome which can be fatal. use with extreme caution and only when clearly needed. why is this medication prescribed? chloramphenicol is an antibiotic used to treat certain serious infections caused by susceptible bacteria, such as typhoid fever and some central nervous system or anaerobic infections, especially in patients who cannot use other antibiotics. how should this medicine be used? chloramphenicol injection is given into a vein by a healthcare professional. the dose is based on your weight, kidney and liver function, and the severity of the infection. your doctor may monitor blood levels and will check blood counts regularly. complete the full course as prescribed. what special precautions should i follow?if you have ever had bone marrow problems, low blood counts, anemia, eye or vision problems, or liver or kidney disease, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.about all medicines you take, including warfarin, phenytoin, phenobarbital, rifampin, and immunosuppressants, because interactions can be serious. report visual changes, numbness or tingling, persistent fever, or unusual bruising immediately. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. maintain good hydration. avoid excessive alcohol use. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion or injection appointment, contact your clinic right away to reschedule. do not attempt to administer this medicine yourself unless you have been trained to do so and your doctor directs you. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, mouth or vaginal yeast infections, and irritation at the injection site. serious effects include bone marrow suppression with low white blood cells, anemia, or low platelets, aplastic anemia that can be fatal, optic or peripheral neuritis with vision or nerve changes, severe allergic reactions, and gray baby syndrome in newborns. seek medical help for fever, sore throat, unusual bleeding or bruising, severe fatigue, or vision changes.

name: chlordiazepoxide and clidinium
text: important warning: this medicine contains chlordiazepoxide, a benzodiazepine. taking benzodiazepines with opioids can cause profound sedation, severe breathing problems, coma, and death. use together only if no alternative is available and with close medical supervision. benzodiazepines can cause abuse, misuse, and addiction, which may lead to overdose and death. physical dependence can occur with continued use and sudden discontinuation can cause life threatening withdrawal, including seizures. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration and taper slowly when stopping. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of chlordiazepoxide and clidinium is used along with other measures to help relieve symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome, peptic ulcer disease, and other functional gastrointestinal conditions by reducing anxiety and intestinal spasm. how should this medicine be used? take the capsules by mouth as directed, usually one capsule three or four times daily, before meals and at bedtime. swallow capsules whole. do not increase your dose or use longer than prescribed. when stopping, your doctor may reduce the dose gradually to avoid withdrawal. what special precautions should i follow?if you have a history of substance use disorder, depression or suicidal thoughts, glaucoma, urinary retention, enlarged prostate, myasthenia gravis, severe constipation or bowel obstruction, severe ulcerative colitis, respiratory disease including sleep apnea, liver or kidney disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. do not drink alcohol or use opioids or other medicines that cause sleepiness unless your doctor tells you to. this medicine can impair alertness. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. avoid other anticholinergic medicines unless approved.about all medicines you take, including cyp3a4 inhibitors such as certain azole antifungals and macrolide antibiotics. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take doses before meals and at bedtime as directed. avoid alcohol. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice because they may increase the sedative effects. drink adequate fluids and consume fiber to help prevent constipation. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time of your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, blurred vision, dry mouth, constipation, nausea, and difficulty urinating. serious effects include confusion particularly in older adults, severe constipation or intestinal blockage, glaucoma attack with eye pain and vision changes, allergic reactions, respiratory depression, and dependence and withdrawal symptoms such as anxiety, tremor, and seizures if the medicine is stopped suddenly. seek medical help for severe or unusual symptoms.

name: chlorhexidine topical
text: why is this medication prescribed? topical chlorhexidine is an antiseptic used to cleanse the skin to reduce bacteria, such as before surgery, for wound care, or for general skin antisepsis as directed by a healthcare professional. how should this medicine be used? use chlorhexidine on the skin exactly as directed. apply a small amount to the area and allow it to dry. for preoperative bathing or surgical scrub, follow the specific instructions provided to you, including contact time and rinsing if advised. external use only. keep out of eyes, ears, mouth, and genital mucosa. do not use on deep puncture wounds, serious burns, or large areas of broken skin unless your doctor instructs you to do so. allow solutions that contain alcohol to dry completely and keep away from open flame until dry. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have had an allergic reaction to chlorhexidine. severe allergic reactions including anaphylaxis have occurred with topical products. stop use and get medical help right away if you develop hives, swelling, dizziness, or trouble breathing. do not use in the ear canal especially if you have a perforated eardrum due to risk of hearing loss. avoid contact with the eyes. if contact occurs, rinse thoroughly with water. do not mix with other soaps or cleansers unless instructed, because they can inactivate chlorhexidine or irritate the skin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are using it on a schedule and miss an application, apply it when you remember. if it is almost time for the next application, skip the missed application and resume your regular schedule. do not over apply to make up for a missed application. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild skin irritation, redness, itching, or dryness where applied. less common but serious effects include severe skin irritation or chemical burns, allergic reactions with hives or swelling, hearing loss or ear pain if it enters the ear, and eye injury if splashed in the eye. seek medical care for severe or persistent reactions.

name: chloroquine
text: why is this medication prescribed? chloroquine is used to prevent and treat malaria caused by susceptible organisms and to treat extraintestinal amebiasis. in many regions malaria parasites are resistant, so your doctor will determine if chloroquine is appropriate for your travel or infection. how should this medicine be used? take chloroquine by mouth with food or milk to reduce stomach upset. for malaria prevention, begin one to two weeks before travel, continue once weekly during travel, and continue for four weeks after leaving the endemic area. for treatment, follow the dosing schedule provided by your doctor over two to three days. do not exceed the prescribed dose. do not use chloroquine to treat viral infections. if taking long term, you may need regular eye examinations. do not take antacids or kaolin within four hours of a dose because they can reduce absorption. what special precautions should i follow?if you have vision problems or retinal disease, heart disease or a history of abnormal heart rhythms, low potassium or magnesium, liver or kidney disease, psoriasis, porphyria, myasthenia gravis, seizure disorder, or g6pd deficiency, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.about all medicines you take, especially other medicines that can affect the heart rhythm, digoxin, cyclosporine, cimetidine, antiepileptics, and mefloquine. use caution when driving if you develop blurred vision or dizziness. seek immediate care for fainting or palpitations. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with a meal or milk. avoid alcohol excess. do not take antacids or kaolin within four hours of chloroquine. drink adequate fluids. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to your next dose. if you miss a weekly dose for prevention, take it as soon as possible and then continue the weekly schedule on the new day or as your doctor advises. do not take extra doses to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach cramps, decreased appetite, headache, dizziness, blurred vision, and itching. serious effects include heart rhythm disturbances with fainting or palpitations, seizures, severe mood or behavior changes, low blood sugar with sweating or confusion, muscle weakness, and irreversible retinal damage with vision loss with long term or high dose use. seek medical care for serious symptoms.

name: chlorpromazine
text: important warning: elderly patients with dementia related psychosis who are treated with antipsychotic medicines have an increased risk of death. chlorpromazine is not approved for the treatment of dementia related psychosis. why is this medication prescribed? chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders. it is also used to control severe nausea and vomiting, treat intractable hiccups, manage acute intermittent porphyria, and as an adjunct in the treatment of tetanus. how should this medicine be used? chlorpromazine can be taken by mouth as tablets or liquid, or given by injection in a healthcare setting. doses are individualized and may be increased gradually. take it at the same times each day. do not stop suddenly without medical advice. your doctor may order blood tests and heart tests and will monitor for movement side effects. use sun protection because this medicine can cause photosensitivity. avoid overheating and stay hydrated. what special precautions should i follow?if you have heart disease, a history of abnormal heart rhythms or prolonged qt, low potassium or magnesium, liver disease, glaucoma, urinary retention, prostate enlargement, seizure disorder, parkinson disease, myasthenia gravis, blood disorders, breast cancer or other prolactin sensitive tumors, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.about all medicines you take, especially other medicines that can prolong the qt interval, blood pressure medicines, anticholinergics, lithium, antidepressants, and opioids. this medicine can cause drowsiness and dizziness. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. seek immediate care if you develop high fever with stiff muscles and confusion which may indicate neuroleptic malignant syndrome, or if you develop uncontrolled movements which may indicate tardive dyskinesia. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. taking doses with food may reduce stomach upset. drink fluids and consume fiber to help prevent constipation. use sun protection to prevent photosensitivity reactions. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time of your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. if you miss an injection appointment, contact your clinic to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, low blood pressure when standing, weight gain, swelling, menstrual changes, and breast enlargement or discharge. serious effects include abnormal heart rhythms, seizures, blood disorders with fever or unusual bruising, cholestatic jaundice with yellowing of the skin or eyes, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, and tardive dyskinesia with involuntary movements that may be irreversible. photosensitivity reactions and skin discoloration may occur. seek medical help for serious or persistent symptoms.

name: chlorpropamide
text: important warning: chlorpropamide can cause prolonged and severe low blood sugar, especially in older adults, those who skip meals or drink alcohol, and people with kidney or liver problems. know the signs of hypoglycemia and how to treat it promptly. why is this medication prescribed? chlorpropamide is used along with diet and exercise to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes. it helps your pancreas release insulin and your body use insulin more effectively. how should this medicine be used? take chlorpropamide by mouth once daily with breakfast or your first main meal to reduce the risk of low blood sugar. take it at the same time each day. do not crush or split unless directed. your doctor will adjust the dose based on your blood glucose and a1c. check your blood sugar as instructed and do not stop or change the dose without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow?about kidney or liver disease, adrenal or pituitary problems, g6pd deficiency, sulfonylurea or sulfonamide allergies, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. avoid alcohol because it can cause a disulfiram-like reaction with flushing, nausea, and can dangerously lower blood sugar. be cautious when driving or operating machinery until you know how this medicine affects you. learn how to recognize and treat hypoglycemia and carry a source of fast-acting sugar. certain medicines can increase hypoglycemia risk, including other diabetes drugs, beta blockers, salicylates, warfarin, and some antibiotics; others may raise blood sugar. chlorpropamide can cause low sodium; report confusion, headache, or weakness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? eat regular meals with consistent carbohydrate intake and do not skip meals. avoid alcohol. follow your diabetes meal plan and stay hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember with food. if it is near the time of your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your normal schedule. do not take two doses at once. check your blood sugar more frequently if you missed a dose and contact your clinician if levels are very high or low. what side effects can this medication cause?
